documents.commentText:
Please do not place Kratom nor its derivatives into the DEA Schedule 1.  

Banning Kratom will deny access to safe and effective pain relief for many returning war veterans like my stepson.

Kratom has been used safely by millions of people in the U.S. and evidence supports kratom's potential as a pain reliever and opioid replacement.  

Many people struggling with opioid addiction have turned to kratom to help them cut back or quit, but now all promising scientific studies on kratom's role in opioid treatment could be immediately shut down.  Side effects of kratom are minimal, and its withdrawal symptoms are weak and nearly inconsequential compared to the suffering of people trying to quit opioids.

Prohibiting kratom will worsen the country's problems of opioid addiction and overdose. 

Barry Schaeffer
Anacortes WA

documents.commentText:
I am a 46 year old mother of two children biologically, as well as many other children I have fostered and had live with me that I also call mine. I worked as a hospice care nurse and a daycare provider for as many years as I could until the pain and fatigue stopped me. I don't drink or smoke and I have never taken illegal drugs. I was diagnosed with SLE Lupus in 1999 after a few years of wondering why I was always so tired and hurting. After that I was also diagnosed with Fibromyalgia, Degenerative Disc Disease and Psoriatic Arthritis among other things. Some of the medications I took for these illnesses caused weight gain and raised my blood sugar, I became obese and was diagnosed with diabetes and high blood pressure. 
     After trying every other option my doctor could think of: physical therapy, NSAIDs, steroids, counseling, meditation, antidepressants for a few examples, I was prescribed opioid medications around 2002. I was prescribed opioid pain medication safely and effectively for about 10 years until these legal medications became the drug of choice for many addicts. In an attempt to take these medications out of the wrong hands, they were also taken from my hands in 2012. 
     While I was prescribed the opioids for pain, my home was cleaned, my children were well cared for, I was able to go shopping, work, volunteer, help friends and neighbors and see my friends and family for holidays and social events. I couldn't work as a nurse, but I had gone back to college for accounting and hoped to have a new job, at a desk, so I could still be productive. 
     Once I lost the opioid pain medication I lost my chance to finish college, to have a job, to take care of myself and my home, to have a social life and hobbies. In fact I was basically bedridden other than doctor appointments and occassionally shopping for groceries. I had completely lost any quality of life.
     In 2015 I found out about Kratom from a chronic pain support group. Some in the group had taken it to help with withdrawal symptoms when their doctors had forced them to abruptly go off opioid medication and they said it seemed to help manage their pain as well. I was scared to try it at first, I didn't know if it was some kind of fancy new drug the kids were all into - and I want no part of something like that! I asked a lot of questions and did some research myself to find out that it is an herbal supplement like glucosamine, chondroitin or turmeric which I have also tried. I decided to try it and it's been a true life saver, I'm starting to feel like myself again.
     Since I've been taking Kratom, I've been able to walk 3-5 miles daily and have lost 70lbs., a little overweight but no longer obese. I'm able to go shopping as often as I want, get fruits and vegetables and stand in the kitchen long enough to prepare and cook them. I now control my blood sugar by diet and exercise alone. I am currently back in school, able to concentrate enough to read and finish homework and getting good grades. I'm hoping to start a job soon after I finish. I still have all the same illnesses that I had before, Kratom doesn't cure anything, the difference is that I am able to manage them. I am able to get up, get out and actually live as opposed to sitting in bed watching everyone else live. My pain is controlled enough that am I able to have some quality of life again and I am hopeful. I actually see myself having a future now.

Hello my name is Ryan and I am 27 years old. I am a father of 2 young children. 3 year old son with autism and 4 month old beautiful baby girl. I am a full time working tax paying citizen. I don not use any drugs or drink alcohol. The only thing I use on a daily basis is kratom. It is an amazing tool to help pain and fight the rising opioid/opiate epidemic in America.


I am against the ban of kratom.2 years ago i broke my spine. I was then prescribed oxycodone and dilaudid. Needless to say I got addicted to the pharmaceutical pain killers. I needed them to function. My doctors then one day just stopped refilling my prescriptions. I am still in severe pain to this day but my doctors will not manage my pain because of "DEA regulations". After being cut off my medication I applied for disability because there was no way I could function in the amount of pain I'm in. I did a lot of research on natural botanicals that could help me out. I came across kratom and tried it. It changed my life. I could get out of bed,go to work, and take care of my children. I canceled my disability and went back to work full time. I now feel like my old regular self again. Kratom helps me with the pain without getting me high or foggy. I can care for my 3 year old and 4 month old children. I'm a law abiding tax paying citizen. If kratom is scheduled I will have to go back on disability and be unable to care for my young children.

You cannot overdose on kratom. You cannot die from kratom. It's literally impossible unless your using multiple narcotics together. Kratom has been blamed for numerous deaths but has never been the only thing in the bloodstream. All of the deaths are from people mixing kratom with multiple deadly drugs. Which kratom is not. Scheduling this botanical will do nothing but make the opioid/opiate epidemic even worse. In states where kratom was banned the opioid over doses quickly stacked up. There's enough proof right there to see what will happen if you schedule this plant. Please do not schedule this benign botanical. This scheduling willl do only harm and nothing good can come out of this. I think regulation is the proper thing to do. An age limit like alcohol would make sense. Banning it would not.

I'm writing this testimony in response to the proposed scheduling of Kratom (mitragyna speciosa). I'm not sure where to begin, other than say that quite simply kratom has saved my life and my sanity.  I suffer from extreme anxiety, and ever since taking kratom (for approximately one year) my panic/anxiety attacks have completely, 100% disappeared.  

I started taking kratom after being referred to it from a friend who also suffered from extreme anxiety.  Before I tried it, the ONLY thing that would alleviate my problem was taking prescription opiates, which are quite obviously illegal to obtain.  I discovered this when I had to get a tooth pulled and was given some by my dentist.  My head cleared, my pain went away, and my anxiety was GONE for the first time in probably 15 years. When my prescription ran out my problems came back though.  Rather than turn to heroin, I decided on a whim to try kratom. I am proud to say that I have not taken a prescription pill in over a year because of kratom.  I am able to concentrate at work without having anxiety, and my family life at home is also MUCH better as I simply do not worry anymore. 

To be quite honest, I'm absolutely petrified at the thought of not having access to kratom anymore.  It legitimately saved my life and my mental stability.  I do not take it to "get high" and I have never experienced an overdose from it.  It just simply provides me with mental clarity, concentration and eliminates my anxiety 100%.  I have been able to completely function as a normal member of society for one full year thanks to it.  

Please take this into consideration when making your decision.  I am scared of losing my sanity, but I am even more scared about what I'm going to do if it becomes illegal. I've never filled out a form or anything like this before, but this decision quite simply affects me more than maybe anything else in my entire life.  Thank your for your time.

documents.commentText:
My name is Chelsea. I am 24 and now am a Licensed Nail Technician. I was born with short Achilles' tendons, but I did not know until I was 12. I grew up always in pain when I would stand for long periods of time. I remember going to the mall with my mom and crying from the pain from only standing for a good 30 minutes. I have a distinct memory of going to Gettysburg with my 4th grade class. We walked one of the battlefields, the pain was so excrutiating I was crying as well as sitting every chance I could find. The main thing I remember is one of my classmates fathers was a doctor. And the look of disgust/annoyance he kept giving my mom and I. He looked at me like I was a lazy, complaining child. Growing up I got that a lot from many different people; 
teachers, parents, as well as my elementary school principals. When I was 11, my mom, brother and I moved to a small town in Northern California. My mom started working for a podiatrist and immediately booked me an appointment with him. She was the only one who knew there was something more going on. That appointment we found out that I had short Achilles' tendons. Normal people can stretch their legs to a good 14 degree angle. My good leg I was measured at a 4. We tried many different things with nothing truly helping. When I turned 18 we made the decision to do surgery. I had my first surgery 3 months after I graduated high school. And the second surgery we did a year later. I had a good 2 years of rehabilitation. I was able to take a few online classes but that was all during that time. Those 2 years I relied solely on my parents, and coming out of the second year I knew I had to get a job to help out. I was able to get a job with the only grocery store in my town. I was made a cashier and eventually worked in every department. The 3 and a half years I worked there were excrutiating. There were no positions that you were able to sit, I stood for 8 hours a day, 6 days a week. I took aleve throughout the day with it not helping whatsoever. My general doctor as well as the podiatrist worked together and I tried many different medications during that time with them not helping at all either. They started giving me Vicodin, which was the only way I was able to get through those days. The last year I was taken off pain medication, since I am so young they did not want me relying on it. I was back to square one hurting every minute of everyday with no relief. I ended up quitting my job and having my 3rd and 4th surgery done, which I truly feel didn't help either. I have seen a few different doctors and each one tells me they can't do anything more and they don't know what to tell me. 
6 months after my 4th surgery I was reading an article about Kratom and decided to give it a try. It has changed my life. It helps me like ibuprofen and aleve help normal people (at least that's what it seems like). I have been taking Kratom for a year and a half now. I have gone to school and now have a job as a nail technician. I know that I will always have pain. I'm at the point where I just have to find ways to live with it. Step number 1 is not ever having a job that requires me to stand. I used to be in excrutiating pain, I honestly don't like looking back, it reminds me how consumed with pain I was.  Ever since I've been taking Kratom, I have been able to actually live life. Before there were so many things I would miss out on. But now I'm able to do all those things and honestly I am still in a little pain but Kratom makes it so I can handle the pain. I love being outdoors. I love hiking, exploring and everything that comes with the outdoors, and before I wasn't able to do any of the things I truly love. Kratom has made it so I can still do the things I love. I wouldn't be me if I wasn't able to do those things.
This August I heard that the DEA is planning on making Kratom a schedule 1 substance. I was absolutely devastated. I cried and called my parents asking what I'm going to do. I can't even imagine going back to the way I was living before. I can't go back to the pain I was in. What kind of life is that?  The DEA has no right to take Kratom away from people who's lives it has changed. Reading some of the articles about what the head of the DEA has said about Kratom just shows that they have no clue what Kratom even is. And I honestly feel like, with this irresponsible decision they have made, they do not have our best interests at heart. They do not care about the people who take Kratom, they do not care about any citizen in this country, because if they did, they would realize how much it has helped people like me. The positive direction my life is heading now. So I ask you DEA if any of you are reading this do not take this away from us. The doctors have failed me, the medications have failed me. But please do not take away the one thing that has not failed me. Kratom has given me a life again. Please do not take that away from me. 
Thank you for reading.

documents.commentText:
Hello,

I stand firmly in opposition to scheduling kratom or any of its active alkaloids this December. As a pre-med student, I have been closely following the growing opioid epidemic across the US. In the context of that scourge, kratom appears to be a great help to many recovering opiate users: it provides many of the benefits of methadone or suboxone maintenance therapy to patients too remote or too poor to afford going to more traditional clinics. Additionally, the risk of deadly respiratory depression from overdose seems virtually nonexistent (a rare quality in opioid analgesics), and subjective withdrawal syndromes seem less severe than those associated with traditional maintenance drugs like buprenorphine.

Moreover, scheduling mitragynine and associated alkaloids poses a significant threat to clinical research. These compounds represent a promising frontier in pharmaceutical research. In the next few decades, kratom-based drug discovery research has serious potential to yield a less harmful alternative to disastrously addictive and diversion-prone drugs like Vicodin and Oxycontin.

For these reasons, and for the relative scarcity of cases of drastic harm due to kratom use, I urge the DEA to refrain from scheduling kratom, mitragynine, and the related alkaloids.

Thank you.

--Prohibiting kratom will worsen the country's problems of opioid addiction and overdose.

documents.commentText:
Thank you for offering a comment period regarding the proposed scheduling of kratom.  It is important to have a public dialog concerning the legality of plant materials and other drugs.

I don't use kratom, nor do I personally know anyone who does.  I have an interest in maintaining the legal status of any plant based medicine.  In most cases replacement of pharmaceutically based medicines with plant based alternative is much less damaging to the body and less addictive and more cost effective as well.  I have successfully used cannabis as a pain management tool for arthritis instead of taking NSAIDs or other pharmaceuticals.  I sympathize with those who are using kratom to manage their pain and am happy for them that they have found a safe medicine.  The threat of having something taken away from them that is effective in their pain mitigation is disturbing; many will risk becoming felons as they continue to use it if the ban goes into effect.  It is important that those people do not become "criminals" because of a ban.  The US already has the largest prison population in the world because of our ineffective war on drugs.  Let us stop this insanity.  Regulate kratom, allow its sale only to adults, require that if come with warning documentation just like any other over the counter medicine, but please do not ban it and continue to add to the mindless incarceration rates of American citizens who only choose to manage their pain.  Consider a mandate of yours to be the education of the citizens on the safe ways to use plant based medicines like kratom.

documents.commentText:
I am so relieved the DEA suspended it's proposal to schedule kratom as a scheduled drug, and urge them to withdraw the ban permanently. 
Kratom has helped so many people who suffer from chronic illnesses like I do. It's helped eliminate or drastically reduce our need to take prescription painkillers (opioids) just to get through the day. I have been diagnosed with degenerative disc disease, fibromyalgia, and depression as well as migraine headaches and extreme fatigue. At one point I was taking fentanyl, hydromorphone, tramadol, topamax, cymbalta, and several other medications in order to keep my pain under control. I couldn't drive and could barely function because I was so doped that my pain management doctor prescribed adderal to counteract the sedative effects. I was 30 years old and on more medications than my grandparents. 
Long story short, I've been able to stop taking all the pain medicine and am down to thyroid medication and a mild antidepressant in addition to kratom. My pain is manageable and on "good" days I don't even notice it. My depression symptoms have lessened as well and I have the energy to get through the day without having to spend the next week in bed from overdoing things. If it weren't for kratom I'd still be seeing my pain management doctor every month and going though my life in a narcotic daze. I was so worried that this would happen back in August when the ban was proposed and ask that the DEA to please not deny people with chronic conditions the quality of life they deserve.

documents.commentText:
I am requesting that you do not make the natural plant/substance kratom a schedule 1 controlled substance.  I was diagnosed with Tarlov Cyst disease 4 years ago and suffer from constant pain.  Tarlov cysts are perineural/perineurial, or sacral nerve root cysts. They are dilations of the nerve root sheaths and are abnormal sacs filled with cerebrospinal fluid.  These cyst compress all my nerves from s1 to s4 and have worn away the bone in my sacrum causing constant pain.  The prescribed hydrocodone that I must take for the rest of my life is proven to be highly addictive. It causes me nausea, constipation and a constant feeling of being 'loopy'.  This makes working and being a contributing member of society extremely difficult.

My daughters who have been taking kratom for menstrual cramps for several years recommended I try kratom for my constant nerve pain.  I was amazed that drinking a tea from a natural plant could provide pain relief without the horrible side effects and addiction that hydrocodone causes.  Before taking kratom I suffered rather than take the risk of becoming addicted to hydrocodone.  Kratom is a non addictive natural supplement that has provided me enough pain relief to be able to work and be there for my family.  

Please do not ban a natural substance that has been used around the world for centuries. This proposed scheduling will have a negative effect on many peoples lives.

documents.commentText:
To whom this may concern,  

Thank you for taking the opportunity to read my comment and make the necessary appropriation to establish Kratom (Mitragyna Speciosa) as a non lethal plant that can aid and alleviate many common concerns that are being suffered throughout the United States.  

Allow me to introduce myself.  My name is Robert Gomez, a 46 yr old graphic artist that lives in El Paso TX.  I have surrounded myself in the natural health industry for more than two decades and would consider myself an overall healthy individual with no sign of addictive tendencies.  I don't smoke and my strongest "vice" if you need to know would be a strong cup of coffee or two every morning.  

For most of my adult life I have had to deal with the symptoms of adult ADHD and mild depression that would manifest in several uncommon ways.  The lack of motivation, anxiety and lack of concentration or focus were becoming bothersome with no end in sight.  I began to research natural alternatives to support my brain and overall health.  When i read upon Kratom, I was skeptical but decided to give it a try.  I didn't have anything else to lose by this point. 

Kratom has been a godsend.  It has helped me conquer everyday tasks along with my ability to focus and concentrate unlike anything else.  My mood and overall outlook has been uplifted and I no longer feel as if I'm going down a deep hole with no end in sight.  What is even better than the effect I feel is the fact that I don't have ANY side effects while taking it.  Kratom is a wonderful self regulating plant.  It's effective in lower doses and more sedating in higher ones.  If anyone insists on passing the "threshold" dosage, he/she will simply feel nauseous and/or eliminate by throwing up.  You feel fine once it's out of your system.  One quickly learns that more is not necessarily better.  

I aid in the care of my elderly mother who is 78 with Osteoarthritis, Diabetes and HBP.  I have been able to wean her off of the Hydrocodone and Tramadol that she was being prescribed by supplementing with Kratom. documents.commentText:
I am a 41 year old woman who works in the substance abuse field as a Masters level counselor. Additionally, I happen to be in recovery myself - sober from drugs and alcohol for almost 8 years now. What I see, day in and day out, combined with my personal, first-hand experience with Kratom leads me to be EXTREMELY troubled and quite frankly BAFFLED regarding the DEA's plan to schedule Kratom as a controlled substance.

For well over a year, I have been using Kratom regularly - both safely and responsibly. I drink Kratom much like one consumes coffee, tea or soda. As a matter of fact, in my experience, coffee is FAR more addictive and quite a bit stronger than Kratom - which is why I fail to understand how Kratom would be categorized with hard core drugs.

Many of my good friends and acquaintances also consume Kratom. All do it safely and responsibly. As a matter of fact, I've NEVER even heard of anyone abusing Kratom. What I have heard from the patients I work with is that Kratom is one of the only things that can prevent them from becoming "dope-sick" when they are trying to get off opiates or heroin. Many patients can't afford methadone, suboxone or the like but can't bear to go through the excruciating withdrawal. It is cruel to deprive these people from the opportunity of accessing a natural and inexpensive remedy seeing as so many are suffering intensely on a regular basis. I truly wish all opiate addicts knew of Kratom as I am confident it could save many lives. This is why I fail to grasp how this beneficial plant could be so misunderstood.

Because I am a recovered alcoholic, I think it is fair to say I understand how addiction feels and know first-hand the damage it causes. Working in the field of substance abuse has made me extremely familiar with other peoples addictions as well as the impact on family and society. I am absolutely 100% clear that Kratom does not even remotely compare to any addictive substances including legal alcohol. Alcohol and nicotine are FAR more damaging and addictive.

Please do not prevent us from harnessing this plant that has so much promise. Kratom has healing properties and can possibly mitigate the devastating epidemic of opiate abuse. Today more people are dying from opiate overdoses than from car accidents or guns. Clearly our opiate problem has reached catastrophic proportions. Is it sane or reasonable to ban a natural remedy that could help save millions of lives? Perhaps we would be better served exploring solutions to the problem instead of mislabeling a remedy. Please consider how many people could be helped by Kratom. Please consider how many people are ALREADY being helped by Kratom. Please prioritize human lives and scientific evidence over misinformation and misunderstanding. Please do the research.

Sincerely,

A recovered alcoholic substance abuse counselor and Kratom supporter

documents.commentText:
I write to oppose the DEAs proposal to make the alkaloids mitragynine and 7-hydroxymitragynine, two constituents of the kratom plant, schedule 1 controlled substances. This would put kratom  a plant consumed safely in the U.S for decades and world-wide for millennia, and one that helps millions of people  on the same level as illegal drugs like heroin. The DEA scheduling would also prevent further research which, to date, has shown the primary alkaloids in kratom to be beneficial without causing respiratory depression; the main cause of death from opiate overdose.

Kratom is a regulated dietary ingredient. Kratom is not a drug. Kratom is not addictive.

I do not believe Kratom should be reclassified as a Schedule 1 controlled substance. 

Thank you,
Jean OMalley
Professor, Hudson Valley Community College

documents.commentText:
Docket No. DEA-442W

Dear DEA, please do not put Kratom on the Schedule 1 drug list.  It is the only thing that has any effect on my pain due to peripheral neuropathy.  Please do more research and when I say research at least study.  As the opioid painkiller and heroin epidemic kills tens of thousands of Americans each year, some pain patients have turned to alternatives to opioids to ease their pain without as big of a risk of addiction and overdose. One of those alternatives is kratom, which appears to have  although, again, we dont know for sure, since the research is scarce  fewer deadly risks than opioids, yet can still relieve peoples pain.

The best overview of kratoms effects comes from a 2015 study published in the Journal of Psychoactive Drugs. The study noted that there wasnt rigorous scientific research on kratoms effects on humans. So it instead analyzed hundreds of anecdotal accounts from Erowid, a popular website for drug users and researchers, to gauge its effects.

The study found several positive effects (from most to least common): euphoria, relaxation, enhanced sociability, increased energy, pain relief, sensory enhancement, and warmth or tingling. It also found some negative effects (from most to least common): nausea and stomachaches, withdrawal (from addiction), chills and sweats, dizziness and unsteadiness, vomiting, hangovers, and itching. Reviewing other research, the study found no good evidence that kratom alone has caused deadly overdoses.

According to the study, the pain relief element has become particularly promising for pain patients who want to seek alternatives to highly addictive, potentially deadly opioid painkillers. The study also found that kratom may aid with easing withdrawal from opioid addiction.

The Transnational Institute, in its 2011 report, noted these benefits have been known in other parts of the world for a long time:

Many studies report that the effect of kratom on the body reduces pain from withdrawal symptoms and helps manage detoxification. Interviews with [Thai] community members and leaders indicated that many people have been using kratom to wean themselves off heroin, yaba, and even alcohol and tobacco dependence. Indeed, 60 years ago, when kratom became a controlled substance in Thailand, its potential for management of opiate dependence had been widely recognised.
But how do the positives and negatives of kratom compare to opioid painkillers and other drugs? Chris Ingraham, whos done a lot of great reporting on kratom at the Washington Post, scoured Erowid for positive and negative anecdotal accounts for several drugs and how they compared to the positive and negative accounts for kratom. He put them all together in this chart, which suggests that kratom is less risky than marijuana and the opioid painkiller oxycodone:



Still, the ranking suggests kratom is relatively safe. So why did the DEA move to ban it?

Why the DEA moved to ban kratom
The seal for the DEA.
Mandel Ngan/AFP via Getty Images
The DEAs initial decision to ban kratom came as the drug had slowly gained some popularity in the US.

With that popularity came more negative reports of kratom abuse: The Centers for Disease Control and Prevention reported that the number of calls involving kratom to US poison centers "increased tenfold from 26 in 2010 to 263 in 2015." And the DEA has tracked 15 deaths linked to kratom between 2014 and 2016  although none of those deaths were directly attributed to kratom, since people often use it with other drugs.

Given these concerns, the DEA at first concluded that it needed to ban kratom to "avoid an imminent hazard to the public safety." So it moved to classify kratom as schedule 1  meaning the agency would consider kratom to have high potential for abuse and no recognized medical value, and banning its sales and production. (As of now, kratom is on the DEAs list of "drugs of concern," meaning the agency is keeping an eye on the drug but not officially banning it.)

THE DEA AT FIRST CONCLUDED THAT IT NEEDED TO BAN KRATOM TO "AVOID AN IMMINENT HAZARD TO THE PUBLIC SAFETY"
But the biggest issue for the DEA seemed to be that we just dont know enough about kratom.

Generally, in the US, drugs are regulated to ensure their safety and effectiveness. The DEAs mission is in large part to ensure that drugs are not being abused recreationally, but also to ensure that drugs that are often abused recreationally are available for use as medicine if theres research to support medical use. It typically does this by locking drugs into different schedules that measure potential for abuse and medical value.

Please research this more. Making it a schedule 1 drug will only put innocent people into an already overcrowded prison system.

My name is Dustin, I am 42 years old and employed as a produce manager at.a local grocery store. I started using kratom about 3 years ago to deal with chronic pain and major depression. I've tried a multitude of  prescription anti-depressant as well as talk therapy with very limited success. I have also been prescribed narcotic painkillers in an effort to deal with my chronic pain. I found them effective but worried about the potential for becoming dependent on them. I would take these pain killers when I had unrelenting pain but after my pain flare ups improved I would discontinue taking them. I experienced withdrawal from these prescriptions even though I never took more than prescribed. I read about kratom online and heard it was effective for pain but with fewer problems than prescription narcotics. I was amazed that when I took kratom several days in a row for my pain flare ups that not only did my pain improve but I felt significantly less depressed. Furthermore, when I discontinued kratom after about a week and a half, I felt none of the withdrawal symptoms that I did when using my prescription Percocet. I strongly oppose scheduling kratom or its alkaloids as a Scheduled I substance. This is a plant that is on this planet to help people. Adding it to Schedule I would inevitably lead me to seek
 relief through Dr prescribed narcotics. I don't want to be forced into that situation by the criminalization of this plant. In my opinion, Schedule I status would restrict the scientific research needed on this plant and from personal experience, kratom is FAR less dangerous than Percocet or Vicodin. 
                                                          Sincerely,
                                                                 Dustin Hauer

documents.commentText: From first hand experience, I believe that Scheduling Kratom is ultimately best for the people of this country. I myself have struggle with Opiate addiction. For the better part of a decade, and when I found kratom, it did not offer me solice; it just replaced my needles and back alley meetings for stomachs full of capsules and daily visits to local head shops. People that believe this a cure for addiction, ESPECIALLY Opiate addiction, are sadly mistaken. This drug produces identical feelings to low amounts of heroin, and it is also EXTREMELY habit forming. I was addicted, physically and mentally, to kratom for over a gear. While the withdrawl from it was not as severe, it was very, very unpleasant. I would hedge a serious bet that anyone else with the same affinity for drug abuse that have would too experience a substitution of kratom for their current Opiate drug of choice. Again, not only does it produce similar effects, but it is legal! Which is rediculous. If this drug is so helpful to those with pain, then it could atleast be a schedule 2 drug, with some kind of regulation. This drug is currently available at almost every head shop in my city, to anyone 18 or older (or potentially younger, because who's to say how strict these business owners even card their younger customers.) It is utterly absurd to me that a drug that is physically habit forming can be so openly sold on the open market, both at brick and mortar locations, as well as from the click of a button from dozens of Internet sites.  Kratom addiction brought me to a place of utter hopelessness and near suicide. All it takes to create a habit in someone using this drug is a couple uses. Anyone that has a genetic predisposition to addiction will find this drug, see that it's legal and easy to get, and possibly get addicted. Not only those people, but this, much like "spice" (synthetic Marijuana), is just another loophole drug that people trying to avoid failing drug tests can take. Substitution of one addiction for another is not the answer. Maintenance drugs are not the cure for addiction in today's world. I can see this just becoming the next suboxone or methadone, which have arguably been failures in the sense that all these doctors are doing are getting their patients dependent on something they prescribe, rather than something they buy on the street. My only positive comments on Kratom are that I do believe that it is a better alternative to perscription opioids for those who are in chronic, severe pain.  Because of this, I believe this drug should be able to be distributed to those who need it, but only by licensed professionals, after it has been researched by the FDA. I know me saying this kind of contradicts my previous statements on doctors prescribing maintenence drugs, but atleast if someone has to have a license to prescribe and distribute the drug, then it will immensely cut down on the chances of it falling into the hands of those people who want to abuse it to get high.  Please, I implore you to take this drug off of the streets. There is a reason that so many other countries have made it illegal; when not used for proper reasons, it can negatively impact, and even destroy lives! Leaving this drug available for purchase and distribution by Americans who either have no clue what the possiblength outcomes of its abuse are, or who actively sell it knowing that it will get their customers hooked (in turn making them huge profits and daily eevenue) is just plain immoral, and wrong!!! TAKE KRATOM OFF THE OPEN MARKET IN THE UNITED STATES!!!!!!!

documents.commentText: My boyfriend is an addict and was addicted to heroin for several years before I met him. He has always had issues with pain and someone introduced him to kratom a couple of years ago. He has struggled with addiction to it ever since. The problem was made worse since it was so easy to get. He acts as if he is addicted to heroin and can't get off of it. He says it is just as bad as heroin. He does go through withdrawals when he tries. He has resorted to stealing from me so he can get it. He tells me he is off of it and has gotten himself into recovery groups but then he wants to get high just one more time and it is a vicious cycle. Kratom controls him! It is not harmless! He can't control himself because of the Kratom. These people who say that it helps them so much probably couldn't get off of it if they tried. Thankfully, he started taking Naltrexon and now is getting the Vivitrol shots. This is the only thing that is keeping him clean. He was so happy when he heard the DEA was going to make it a schedule 1 and I know the temptation will be hard for him if it is not changed to a schedule 1 drug. He won't be able to be on the Naltrexon/Vivitrol forever and I am very scared what will happen when that stops. I do hope you will make kratom a schedule 1 drug and save innocent people from getting addicted because they think there is no harm in it. That is the farthest thing from the truth. Kratom is addictive and dangerous and should not be sold over the counter.

documents.commentText:
The DEA should stop any and all consideration of banning the herbal supplement kratom. There should be no prohibition. While the FDA is looking into it as well, most Americans have never heard of it. Why? Because there's NO REAL PROBLEM with it! Quite the contrary...

Kratom seems like a solution to a number of issues, including various forms of drug addiction and chronic pain. Plus, it can perform the pain-killing work of morphine without dangerously depressing breathing -- the way opioids do.

Here's how Kratom works...
It uses a pathway that mediates many of the undesirable effects of traditional opioids such as constipation, respiratory depression. In fact, this knowledge is spurring additional research by pharmaceutical companies.
http://bit.ly/2c8UTI6

About Kratom, a leading researcher notes...
Thailand is considering legalizing kratom as a safer alternative for meth addicts. U.S. researchers are trying to study its potential to help opiate abusers kick the habit without withdrawal side effects.
http://bit.ly/2c8SI7v
There are anecdotal reports of addiction risk. But it appears the addiction can be broken without withdrawal symptoms. Meanwhile, the painkillers currently being used are more addictive, dangerous, and harder to kick. Yet...

The FDA and DEA both appear ready to ban kratom and effectively kill research to further develop this substance. Is the DEA is running cover for a Big Pharma company that wants to monopolize kratom?

As I consider these actions by the FDA and DEA I'm forced to wonder -- WHAT ARE YOU PEOPLE SMOKING

documents.commentText:
To whom it may concern,

I am a 31-year old professional who strongly opposes the scheduling of kratom and its derivatives due to the positive impact it has had on my life. I spent the majority of my 20's addicted to opiate painkillers and contribute my ability to thrive in both my professional and family roles to kratom. When I was addicted to opioids, I was spending every dime I had on getting more. Trying to get sober without any sort of assistance was completely debilitating and incompatible with my desire to achieve success in my career and be a good father. The drugs that the pharmaceutical companies have decided are acceptable for use as an opiate cessation tool are highly addictive, expensive, dangerous, and difficult to access. Kratom is NONE of these things. With kratom I am able to cope with my frequent back pain without having to resort to dangerous and addictive opioid medications. Furthermore, I am able to afford it comfortably and do not have to worry about running out of money or resources to obtain it. I don't have to worry about going to sleep and never waking up. I don't have to worry about resorting to dangerous acts in order to obtain it. At least, I won't have to worry about those things if the DEA determines that scheduling kratom as a Schedule 1 substance is completely unnecessary and reactionary.

Hundreds of thousands of people rely on kratom to remain free from pain, sober, and mentally well. Kratom has not been associated with dangerous crime the way that drugs of abuse have, and that is just one of many reasons why it does not belong on the List of Controlled Substances. I implore you to not restrict people's freedom to find wellness from naturally occurring sources. I am confident that the country is in a better state with kratom being available than without.

documents.commentText:
Dear DEA, 

Please do not ban kratom. 

Banning kratom expands the war on drugs, while the public overwhelmingly supports ending it. If kratom is added to any one of the five drug schedules, people who use it will be criminalized and locked up behind bars. Kratom has been used safely by millions of people in the U.S. and evidence supports kratom's potential as a pain reliever and opioid replacement. Many people struggling with opioid addiction have turned to kratom to help them cut back or quit, but now all promising scientific studies on kratom's role in opioid treatment could be immediately shut down. Side effects of kratom are minimal, and its withdrawal symptoms are weak and nearly inconsequential compared to the suffering of people trying to quit opioids.
Lastly, prohibiting kratom will worsen the country's problems of opioid addiction and overdose.

Sincerely, 
A concerned US citizen

documents.commentText:
My name is Brenda and I am a 62 yr old female. I am a full time employee as a registrar for a school district.  I am writing in opposition to the DEA putting kratom on the list of schedule 1 controlled substances.  I was introduced to kratom a year ago by my brother.  My brother had researched a way to free himself from a 12 yr addiction to oxycontin which had been prescribed to him by his doctor for various medical conditions.  He had never heard of kratom before but found blogs by people who had freed themselves from opiate addictions  by drinking kratom tea.  He ordered some and within 2 weeks with no withdrawal symptoms he was free from oxycontin and has not used it since.  
I have found that this plant  works better to ease the  pain of my diabetic neuropathy, arthritis and sciatica than any of the drugs prescribed by doctors.  I have never ever felt, foggy headed, drugged or had a negative reaction when I use it, in fact just the opposite.
I get a lift much like a good cup of coffee. I am very clear headed and more productive. 
My mother who is 82 also uses it now to ease the pain of old age and finds that she feels more productive also.  She has also never had a negative reaction.  Kratom is not something that is used recreationally.  
In conclusion Kratom has been beneficial to myself and other members of my family
for different reasons.  To make this plant illegal to use for people who have benefited from it would be a very bad thing possibly causing a ripple effect and driving people to use drugs, the very legal drugs that actually have cause deaths.  Kratom is a plant not a drug and it actually works better than those drugs, without the side effects.

documents.commentText:
The emergency scheduling of Kratom (a plant) in my opinion is unjust and irresponsible. The community that I live in happens to be the recovery capital of the world. I've also worked in treatment centers for substance abuse for the past 5 years and have not encountered one case of Kratom addiction. 

The plant is in the same family as coffee and typically used to brew tea. It is psychoactive and does activate opiate receptors but it is not an opiate. It's effects are mild and do not impair the users ability to operate heavy machinery or drive. The kava bars that sell this tea provide education to anyone who is trying Kratom for the first time, clearly serving it in a responsible way.

 I was diagnosed with Crohn's disease at a very young age and for many years I've been able to control the symptoms by using this herb. It's safe and honestly it cannot be abused in tea form. I have heard rare cases where people have abused the extract version of this plant but they are far and few between. Reports of incidents where people died or were injured with Kratom in their system are often misreported and always included some other mind altering substance. These events are very low in numbers and are unsubstantial if compared to alcohol related deaths or pharmaceutical related overdose. Both having astronomical numbers. 

In comparison to Kratom there are many substances either over the counter (approved by FDA) or synthetic (unable to be scheduled due to chemical make-up) that are widely available, abused and repeatedly on the news, that nothing is being done about.

In the field of recovery I have met many people (addicts) who have used this supplement to treat chronic pain, exhaustion, anxiety etc. without having to turn back to opiates which had previously destroyed their lives. For them, Kratom has served as a safe alternative that does not pose a threat to their lives and their families lives.

Please consider that many people benefit from this herb and if it is banned there will be very negative consequences that will be imposed on good law abiding citizens who pay their taxes and make positive contributions to society. Their quality of life is in jeopardy and in my case I will be forced to turn back to pharmaceutical narcotics that I one point destroyed my life and left me homeless with nothing. I'm lucky to be alive and Kratom has played a major role in my personal recovery. Please I beg you to help me and people like myself continue to use this herb (dietary supplement) responsibly.

In all sincerity and gratitude,
Josh McBride

When I discovered and tried Kratom, I was amazed. It is not only better at relieving my pain than Vicodin is, but it also stays active in my system longer for greater relief. That I can obtain it without a prescription is a great plus to me since doctors are increasingly skittish about prescribing pain relief medications.

Thank you for your consideration.

documents.commentText: After very serious surgery on my spine following an injury playing ice hockey, I had my first awful experience with pain pills like Vicodin and Percocet. These pills were highly addictive and turned me into a moody, depressive monster who couldn't function without them. In addition to my addiction, my mental health deteriorated to the point that I was so depressed I couldn't get out of bed in the morning (or afternoon...or evening). I did some research online, and came across Kratom like many others with the same issues I faced every day. Since switching to kratom, I've taken myself completely off pharmaceutical pain pills and my depression has almost completely disappeared. I'm able to function as if I never had major back surgery, and I'm even able to play hockey multiple times per week. If I wake up in pain, I take 2-3 grams of kratom mixed with whey protein powder, and I'm good to go in 15 minutes. I'm concerned about the DEA's reckless effort to place kratom in the same category as heroin and cocaine. The comparisons I've seen by some major news networks of kratom to cocaine and heroin is absolute absurdity, and I've never talked with anyone who's ACTUALLY tried the substance compare it to any hard drugs. Claiming that kratom is responsible for over 10 deaths (rarely mentioning the other substances in the victims system) is NOTHING compared to the thousands of victims to pharmaceutical opiates. Even mentioning the poison control numbers as if they're an issue is hilarious as well - how many people call poison control due to caffeine, tylenol, and alcohol every year? The numbers are multitudes higher than the fractional percentage of people who call about ingesting kratom. If the DEA follows through with the scheduling of kratom, thousands of people like me will be forced to hop back on the opiate train to manage pain. IF THE DEA SCHEDULES KRATOM, MORE PEOPLE WILL OVERDOSE ON OPIATES. Please reconsider and listen to the American people - kratom isn't in the same universe as heroin and cocaine.

documents.commentText:
Dear Sir/Madam, 

This comment is to support the claim that Kratom should not be made listed as a schedule I controlled substance. I started taking Kratom almost 2 years ago. I first started taking Kratom for two reasons. (1) My mother and brother were both addicted to prescription opiates due to physician prescriptions for chronic pain and I wanted to help find a way to assist them in getting off prescription meds that were ruining the quality of their life; (2) I was beginning to develop similar problems as my mother and was beginning to be prescribed these horrible medications as a way to deal with those issues at any time. I have slowly watched my mother deteriorate for the last 15 - 20 years. She is only 65 years old, but I have been living with her and my father to help as her caregiver for 10 years now because she appears to have the life of an 85 year old. This has ruined her life as well as my own and ruined the relationship she has with both my brothers and father. The doctor's began decreasing her prescriptions of these medications a couple years ago. documents.commentText:
My name is Phillip Edmonds. In 2009 I had heart surgery to close a hole in my heart, that lead to a stroke, that caused my honorable discharge from the United States Navy. During the surgery the doctor damaged my right phrenic nerve, paralyzing my right diaphragm. For about 10 months after my procedure I was prescribed and used prescription pain killers, to the point where I felt that I was addicted. The doctors called the constant discomfort that I felt as a "slow pain" and because of it, for years I dealt with issues of insomnia, depression, and a general lack of energy. I had no energy to play with my 2 year old daughter when I came home and would get annoyed by her wanting to play with her daddy, all I wanted to do was rest. I was in a really low spot. I talked to my doctor about it regularly and he placed me on many different prescription drugs to try and mitigate the issues that the surgery caused. None of them were a permanent solution. At that time, I started to research natural anti-depressants and natural replacements for opiates, and that is where I found Kratom. I found out that the local tobacco shop sold it, so I went and purchased some. After taking it, I was instantly overcome with a feeling of goodness and general well-being. That night, I went home and ran around the yard with my daughter, for the first time since she had been born. I felt new life! I purchased it for a while from that store and eventually came to know several farmers from Indonesia that sold the botanical in bulk, at much more reasonable prices, so I started buying it from them. Through my day to day life, I couldn't help but tell people about this miracle that had brought me back to life, that allowed me to feel whole again, that repaired the relationships between me and my family. In doing so, I found several other people that were interested in trying Kratom. We ended up forming a co-op. Among the people in the co-op were 3 heroin addicts who had collectively overdosed and died over 10 different times, they had all been to rehabs and all had relapsed, they knew they needed an alternative because the addiction was too strong for them to beat. Kratom provided them with a safe and healthy alternative, and they have all been clean from heroin for over 2 years now. Also in the co-op is two alcoholics. These two people have also struggled with addiction, and depression, and the multiple attempts at treatment through prescription medications had failed them both, alcohol was their only solution, until I introduced them to Kratom. One of them for a year, the other for two years, have been sober, and haven't touched a drop of alcohol, because of Kratom.  Another member of the co-op has a rare degenerative disorder, there are only three known people in the world that has this disorder, and one is his brother. His muscles are literally deteriorating daily, and to combat the degeneration, he has to constantly exercise. He was in a constant state of pain and lived with multiple handicaps. Since introduced to Kratom, he no longer has pain, has had energy to exercise, and has an overall positive outlook on life, when no one in the medical community ever gave him a single shred of hope. I have another member of the co-op that is a wealthy business owner. He used to quell the stresses of his life with alcohol, Xanax, and over eating. Since taking Kratom (for about a year now) he only drinks socially and he has lost over 80 lbs. He has not taken a prescription medication for almost a year and the doctor says that he has never seen this man in such good health. Then there are the few people who really don't have anything "wrong with them" per se, but they, like everyone else, feel the pressure of the daily lives that our nation's boom and bustle lays upon their shoulders. In stead of turning to unhealthy means of occasional stress relief (alcohol, drugs, sex, etc) they use Kratom as an occasional opportunity to decompress...provide some outlet to the pressure that is created by a culture of constant business and general stress. 
I have never known of anyone to have any adverse reactions from Kratom, never known of anyone who wasn't able to stop use on command and at will. Quite the contrary, everyone that I know that has used Kratom, including myself, has actually displayed increases in all aspects of personal and mental health. Our little co-cp is a representative sample of the population as a whole that uses Kratom. We are productive members of society that have been great contributions to society BECAUSE of Kratom, and the opportunities that it has created for us. We are military veterans, fathers, mothers, employees, employers, church members, clergy, doctors, lawyers, farmers, and sales people. We are normal people, and much of that normalcy can be attributed to Kratom. To take away this natural plant is to do a great disservice to many people in our great nation.

documents.commentText:
Kratom should NOT be banned:

If kratom is added to any one of the five drug schedules, people who use it will be criminalized and locked up behind bars.
Kratom has been used safely by millions of people in the U.S. and evidence supports kratom's potential as a pain reliever and opioid replacement.
Banning kratom expands the war on drugs, while the public overwhelmingly supports ending it. Kratom should be legally regulated, allowing for quality control measures and product labeling requirements.
Prohibiting kratom will worsen the country's problems of opioid addiction and overdose.

documents.commentText:
Survey Of ER/Trauma Health Care Professionals Finds No Evidence Of Either Kratom Deaths Or Epidemic Of Abuse

(This article is from the following source: http://www.prnewswire.com/news-releases/survey-of-ertrauma-health-care-professionals-finds-no-evidence-of-either-kratom-deaths-or-epidemic-of-abuse-300369942.html; Accessed on 30NOV16) 

By American Kratom Association, Washington, D.c., www.prnewswire.com lNovember 29th, 2016
AKA is submitting the survey findings as a formal response to the request for kratom-related comments from the DEA, a process that closes at 11:59 p.m. on December 1st.

American Kratom Association Founder Susan Ash said: "We conducted this survey after ER doctors and other medical professionals told us the notion there is some kind of kratom epidemic going on in America is a hoax. In fact, our totally random online survey found no evidence of kratom-related deaths and zero support among America's front-line medical professionals for a ban on kratom. We are not going to stand idly by and let the DEA or anyone else whip up a phony panic about a nonexistent epidemic to try and ban a legal product that's being consumed responsibly, with no major problems, by three-five million Americans."

Key survey findings include the following:

93 percent of those surveyed are aware of kratom.

89 percent of those surveyed have a favorable impression of kratom, including 81 percent with a "very favorable" impression.

87 percent said they would "not classify [kratom] as a problem compared to heroin and prescription painkillers." Another 5 percent said it was a "somewhat smaller" or "much smaller" problem. 0 percent said it was a "somewhat bigger" or "much bigger" problem.

90 percent say kratom is not a "major issue or concern" in their work experience. More than nine out of 10 ER/EMT professionals say they have never dealt with any major case involving kratom.

0 percent said "a ban on the herb kratom is justified based on your professional experience." About 9 percent said they did not have enough experiences with kratom to form an opinion and another 2 percent said they did not know.

0 percent reported deaths due to kratom and only 1 percent related any kind of health-related issues associated with the herb. According to the poll, the vast majority of times (86 percent) that kratom arises in an ER or EMT situation is when someone asks for information about kratom or reports that they consume it.

The random online survey conducted via SurveyMonkey focused on panel of ER/trauma doctors, surgeons, nurses, related health care professionals, and EMTs/paramedics. Invitations to participate in the survey were extended directly through LinkedIn groups (including EMS Leadership and Administration, Emergency Room RNs and Management, Emergency Medicine and EMS World) and Facebook groups (including Paramedics on Facebook, FRCS Trauma & Orthopedic Surgery, First Responders, Trauma, Critical Care, and Acute Care Surgery, and Emergency Medical Technician). The full results and the complete text of the survey instrument are available online at 

http://bit.ly/kratomdocpoll.

http://www.prnewswire.com/news-releases/survey-of-ertrauma-health-care-professionals-finds-no-evidence-of-either-kratom-deaths-or-epidemic-of-abuse-300369942.html

documents.commentText:
I used kratom, via brewed tea, over two years daily for back pain. It was quite effective in this regard. I personally never experienced any serious side effects, aside from occasional constipation, and nystagmus. Both of these subsided quickly, usually soon after the analgesic effects wore off. Upon cessation, I never experienced any withdrawal symptoms, or major cravings. During this time I also had regular blood-work, and urinalysis performed, both of which showed no abnormalities in regard to liver, or kidney function, which has been a concern for some users, and the medical community. 

I have never met a "kratom addict," though they are purported to exist. I lived in a town with a bar that sold kratom, and there were not any people that seemed to become intoxicated by kratom, or expressed any sort of craving, as one would expect from an addicted person, for kratom in my observation of the bar, and town. 

From my experience, and the similar experiences of those around me, some of whom have successfully used kratom to cease heroin abuse with minimal withdrawal, I do not find it fitting to schedule kratom at all. Perhaps an age regulation is in order, simply in the interest of keeping psychoactive (however mild) substances only in the hands of those responsible for their own well-being. In addition to this, taking action against high potency extracts may be the more prudent thing to do, as they seem to be behind a majority of the problems where kratom is involved.

documents.commentText:
Dear Sir,

I have been taking Kratom since May of this year when I was diagnosed as a glaucoma suspect.  I learned about it from online research.  It has done nothing but help me cope with the fear, anxiety and distress that the diagnoses has brought on, and I have been more productive and energetic than ever since taking it.  It has also reduced my urge to consume and abuse alcohol.  I have had my eyes tested twice since then, and both times my eye pressure was 17 mm Hg, within the normal range and down from 27 mm when I was first diagnosed in early May.  Therefore, the Kratom has had no ill effects on the disease itself. 

I am a 59-year old professional software engineer with 35 years experience and a reputable career behind me.  I am not some "kid" on the street seeking a "thrill high".

The argument that Kratom should be banned because it may be tainted with cannabis, synthetic drugs or other substances is a ridiculous argument.  It's like saying someone might taint chocolate with cyanide, therefore we should ban chocolate.  If anything, it's an argument for legalization and regulation so that people know they are getting a product that is tested and verified.

Haven't we had enough of drug lords, street gangs, organized crime and more dangerous street drugs taking the place of banned substances?  This ban will only create more criminals, fill more prisons and replace legitimate vendors with dangerous pushers adding to those already pillaging our communities.  I see no good coming out of this.

I urge you to keep Kratom safe and legal.  Let it's distribution and sale be a legitimate business that employs people and adds to our GDP, not a street activity that adds to our crime rate.  Let responsible adults decide their own risk level and accept the consequences, and not turn them into criminal wardens of the state.

Thank you.

documents.commentText:
Please do not schedule Kratom, a benign dietary supplement that helps many people better themselves despite physical and/or mental setbacks. There has been a good amount of misleading and outright wrong information being spread around different media sources as of late, and it is important to debunk this misinformation so this plant does not get wrongly scheduled. Despite various internet claims, there has actually only been one death recorded of someone ingesting (solely) Kratom ever; the other fourteen were caused by the person using multiple drugs at once,  as proven by Snopes.com, a fact checking website commonly used in education and politics. Compared to the 14,000 overdose deaths from prescription opioids in a single year as reported by the Center for Disease Control, this is nothing. Furthermore, the 660 calls about Kratom to poison control centers in the U.S. over a 5 year period need to be put in perspective as well, seeing as there were over 300,000 calls related to synthetic analgesics in 2014 alone. It should be obvious where the real danger lies. 

To compare Kratom to heroin like some people and media outlets are doing is absolutely asinine; such an outrageous claim can only be attributed to pure ignorance. A similar comparison of coffee and cocaine could be made because they both act on noradrenaline and dopamine, but there is no impending ban on caffeine, as that would be seen as ridiculous. This potential scheduling of Kratom is no different. Kratom is actually a plant in the coffee family, and although it slightly works on the same receptors in the brain as opioids, it is not an opiate and does not produce nearly as strong effects. When I was in high school, I broke my neck in two places and 7 years later, I fell off a 60 foot cliff and shattered nearly every bone in my face.  I have therefore been prescribed a multitude of hard drugs over the past few years including Fentanyl, oxycodone, Vicodin, gabapentin, Valium, cyclobenzaprine, Tramadol, and some SSRI's to deal with chronic pain; Kratom is nothing like those drugs and shouldn't even be named in the same sentence. All of those drugs produced either inadequate relief from my symptoms, side effects that I could not tolerate, or physical dependence that I was uncomfortable with, making coming off of those drugs extremely difficult and unpleasant yet necessary. While there are some physical symptoms upon discontinuation of daily use of Kratom, they are similar to those experienced when coming off of caffeine, and in many cases, much less severe. 

It is surprising that Kratom is being labeled as a drug at all; it's more comparable to a dietary supplement that happens to help a lot of people, not unlike Skullcap or Lemon Balm. It doesn't really kill all pain, but it provides muscular tension relief while giving a slight boost in mood and ability to focus, with much less potential for abuse (because there's no true high) than synthetic drugs. This may not seem like a big deal for healthy people, but for chronic pain patients, it can mean the difference between living a full life or being bed ridden. We use it like caffeine, only unlike caffeine, Kratom doesn't cause anxiety or stiff muscles, so it's a much more viable option for us, and one that we will be severely hindered by not having access to. Please understand that it is not the health threat that it is being made out to be; it is a plant, just like tea or coffee, that helps many people get through their day without wanting to kill themselves or get high. Thank you for reading my comment, and if you have any more questions, feel free to contact any member of the American Kratom Association.

documents.commentText:
Hello,

My name is Lauren Jackson. I am currently writing this message on behalf Kratom. I am a 22 year old female that has suffered with reoccurring shingles since the age of 17. I have had many complications due to my severe shingle attacks, and every complication is excruciatingly painful. I have arthritis, post herpetic neuralgia, migraines, chronic fatigue, and an ultimately shot immune system. I deal with constant pain that most people my age won't have to struggle with for years to come (hopefully).

I have been prescribed many opiates, strong antibiotics, and anxiety/depression medications. I've been hospitalized multiple times. During those hospitalizations, I was diagnosed with various illnesses that just didn't make sense. I was a guinea pig for laboratories, an easily recognizable face at doctors' offices, and a medical mystery when everything came to a close. 

For my own health, I (eventually) weaned myself off of the opiates I was consuming. I discontinued the antidepressants and anxiety drugs because they only increased suicidal thoughts and unwanted side effects. Finally, I found a wonderful, safe, effective herb called Kratom.

I've been drinking Kratom as a tea, once in the morning and once at night, for two years. During those two years, I've been able to skip days whenever my pain is manageable on its own without any withdrawals or side effects. 

Kratom, scientifically classified as Mitragyna Speciosa, is a nonaddictive plant that is in the coffee family. It has zero to minimal side effects. On its own, Kratom has never caused a single death. This plant has been used for years upon years for various medical issues. The DEA's spontaneous decision to place Kratom as a Schedule 1 drug is appalling. Obviously, the DEA is either doing this for big pharmaceuticals to have more money in their pockets, or the DEA isn't knowledgeable of how much Kratom truly helps people. Either way, the DEA is completely overreaching with this ban. Any restrictions on Kratom would be absurd.

After hearing my story, please consider to drop this ban entirely. I don't know what I would do without Kratom, but I know that I can't go back to a life that is riddled with pain. Please, assist me (along with the rest of the natural herbal community) to keep Kratom legal. This ban needs to be defeated. Kratom is commonly used to transition drug users off of heroin, percocets, hydros, suboxone, methadone, and so forth. Taking a non-abusable herb from those who truly need it would only cause addicts to return to a toxic life. If the DEA schedules this amazing plant as a Schedule 1 drug then the death toll WILL rise due to overdoses from unnatural, harmful drugs. The banning of Kratom would have grave repercussions that I don't think the DEA intends, but the DEA also doesn't understand how innocent this herb is.

Thank you for reading.

God bless,

Lauren Jackson

Recently, I purchased a bottle of kratom capsules for a friend of mine.  She has become a recluse because she is in so much pain, she can't move about freely and she endures too much pain to leave her home.  I was curious to see if the kratom would make a difference in her life.

documents.commentText:
RE: Docket No. DEA-442W - my comments

Hello,

I first came across kratom about ten years ago.  I had read online it would help with pain, which my doctor would not prescribe any prescription narcotics for.  I had badly sprained my ankle and could hardly walk even after several weeks.  So I thought I'd give it a try since ibuprofen and advil were not working for me.  After taking a teaspoon of kratom all the pain was completely gone and I was able to get around and continue working, this helped during I time where I had no car and had to walk everywhere to work and to the store for food.  When the sprain finally healed I no longer needed kratom and didn't feel any desire to continue use.  It was unlike past surgeries where I had been prescribed Vicodin.  The Vicodin helped with pain but also left me very nauseous, unable to sleep and can get you high.  I experienced none of that on the kratom I took.  When I ran out of vicodin I couldn't help but feel the desire the keep taking it, but thankfully I only had a small prescription.  It was then that I understood what many people go through when being prescribed strong narcotics for pain.  In my case I didn't need them as the pain was temporary, but I know many people who had to take them for so long they became addicted and after their supply from the doctor ran out they sought other illegal means of obtaining the drug.  

6 months ago I found myself drinking way too much, after a hard breakup with my then girlfriend of 10+ years.  I would quit drinking for several days and suddenly finding myself thinking it was okay to drink just one last time, this cycle repeated for about a year.  So in a effort to stop myself I remembered my first encounter with kratom, and how many said it helped them get off of drugs and alcohol.  So, I thought I'd give it a try.  I began taking kratom  on the weekend when I had time to relax, during those moments when my urge to drink was strongest.  The kratom left me with no desire to drink alcohol whatsoever and I have been clean since that day 6 months ago.  I feel lucky because my uncle died of alcoholism and I was able to stop myself completely.  I still take kratom occasionally, but it mostly just gives me a boost of energy and surprising none of the "highs" that many people claim it is good for.

The one thing that makes me upset about the proposed ban is that we should be stepping away from prohibition as there is no research showing it is at all effective at reducing the drug problem in the US.  It makes criminals out of people who have not committed any violent crimes, where the only victim is themselves.  Instead I think we should not shame these people, and recognize they have a problem and are not criminals.  Kratom, in my opinion, could be a tool used to fight drug addiction, and banning it will not only prevent further research but also turn the many who rely on it as an aid to quit drugs to go back to illegal means of obtaining actual drugs.  I think the best course would to restrict it's sale to people of a certain age, much like alcohol and tobacco is handled.  Considering that alcohol kills 80,000+ people every year, and kratom has killed none directly should be evidence of it's safety as a supplement.  If anything I believe tobacco and alcohol should be on the table for restriction, we knowingly allow their use and know that they kill and ruin peoples lives, yet now somehow the focus is on a plant that most people have never heard of and most use to help them with some ailment. 

Please take my story into consideration, and don't continue this senseless drug war on harmless plants.

documents.commentText:
Dear officials of the DEA,

     It is unfortunate that my knowledge of Kratom has been so limited until recent times. I am not a user of Kratom, but I have heard many positive testimonies of the benefits it has provided so many people who had no where else to turn.
     It is no secret that pharmaceutical drugs administered by physicians is a mixture of preference, financial compensation, and trial and error. With the money monster that this industry has become, it is no wonder the free people are taking it upon themselves to research and experiment with alternative cures for the ailments they suffer from. Admittedly, this could be considered a dangerous practice in the past, but with communal efforts, the internet, and the modern tools and equipment available to professionals, enthusiasts, and activists, it is no wonder that we as a non-government affiliated group can discover alternative solutions to problems we face a civilization.
     The drastic decision to ban the use of Kratom by the small minority of officials in government office is a disgrace on what I know this astounding country to stand for. This is a decision to be made by the public through a vote. Before any conclusion can be made, the citizens need to be exposed to all the information pertaining to Kratom. Old, current, and further research must be done and distributed to the masses, so that we the people can once again determine what is best for us, as opposed to the similar tyrannical rulings thrust onto us in the past. And when I speak of the information that is necessary, I am not referring to smear campaigns and biased commercials similar to those seen during a presidential election, I am referring to hard unaltered data, old and new, explained by the uninfluenced scientists of the world.
    This way I have described above, and only this way, can we come to a conclusion on the issue. I myself am not an expert on the matter, but certainly would like to be further educated before I can cast my vote to decide as a country what is best. Thank you for your time and I hope this comment can influence you to uphold the values of our forefathers.

documents.commentText:
I'm dying. 
I am only 44yrs old and have been ill since I was a teenager due to a genetic disorder. I became much worse in my 20's and by the time I was 30 I was started on opioids to control my pain. I was finally properly diagnosed when I was 34 and fully bedridden to relieve strain on my heart and increase my lifespan . All that can be done is to treat symptoms, there is no cure, so for 8yrs I lay in bed on increasing amounts of medications including high doses of Norco Morphine and Soma. I lived in a fog. I slept my days away. 
I have been married for 22yrs and have 4 amazing children. My husband and kids did not have me in their life like they deserved for those 8yrs and I feel like that was precious wasted time. 
I am medically educated with licenses as an EMT, EMT-I, Paramedic, Operating Room Tech, and Diagnostic Medical Sonographer. I understand how important medications are to us but have learned that we need nature too. 
Just 2yrs ago as I realize quality of life for me is much more important than quantity, I searched the Internet desperate for help that doctors weren't able to provide. I found kratom and after much research decided I had nothing to lose by trying it. 
The very first day using this herb I went half a day without needing (or even wanting) my opioids. I have a new energy similar to really good strong coffee but no jitters. I cannot handle coffee normally as my condition has caused heart failure and I cannot handle harsh stimulants. I was alert!! I was able to spend time out of bed and with my family. I now spend anywhere from 6-10hrs of my day out of bed (which is huge for me) and am able to do some small chores around the house but mainly it's time I have with my family.  I am able to spend this precious time with them now and only wish I had found this herb sooner. 
I am now on the very lowest doses of opioids and only taken on really bad health days despite the fact my health is rapidly deteriorating. I have no negative side affects from kratom and my body is highly sensitive to medications normally. We all deserve to be able to do what is best for our bodies and this is best for me and countless others. Please don't take this away. Utilize this plant to help people! Allow us our promised freedoms to use natural supplements and help people get healthier again. Allow me to spend my end of life with my family. This herb deserves further research and testing, closing that off will only hurt so many people and one day it may be you that is in need of it. We need MORE options to alleviate illness symptoms not less. We need to see these testimonials as a beacon of hope that nature can help some people and be open to that idea. We need to embrace what nature has provided and not make everything about big pharma and money!
Save this herb and help change lives!

documents.commentText:
Good afternoon,

My name is Jennifer Sartin and I am a licensed chemical dependency counselor.  I also have a masters degree in marriage and family therapy.  I am writing in opposition to the DEA  scheduling kratom as a schedule 1 controlled substance.  Most of my experience with kratom has been observed through others, both personally and professionally.  I have seen firsthand the effects of the opioid epidemic in our country.  I have also seen numerous people recover from heroin and prescription drug addiction utilizing kratom as part of their process.  They have reported ease of withdrawal symptoms, decreased depressive episodes, and decreased anxiety.  My fear is that there are countless people who may return to illicit and pharmaceutical drug use if kratom is banned.  I have suffered from depression and insomnia off and on throughout my life and I have personally used kratom and was shocked at the results which included mood lift and ability to fall sleep.  I have read study after study claiming positive and safe benefits of kratom.  I have read that deaths associated with kratom were not a result of kratom alone, but rather in combination with other, more harmful drugs.  In my opinion it would be a disservice to the millions of people who benefit from this natural herb.

Sincerely, 

Jennifer Sartin, MS, LCDC
