documents.commentText:
Dear Sir or Madame,
    First I would like to thank you for holding off on the decision to ban Kratom by placing it on the dangerous substances list, under Docket Number DEA442W.  
   I would like my voice to be heard on the matter of the scheduling of Kratom as a dangerous substance.  I suffer from several problems, not the least of which is severe Arthritis, Fibro Myalgia, Migraines, Pseudo Gout and Chronic Fatigue Syndrome. For approximately 25 to 30 years my doctors were treating my pain with several kinds of Narcotic pain medications. In the beginning low doses helped, but as with any narcotic the need for stronger and stronger doses became the way of life for me.  I was eventually on 240 mg of Morphine a day, as well as 80 mg of percocet.  Both are extremely potent narcotics. Both have nasty side effects including respiratory depression, foggy brain, insomnia, forgetfulness, and extreme addiction.   
     After many years of taking these strong and dangerous drugs, I made the difficult decision to stop taking them. They had stopped helping my pain, and in fact were making it much worse combined with swelling and other side effects. I suffered terrible withdrawal symptoms for about 2 months. This is not a problem I would ever want to face again, but I still have the pain that led to my addiction. 
     About a year ago I was introduced to Kratom as an alternative to narcotic pain meds. It only took one small dose consumed as a tea to tell me that this was my answer.  At first I was afraid because of all the negative comments on this herb. But after reading further, and talking to many consumers of Kratom, I became convinced.  I use a very small amount about 3 to 4 times a day taken as tea to control my severe pain. I no longer suffer from Mental Fog, insomnia, swelling, forgetfulness or any of the other problems I had before. I have never experienced any feeling of euphoria by using this herb.  I never liked the feeling of being High or drunk so I am glad this wonderful leaf does not give me that effect. 
     I am a 61 year old grandmother and great grandmother. I used to work for Law Enforcement and I definitely do not fit the profile of a "recreational user". I have told all my doctors about this wonderful herb and several of them have researched it for themselves. 
     By postponing the scheduling of Kratom, it will be given the chance to be studied and tested to show that it does indeed have great medical usage, and is not just another "street drug".  It does in fact have a great usefulness in helping addicts to get off the dangerous drugs like Heroin and other opiates.   
    Thank you for considering my letter and for listening to the thousands of other Kratom advocates. We all have a story and a voice. 
Respectfully,
Adrian Madden

documents.commentText:
Thank you for this opportunity to comment on Kratom. My name is Brad Allred, I am a 34 year old male, married with four wonderful children, I am a hard working American and have been so since I got out of high school. I have had social anxiety and ADHD my entire life and never went to college due to these issues. I have struggled with alcoholism and addiction for years. I used to drink heavily every night when I got home from work, I just figured that was how it was supposed to be since all of my friends did the same. I noticed I would get pretty angry and annoyed easily when I drank and my family was urging me to not drink when I got home. I tried Kratom instead of drinking and I noticed that it made ALL of the cravings for alcohol go away to the point that I had zero desire to drink, after a while of struggling to quit drinking (it wasn't like it just happened overnight) and using Kratom to help stop cravings I was able to quit drinking completely about 3 years ago! I honestly believe that I couldn't have done it without Kratom's help and I really hope you don't take this wonderful herb away from us!  Unlike a lot of us I was never addicted to opiates, however some of my friends have gotten addicted and have used Kratom to reduce withdrawal symptoms, which they say works amazingly well. 

I have now worked my way up to a college level job (Software Developer) and use Kratom to help with my anxiety and some recent back pain issues. I can honestly say that Kratom does not give me a "buzz", it just helps me feel like myself. Back when I first started taking it there was a definite "buzz" to it, but wasn't really what I would call a "high" just warm, comfortable feeling.

I've been using Kratom for about 4 years now and if Kratom was really harmful I would be one to know, I have a tendency to test my limits and have gone as high as 2 ounces of Kratom a day (that's a massive amount) with minimal side affects. I don't believe that you can really "overdose" on this substance as it will make you very dizzy and nauseous to the point of vomiting up everything you have ingested. It definetly works best at lower doses anyway.

Some of the side affects I have experienced at higher doses are: dizziness, vomiting, constipation and grogginess. At lower doses these side affects are either non-existent or mild and easy to deal with. I have experienced a lack of sexual drive and some prostate problems which may or may not be related. 

Personally I believe it should be somewhat regulated so that it can meet certain purity standards and should be restricted to ages 21 and up. But please don't schedule it, there are so many people that could benefit from this natural herb and it would be a shame to prevent them from having access when they need it.

Thank you for you time!

documents.commentText:
I am writing in regards to the DEA consideration of making Kratom a Schedule 1 Controlled Substance.  I am a 54 year old female who uses Kratom and supports keeping this plant legal and safe.  Although I appreciate the important effort our government makes in keeping dangerous, mind-altering substances out of the hands of our people and off our streets, it has been my personal experience that Kratom does not fall into this category.

I started using Kratom after reading many testimonies of it helping others with one of my professionally diagnosed, painful medical conditions.  The only drug which I knew to consistently alleviate my symptoms was oxycodone, which I had been prescribed several times while recovering from my many breast cancer surgeries.  For obvious reasons, even If I had been able to get a doctor to prescribe opiates for me for the rest of my life, this would not have been a healthy option.  The logical course of action for me then was to search for a natural herb with no side effects that would mimic oxycodone in that it would alleviate symptoms but without possessing any mind-altering, ethereal-like, or addictive qualities.   

The Kratom worked exactly like others said it would and I was thrilled with the results.  I don't experience any side effects at all, no weird high or ethereal feelings; it simply takes away my pain and I have been able to actually sleep through the night for the past year or so.  What a blessing!  

I imagine that if I paid enough money and spent enough time, I could find a doctor who would prescribe opiates for my condition; Ive heard they are out there anyway.  But in my mind, that would be a lot riskier to my health and the danger of addiction is very high.  I would choose the lesser, milder, Kratom over prescription opiates any day!  

Thank you for your time.

documents.commentText:
The DEA should stop any and all consideration of banning the herbal supplement kratom. There should be no prohibition. While the FDA is looking into it as well, most Americans have never heard of it. Why? Because there's NO REAL PROBLEM with it! Quite the contrary...

Kratom seems like a solution to a number of issues, including various forms of drug addiction and chronic pain. Plus, it can perform the pain-killing work of morphine without dangerously depressing breathing -- the way opioids do.

Here's how Kratom works...
It uses a pathway that mediates many of the undesirable effects of traditional opioids such as constipation, respiratory depression. In fact, this knowledge is spurring additional research by pharmaceutical companies.
http://bit.ly/2c8UTI6

About Kratom, a leading researcher notes...
Thailand is considering legalizing kratom as a safer alternative for meth addicts. U.S. researchers are trying to study its potential to help opiate abusers kick the habit without withdrawal side effects.
http://bit.ly/2c8SI7v

There are anecdotal reports of addiction risk. But it appears the addiction can be broken without withdrawal symptoms. Meanwhile, the painkillers currently being used are more addictive, dangerous, and harder to kick. Yet...

The FDA and DEA both appear ready to ban kratom and effectively kill research to further develop this substance. Is the DEA is running cover for a Big Pharma company that wants to monopolize kratom?

As I consider these actions by the FDA and DEA I'm forced to wonder -- WHAT ARE YOU PEOPLE SMOKING?

documents.commentText:
Hello- I survived a very bad motorcycle accident in 1974. I am 64 yrs. old and suffer chronic pain. Dr.'s have prescribed me hydrocodone and oxycodone off and on since then. At my age, I refuse to have any more surgeries. The pharmaceutical pain relievers have had their own issues, AND the government has made it hard for them to be prescribed anymore- because of unscrupulous Dr.'s AND an unscrupulous government. That's simply REALITY. I have used kratom off and on for the last 3 yrs., have had NO side effects, nor addictive tendencies. I would NOT put anything into my body if it weren't safe, and I certainly don't need the DEA, nor FDA, telling me what's safe, and what isn't.
I only take kratom in the colder months, for obvious reasons- cold weather wreaks havoc on damaged bones and joints. I have found that there are NO sensitivity, nor addictive, issues with kratom, AND I don't have to take the recommended amount for my body weight. 2.5 grams of the powder in my first cup of coffee in the morning gets the job done.
My question is, why does the government always keep trying to control our lives like this? They assume that ALL people are the same, which we are NOT!...For crying out loud!...read your Bible! We are all different, so quit trying to shoe horn us into boxes and categories. For the record, I do not use marijuana, nor do I advocate it's use, even for medical purposes. Sure, I used it in the early 70's, as did the majority of kids then. I can truly say, for me, that there are no medicinal values to marijuana, but kratom is another matter. Now, here's the best part- I have health insurance and prescription drug coverage. Kratom costs more, and is out of pocket. Do the math!

documents.commentText:
My name is Brian, I am 38 a responsible father, son, and husband. I am a highly skilled technician in the industrial field. I have never been addicted to any Drug nor have I ever used illegal recreational drugs, I also do not drink.

I do not believe the actions taken here have been a responsible response to what was called a threat to society. kratom has been lumped into the recreational drug arena in which it does not belong. Kratom has not become a wide spread recreational drug because it does not produce the psychoactive effects recreational drug users are looking for. It does however provide chronic pain sufferers as well as several other illness/injury sufferers relief from the pain in what ever form they suffer.

I was in an accident in which I received an injury to my spinal cord causing permanent damage to the pain nerve extending down my right arm and into my fingers. The pain is constant and unbearable. I am unable to sleep ant night and unable to function during the day. I have decided to not use opiate based pain medication due to the addictive properties of those drugs I have used Lyrica with no beneficial results, and Gabapentin gave me horrible side effects.So I have chosen to take a holistic approach and kratom is what I have found to help reduce the pain to a more manageable level. I have never felt or had any negative affects from kratom. I have also stopped using kratom and during that time period I never experienced any negative affects. I believe this to plant to be a useful tool in holistic approach to illness and injury.

I am asking you to please reconsider the decision to place kratom on a schedule 1 ban. By doing so I will not be able to use kratom relive my chronic pain and will have to resort to an opiate based pain reliever. As I have stated before Lyrica and Gabapentin did not work or worse caused symptoms worse then the pain. I understand the difficulties and your position with the drug abuse is currently occurring in the United States but I also expect my government to make research-based decisions. 

Thank you very much for your time, I would also like to thank you for reconsidering the ban and giving the rest of us enough time find an alternative for our chronic pain issues. I did not wish to use opiates but you may leave me no choice.

documents.commentText:
Dear Drug Enforcement Agency,
I would like to begin by sharing my personal story. Ever since I was at an elementary school level of age, eight years old to be precise, I have suffered from a debilitating case of mental illness, which has the prognosis of manic depression and anxiety most noticeably. The treatment- resistant depression I have been prescribed under doctoral supervision has abject side effects that are more unbearable than the congenital and unmedicated mental illness that I had to begin with. This reality has been wholly devastating and has had a negative impact upon my social interactions, ability to work, focus in school, amongst other various constituents that have impeded upon the best of my intentions. I was introduced to Kratom by a dear friend of mine who has used this herbal supplement as a natural remedy for his chronic maladies. The moment I first partook in Kratom as a result of recommendation, the emanating affects began to significantly mitigate every such symptom that I described above. Non- users have often inquired of me as to whether I utilize this supplement for recreational purposes or for adaptogenic purposes. I respond by explicitly stating that the sole reason for my partaking of Kratom is not for recreational purposes, but consequently because from a phenomonological perspective, I myself have seen the edifying benefits of this chemically stabilizing remedy. Kratom has provided reduced symptoms of anxiety, depression, stress, sleep apnea, suicidal thoughts, and a wide variety of other chronic mental ailments. Kratom has most importantly generated within me a greater sense of self- satisfaction due to how it has maximized my relational, social, and academic capabilities, that would otherwise have been tarnished by the nature of my mental illness, despite the best of my best intentions. The ubiquitous outcry from a vast number of other American citizens who have experienced the similar beneficial effects and the mental anguish liberation given by Kratom makes this national outcry not in the least bit surprising. To neglect the empirical evidence revealing how beneficial this plant has been upon the lives of millions, is to disregard not only the plea of the people, who unanimously desire to upend this Schedule 1 classification, but such a ruling would also violate basic human altruism and a sufficient consideration for the well- being of others. Users of this natural medication are by-and-large productive tax- paying and law abiding members of society. It is unconscionable to think that these members of society would become vilified and incarcerated for the non- violent crime of desiring to medicate themselves from the chronic ailments they never chose in the first place. Please take into consideration my contention for keeping Kratom legal, and please hear the petitions of the multitude of others who have had profoundly similar positive experiences with Kratom. A compromise is only necessary.
Sincerely,
Scott Lambert

documents.commentText:
Hello,
My name is Bryan Kirwen and I'm the president if the University of Cincinnati's Students for Sensible Drug Policy chapter. If there's one thing I've learned about drug policy while in college it's that prohibition does not work. It encourages illicit markets, gang violence, and makes drugs in fact EASIER for minors to obtain. The  Iron Law of Prohibition states that once a substance is made illegal, illicit marketa are encouraged to make a more potent and potentially more dangerous product. By prohibiting drugs, we have only created a public health and criminal justice crisis in our country. Prohibition has also demonized minorities, and has created generations of poverty due to the harsh mandatory minimum sentencing on nonviolent drug possession that makes it difficult or even impossible to find public housing and apply for federal aid to attend college, among many other things. Scheduling kratom would only make everything that's happened thus far worse. Since our government hasn't stepped up to properly address the heroin epidemic, citizens are taking it upon themselves to try to get off heroin with the aid of kratom. I very strongly recommend that kratom remain legal, and I further recommend that we establish a legal means for heroin addicts to obtain kratom, such as through a doctor's prescription. The DEA must make the right decision to keep kratom legal. This is a matter of public health, not law enforcement. For once, DEA, do the right thing.

documents.commentText:
Please dont make Kratom Illegal. I am a long term opiate user who have recently received a Pain Pump. The pain pump has not been working initially. I am still on a small amount of opioids orally. I know that I am going to have to stop taking opioids. I am having trouble, turning away from opioids, because of the addictive properties. I had run out of Percoset, and I knew that withdrawal was about to follow. 

I rushed out and got some Kratom. I cant believe that this plant has made my withdrawal minimized. Having suffered withdrawal several times, I can say the pain drives me back to get more pills. Well now I know that is not a pattern I have to continue.The Kratom is a simple leaf, whose properties have allowed me to sleep at night, use the restroom, and kept me content, while not being high. The effects of kratom, to an opioid user, are not seen as a drug. Its like a tea, that keeps me from feeling out of my head, as I struggle to get off the Percoset pills. 

If you take Kratom away, there is nothing available to help the masses get off opioids. That is the simple truth. This is a short comment, but its the most important thing. Any Doctor should point to Kratom, when their patient is complaining, that they "need" more pain medicine. 

Also, I am noticing it is not practical to stay on Kratom long. Its a plant. Its messy. My trajectory is I will only use this plant because I have to. Once I am done with the effects of addiction, I can safely stop taking Kratom. Its not a substance, that even lends itself to addiction, like the Percoset I have been on for 5 years.  

 So I have now been Percoset free for 5 days. This is the longest I have been off Percoset in years. Because of Kratom, I am not staying up all night, sweating, with a fever, and then being to exhausted to go to work. I can have some Kratom, go to work, and maintain my responsibilities at work, while simultaneously getting off opioids, instead of having to make another appointment to go to the doctor to get more. Because, otherwise, I cant go to work in withdrawal, I have to get more opioids, so i look normal at work. Its a horrible way to live.

I am proud to have been given the opportunity to speak out about this and please dont make this very good herbal remedy Illegal. Where else would I turn for help?

documents.commentText:
You Must Ban Kratom!
We have our son in the 3rd stay in professional rehab.  This drug is so sneaky, it is worst than heroin once it grabs you, that is its danger. Slowly your body requires more and more Kratom to reach the same euphoric effect. Soon, like our son, it consumes your life, requiring close to $100/day to scratch the itch. It is then you realize it's "got you". In the same time frame, you loose weight and health, loose motivation, loose your friends and social life, develop paranoia, and have a hard time holding a job let alone keep a simple conversation.  When you try to stop, the 10-14 days of withdrawal is incredibly painful to go through and to watch as a parent. And as mentioned earlier, it his 3rd attempt to stop using. He wants to stop but he cant. Just after 30 days of sobriety, the Kratom urges remain so strong, it keep calling him back. 60 days just as strong; Today its 90 days post treatment and he says there is no relief from the urges to do more Kratom. This Drug needs to be properly understood before more lives are ruined. This is the only drug he used!   

For those who feel it helps with other addictions?, Please! Our country has spent BILLIONs on treating drug addictions and has made incredible progress and success. This success is by the professional and science base information of trial and error; That is how this country protects its citizens responsibly.  So to think some "magic plant", with out any professional oversight, has this kind of power for success is ridiculous and would be dangerous to give Kratom such validation. If its too good to be true, it probably is.  

If Kratom has an indication to be a great rehab medication, then sent it through the proper channels to prove its safety to our public, that is our Governments #1 responsibility to its citizens.  And if it has a valid scientific proof of purpose, THEN have it administered and prescribed by the proper medical professionals, and not prescribed by the opiate and heroin addicts on the internet. The current unregulated usage of Kratom for other serious addictions, without professional oversight,  is DANGEROUS. 

Kratom may not have a high fatality rate, but, you dont have to loose a life to ruin a life!
Kratom has been an expensive problem while our son was using, consuming his entire paycheck.
Kratom has been an expensive problem when our son wanted to quit, $38,000 each attempt in rehab (x3 times), plus lost time, lost jobs and follow up counselling. 
Kratom has created disturbing paranoia, destroyed our sons personality and social life, and created a person that is more of burden on society than a contribution.
Kratom has taken away a parents most precious hopes and dreams; For their kid to have a happy and productive life.
Dont tell us Kratom is harmless. Dont tell me it helps. Not one once of goodness so far. 

I know the DEA has been bombarded by Pro-Kratom users due to their well organize effort.  Dont let these high numbers of opposition be a persuasion.  So please, be responsible to your citizens and protect all of us. Ban Kratom until its further understood.  

Thank You
Paul and Kathy
Darien, IL

documents.commentText:
Director Rosenberg:
Re: The Herbal Dietary Supplement Kratom

I am a 63 year old professional (attorney) and live in Hollywood, Florida . I do not drink alcohol or take drugs. I submit this formal comment in strong opposition to the DEA taking any measures to schedule the herbal dietary supplement Kratom in any schedule. 
I have been drinking Kratom tea once or twice a week for ten years. The numerous alkaloids in Kratom have a strong antioxidant effect. I routinely use Kratom and other supplements to support my immune system during allergen exposure and migraine headaches and I can verify that Kratom supports mental focus, supports routine and everyday aches and pains, and promotes my general health, comfort and well-being. 
 Kratom is not a drug and is certainly not a recreational drug. I have never had any effects from Kratom that could even remotely be described as getting high. Drinking Kratom tea has the same effect as any caffeinated tea or a cup of coffee. Kratom is not addicting. 
As a law abiding and responsible adult, I urge you in the strongest terms to take no action to schedule this supplement.  
Thank you very much for your time and consideration. 

Jerry Breslin
Hollywood, Florida

documents.commentText:
As a sufferer of chronic pain, due to Crohns and Arthritic Colitis, I have been prescribed enough opiates to know their harmful side affects. Having to choose between pain and pneumonia is far to common, and disgusts me that doctors were all too ready to place me in this position as a child. When I discovered Kratom, my life changed. I could begin to do normal every day task without the fear of crippling pain or incontinence. Not only does Kratom help with pain, it helps with many of the symptoms of Crohns. In fact, I was told about it from another Crohns patient, and I have been telling as many IBD sufferers as possible. Everyone that has used it, has told me that it changed their life, they same way it changed mine. What may seem insignificant to you, is like reaching the top of the most dangerous mountain and being able to breathe again to me, and to all the others who find relief in this natural leaf. 

There are no additives, no synthetic substances, it's not cooked or heated, it's just a leaf in the same family as the coffee bean. What reason is there to make a leaf that helps so many illegal? More prescription drugs kill people than this natural alternative, and if each those incidences were looked into, I believe you would find kratom was not the only culprit in their death. Please, don't make the safest alternative I have illegal. Don't make me have to choose between pneumonia or pain ever again in my life.

documents.commentText: I was reluctant to comment at first do to stigma an fear, but here goes nothing. I became addicted to opiates after getting my wisdom teeth pulled an getting a bottle of Vicodin. Three months after that I got bronchitis an got a big bottle of liquid vicoden called tussionex. Needless to say ever since then I've had major health issues including TMD (Temporomandibular joint dysfunction), Rhinorrhea, Eustachian Tube Dysfunction, an Leaky Gut Syndrome all of which would go away if i took another vicodin. I went cold turkey about two and a half years ago an had no intention on going back with a downside that none of my health issues were seeming to heal on their own. I've went to multiple doctors over that span of time only to find out there isn't any thing they could find that is wrong with me. One doctor recommended Lexapro thinking it was anxiety an a lack of serotonin causing my issues but it did not end up working. I was then recommended the option to try xanax or clonazepam which I respectfully declined. I finally gave up expensive doctor visits an began researching natural remedies such as fiber based diet, proper daily vitamins, an eating healthier overall. I then found kratom about one year ago an my life drastically changed for the better. I was able to quit smoking cigarettes and haven't smoked one in six months with no intention on doing so. It literally mitigated all of my issues I was having by at least fifty percent. In that amount of time I got a new career an am doing great for myself while taking kratom three to four times a day. I have a clean background an have no traffic violations let alone ever been in a accident. I honestly an genuinely believe from the bottom of my heart that it is absurd to even think about banning such a beneficial plant. I don't deserve to live in pain an I love myself enough to know that. Ibuprofen is more toxic an dangerous than this stuff. The DEA should consider banning tobacco before banning this plant. Anyways, thanks for taking the time to read this.

documents.commentText:
Kratom was introduced to me by a good friend of mine who has suffered from chronic pain for 15+ years. She has neuropathy in her left leg. The pain is so debilitating most days that she can hardly leave her bed in the morning, let alone walk down the stairs or go to work. She has tried dozens of other medication options and none of them worked to quell her pain and allow her to live a functional lifestyle. She was feeling very hopeless about her medical condition until she discovered Kratom. Since she began taking Kratom her pain has become extremely manageable and she has no problem going through her day joyfully. 

I myself struggle with back pain and Kratom is an excellent remedy for me on days where the painful sensations are so distracting and exhausting that I have trouble completing the tasks that are required of me. 

Personally, I feel that any legal or illegal substance that is psychoactive - caffeine, alcohol, over the counter medications, etc... - can become harmful when an individual does not know how to moderate him/herself. However, this does not mean that banning a substance is an effective method for insuring that people don't use it or use it responsibly. 

I have plenty of experience taking Kratom with moderation and I have witnessed no side effects. 

Overall I believe that Kratom is a safe substance that can improve peoples wellbeing and tackle debilitating medical issues and therefore it should not be scheduled by the DEA.

documents.commentText:
The DEA should stop any and all consideration of banning the herbal supplement
kratom. There should be no prohibition. While the FDA is looking into it as well, most Americans have never heard of it. Why? Because there's NO REAL PROBLEM with it! Quite the contrary...

Kratom seems like a solution to a number of issues, including various forms of drug addiction and chronic pain. Plus, it can perform the pain-killing work of morphine without dangerously depressing breathing -- the way opioids do.

Here's how Kratom works...
It uses a pathway that mediates many of the undesirable effects of traditional opioids such as constipation, respiratory depression. In fact, this knowledge is spurring additional research by pharmaceutical companies.
http://bit.ly/2c8UTI6

About Kratom, a leading researcher notes...
Thailand is considering legalizing kratom as a safer alternative for meth addicts. U.S. researchers are trying to study its potential to help opiate abusers kick the habit without withdrawal side effects.
http://bit.ly/2c8SI7v

There are anecdotal reports of addiction risk. But it appears the addiction can be broken without withdrawal symptoms. Meanwhile, the painkillers currently being used are more addictive, dangerous, and harder to kick. Yet...

The FDA and DEA both appear ready to ban kratom and effectively kill research to further develop this substance. Is the DEA is running cover for a Big Pharma company that wants to monopolize kratom?

As I consider these actions by the FDA and DEA I'm forced to wonder -- WHAT ARE YOU PEOPLE SMOKING?

documents.commentText:
Dear DEA,

I would like to share my experiences with the herb Kratom with you. It was first introduced to me as a recreational substance. I was looking for an alternative social lubricant to alcohol so I bought an ounce of high quality Kratom, about 10 doses. I had that ounce for more than two years. In my opinion, as a recreational substance, kratom has little value. Eating 2-5 grams of powdered leaf is no easy task and the reward is minimal compared to most other drugs. Even though I had it in my possession for two years, after initially trying it out a few times, I did not use it to get high.

In June of this year I was involved in an accident that left me hospitalized with a broken ankle, femur, and spine. By the time I recovered enough to walk I had developed a dependency to the pharmaceutical opiates I was prescribed. Quitting an opiate habit is not easy. When the doctors cut me off I could not sleep without the pills. I felt shaky, sick, both physically and mentally drained. I don't think I experienced even 1/10th of the withdrawals a more serious opiate addict would go through, but it was too much for me. I found some people who had some pills. Without the script anymore I had to make them last, so I shot them up using an insulin syringe. When I couldn't find pills I found some people with black tar heroin that I smoked. This went on for awhile, stopping then going back, then stopping, and going back again.

If you think my story is an anomaly,  it is not. The 2012 National Survey on Drug Use and Health, conducted and published by the Substance Abuse and Mental Health Services Administration, estimated that there were 2.1 million Americans abusing prescription opiates and 467,000 heroin addicts, nearly double the number of heroin addicts estimated by the survey in 2005. According to the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention in 2010 alone there were 13,652 accidental deaths from prescription opiates, and 2,789 fatal heroin overdoses. In this context, the fact that the DEA sites "15 kratom-related deaths between 2014 and 2016," as reason for making the plant schedule 1, seems absurd. And becomes even more absurd when it is realized that all of those deaths involved other drugs. There has never been a single documented case of fatal overdose from kratom alone. I will repeat that, Kratom alone has never killed anyone. Compare that to the 16,441 deaths from pharmaceutical  opiates and heroin in just one year, and explain to me how it is that you think kratom is the problem.

Kratom helped me quit opiates. Kratom made the withdrawals more manageable. I might have been able to quit without Kratom, but I don't think I would have stayed off it. I still have considerable pain from my back injury. Not all the time, but some days it can be debilitating. I  would have likely turned turned to opiates, but instead I use Kratom a few times a week to manage this chronic pain. Kratom is as excellent a pain reliever as there is. It is far less narcotic/intoxicating than opiates, even low dose opiates. I can eat a couple grams of kratom and go about my day feeling sober, healthy, and without pain. On top of these benefits, it is nowhere near as addictive as opiates. I can take kratom many days in a row and then stop with no ill effects. Conversely, if I had 3 Oxycodone I would probably just eat the first, but then snort the second... and by the time I was looking at my third and final pill I would be sorely tempted to inject it. I have never felt like a fiend for Kratom.

Without Kratom I would have almost certainly have gone back to using opiates by now. Please do not take away this vital medicine from me, the thousands of other people who it has helped, and millions it could help in the future. Kratom needs to be promoted not prohibited.  The only logical reason you could possibly have for making Kratom schedule 1 is to prevent it from competing against the pharmaceutical opiates. This is absolutely shameful. Kratom has great medicinal benefits, and a low potential for abuse. Just like a number of other drugs you have listed as schedule 1. Why are you prohibiting research into these potentially useful substances? Why prohibit medical research into Any substance?

Do away entirely with the classification of schedule 1 drugs. Represent the American people, not the pharmaceutical drug lobby.

Sincerely,
Matthew M. Culbertson
Breckenridge, Colorado

documents.commentText:
My name is Gary Sloan. I am currently a full-time musical performer in Denver, CO. I completed my Master's of Music at CU Boulder in May 2015. I primarily play jazz and swing/vintage jazz on the upright bass for my living but also play blues, rock, musicals, corporate/wedding cover band gigs, bluegrass, children's concerts etc. and also perform on trombone, electric bass, and occasionally guitar. I also teach private lessons independently, including bass, guitar, ukulele, mandolin, and more.

I started experiencing symptoms of depression sometime during high school and my first treatments (talk therapy) began during my junior or senior year of high school, roughly 2005. By the time I was a freshman in college the symptoms exacerbated to the point of severely affecting my ability to function and I experienced my first major depressive episode at that time. I first went on an anti-depressant during my first semester of college. Over the next 3-4 years, I was prescribed at several antidepressant/antianxyiolitic drugs at one time or another: Lexapro, Wellbutrin, Citalopram, Effexor, Xanax, and more. I also engaged in on/off talk therapy with little success. The pattern with the drugs was particularly frustrating. Many did not work, some had such horrible side effects that I could not tolerate them, and- at best, in the case of Citalopram which I took last and for the longest amount of time- it worked but was accompanied by tolerable side effects. As time went on, however, the efficacy fell so the dose increased, which improved the positive effects but worsened the side effects.

During my last year of undergrad, my friend/roommate recommended I try kratom. He had an interest in all kinds of substances, some good and others not-so-good, but had been a regular kratom user for some time at that point and actually convinced a local business to carry kratom (kratom quickly accounted for 50% of their profit and they subsequently hired my friend). In short- and I could go on- I found that, compared to the antidepressants that I had taken, was extremely effective in combating the symptoms of depression that make everyday tasks and productivity difficult with very few side effects when used appropriately. I was really struggling to reach even the minimum amount of daily functioning at that time and felt hopeless that I would be able to complete my coursework to graduate on time. Kratom relieved the most severe symptoms of my depression, provided energy, helped with severe depression-related anxiety, and basically allowed me to function well enough to graduate college. I'm not sure I would've passed my courses without it.

Obviously I am not a medical professional, nor do I pretend that kratom will work for everyone, but I have seen enough friends find relief through kratom that they did not get from pharmaceutical drugs that I'm convinced it has huge medical potential. At the very least, the anecdotal  success given by tens of thousands of kratom users not only warrants but demands serious scientific studies. Fayetteville, AR became a bit of a kratom bubble due to the success of the business that carried kratom per suggestion of my roommate/friend, and I watched dozens of people find success with in for self-treatment of persisting long-term issues first-hand. General anxiety, acute panic attacks, long-term pain management, depression, a safer alternative to opiate withdrawal than the methadone clinics, and more as well as for less serious uses including energy, motivation, relaxation, and overall well-being. Many of these people, including my own mother who has sever anxiety and a number of chronic health issues, use it to this day. And, yes, I know many people who use it either for pure recreational purposes or (as is the case with myself) for both recreational and well-being purposes. For that demographic, the side effects are slim to none when dosed responsibly. When it is abused, the user vomits before any acute bodily risk occurs. In my experience and observations, it is closer in risk of abuse of coffee or marijuana than it is to the life-threatening risks of abusing alcohol, opiates, or a number of drugs. I hope that there will be research into the long-term effects; I have used it daily for over half a decade and have no apparent negative long-term effects.

After graduation, I developed a bad alcohol habit that was supported by an enabling girlfriend. I made the decision to quit drinking (and to breakup with the girlfriend) and kratom made it a very easy process. In fact, I decided to get very serious about my music and kratom helped in 4-hour marathon practice sessions that I did 6 days a week for nearly a year and a half before I got accepted to a Master's program in Colorado.

I do not believe there is substantial evidence that kratom poses a health risk to our society and I believe it has extreme medicinal potential. I hope the DEA does the right thing and chooses to open kratom up to serious research.

documents.commentText:
The DEA should stop any and all consideration of banning the herbal supplement kratom. There should be no prohibition. While the FDA is looking into it as well, most Americans have never heard of it. Why? Because there's NO REAL PROBLEM with it! Quite the contrary...

Kratom seems like a solution to a number of issues, including various forms of drug addiction and chronic pain. Plus, it can perform the pain-killing work of morphine without dangerously depressing breathing -- the way opioids do.

Here's how Kratom works... It uses a pathway that mediates many of the undesirable effects of traditional opioids such as constipation, respiratory depression. In fact, this knowledge is spurring additional research by pharmaceutical companies. http://bit.ly/2c8UTI6

About Kratom, a leading researcher notes... Thailand is considering legalizing kratom as a safer alternative for meth addicts. U.S. researchers are trying to study its potential to help opiate abusers kick the habit without withdrawal side effects. http://bit.ly/2c8SI7v

There are anecdotal reports of addiction risk. But it appears the addiction can be broken without withdrawal symptoms. Meanwhile, the painkillers currently being used are more addictive, dangerous, and harder to kick. Yet...

The FDA and DEA both appear ready to ban kratom and effectively kill research to further develop this substance. Is the DEA is running cover for a Big Pharma company that wants to monopolize kratom?

As I consider these actions by the FDA and DEA I'm forced to wonder -- WHAT ARE YOU PEOPLE SMOKING?

documents.commentText:
Name: Robert Bennett
Age: 55
Occupation: Mechanical Engineer
State of Residence: Florida

I am opposed to the DEA  putting Kratom on The List Schedule I Controlled Substances. I find this plant to be harmless, non-addictive , inexpensive and readily available.

I began using in November of 2015 on the advice of a person that I trusted that had experience with plant. 

Kratom helps me in two specific areas and they are interrelated. Motivation and pain mitigation / relief. Being 55 and working full time, sometimes I have a hard time getting motivated to put in a good workout. I find that kratom helps motivate me and also is an analgesic to help me cope with the aches and pains I get from working out.

I just have a hard time believing that there is anything in this substance that could or should be illegal. I have never " gotten high " on it. I have just found it to have a "mood brightening " effect on me. Plus it is inexpensive, readily available and 100% natural. It's just a dried leave ground it to powder. Really no processing or refinement. What more could you ask for? Pharmaceuticals are really just chemicals, completely unnatural. Plus pharmaceuticals all have side  effects. I have never experienced any side effects from kratom.

In closing, I would just like to say that denying the American public free access to this plant would be a poor decision in my opinion. 
 
Sincerely,

Robert Bennett

documents.commentText:
While the science may not be in on the exact effects of Kratom, the right of people to make the choice and assume the associated risks of Kratom use should not be restricted without abundant proof that it is causing some serious social harm. In short regardless of its potential health issues free adults in a free country should no have their choice to do with their own bodies what they will infringed unless it can be proven that to do so would result in significant benefit to society as a whole. The "we don't know enough about it" argument for restriction is in my opinion Un-American as it supposes the role of FDA and DEA or even government in general is to know best regardless of the way people chose to live. It should not be the role of government to prevent individual choices to mitigate risk. The role of government should be to inform of potential risk, and only restrict the freedom of choice of its people if the case is one of undeniable and significant risk to the whole of society. Its pretty obvious Kratom does no pose this sort of risk.

Please don't assume the right to protect people from themselves and in doing so, assume governance over the fundamental right of people to do what they will with their own bodies. Free adults in a free country should not need the permission or approval of their government to live the way they please as long as they are not infringing the rights of other to do the same.

Thank you for your consideration.

V/r

documents.commentText:
Dear DEA,
I find your intention to schedule Kratom as an illegal drug without medicinal value to be in sharp contradiction to the heroin/opiate epidemic that has been only gaining momentum and taking the lives of countless US citizens.  For those who suffer from chronic pain and/or addiction the use of opiates is often a necessity to physically function enough to participate in community and work a job.  To vote, to take care of children, to work and pay taxes.  Their tax dollars supply your budget.  The ones whose injuries and insurance might be prescribed their drugs, under intense scrutiny, and are considered law abiding citizens.  The overwhelming majority have few alternatives.  Street heroin, methadone clinics, or Kratom.  Your entire organization's efforts against the trafficking and distribution of heroin should be a top priority yet on a street level heroin is cheaper and more pure than ever.  Overdoses are killing far more Americans than ISIS or the Taliban.  The middle east exports black gold, opium and oil.  Methadone and Suboxone are legal alternatives, yet as expensive without insurance and exponentially more difficult to withdrawal from.  The ONLY other alternative is a natural, safe, and affordable substance that provides relief from withdrawal symptoms, pain, and psychosomatic stress.  It doesn't induce a euphoric high to chase, depress the CNS dangerously, withdrawal symptoms are short and mild.  Kratom is America's ally.

documents.commentText:
What Kratom is not
Kratom is not a drug. Kratom is not an opiate. Kratom is not a synthetic substance. Naturally occurring Kratom is a safe herbal supplement thats more akin to tea and coffee than any other substances.
Kratom behaves as a partial mu-opioid receptor agonist and is used for pain management, energy, even depression and anxiety that are so common among Americans. Kratom contains no opiates, but it does bind to the same receptor sites in the brain. Chocolate, coffee, exercise and even human breast milk hit these receptor sites in a similar fashion.

documents.commentText:
Banning this life-saving drug would be a terrible mistake.  I have a family member who has come to rely on this harmless medicine.  As a nurse with many years of emergency background, I am unable to ascertain a logical reason that the government sees a reason to impose such a ridiculous measure.   The family member in speak, had the misfortune of having chronic pain that caused some understandable anxiety after surgery.  This surgery was needed to repair damage left by giving birth.  Unfortunately, the fix was not perfect.  After a brief struggle with mild narcotic addiction, we found Kratom.  Kratom offered pain relief without the sedating side effects left by narcotics.  Kratom is able to provide mild anxiolytic properties as well.  
When I heard that the DEA was going to ban Kratom, I was absolutely floored!  None of the reasons listed for the ban make any sense.  In my vast years of emergency experience, I have NEVER seen a side effect from Kratom usage.  Traditional opoids have taken countless lives.  Heroin deaths are all too common and I promise you that if Kratom is banned, you WILL not maybe but WILL see an increase in heroin related deaths.  Why might you ask, because people use Kratom in their everyday lives.  They are able to do their day to day activities because they are not overly sedated as is the case when taking narcotics.  These same people will always need relief and that will lead them to back to narcotics and in many cases, non-functionality.
Schedule I drugs include Heroin, MDMA and LSD, meaning that there is no safe medicinal value and the dangers of consumption are high.  Heck, even cocaine has been shown to have medicinal value.  You want to say Kratom has no medicinal value and the risk of death associated with its use is high.  This is simply not true. It is unconstitutional to place it into Schedule I status to "study" the drug.  Scheduling a drug should occur after multiple scientific, fact based and non-biased research studies have taken place.  In the mean time, issue a warning, no potential jail time because the DEA doesn't know what it is talking about!!
On a personal level, the family member I mentioned is my wife.  She is very sensitive to medicines and has no interest in being doped up for the day.  She has successfully established herself as a housewife, stay at home mom and home school teacher to our 6 year old.  Without any exaggeration, Kratom has been the medicine to make this possible.  Pain is an everyday reality for her but Kratom allows her to function as a normal human being while not being sedated, wanting to sleep and fighting constipation.  I cannot imagine her not being able to have the Kratom and shutter at what we would have to do if you decided to ban it. 
As a nurse, I see the value in this as well.  I see narcotic addiction daily.  It is detrimental and does take lives.  Kratom provides an opportunity for safe and effective pain relief.  Why would the DEA want to take something away that has been proven time and time again to work, away from everyday people.  Would I trust a pilot to fly me on Kratom? Yes.  Would I allow a surgeon to operate on me after taking Kratom? Yes.  Is it safe to drive a car while taking Kratom? Yes.  Can you care for a child while taking Kratom? Yes.  The list goes on, but I think my point is clear.  This medicine does not endanger anybody taking it or anybody around somebody taking it. 
It's time to exercise good and moral judgement and drop this potential ban.  If you choose to study it, great!  You will find a great and safe substitution for narcotics.  If your goal is a safe medicine, you have found it.
Please don't hurt my 6 year old son by making his mommy have pain again.

documents.commentText:
Wyatt Spruck
500 Greenhaven Drive
Burnsville, MN 55306
Age: 24
Profession:  Arborist/Tree Climber

I oppose the DEA's intent to schedule Kratom and it's constituent components.
Kratom is not a threat to public welfare - it is not nearly as much of a problem as the nationwide opiate epidemic, alcoholism, and other more harmful substances.  The DEA has not provided a strong enough argument (statistical, or otherwise) for why kratom is such a terrible threat to public welfare.  It certainly is not worthy of an outright ban and it certainly has potential medicinal value in the realm of addiction recovery, pain management, among many others.  

I started using kratom to help combat a drinking problem I started to develop in my early twenties.  It helped me with rebound insomnia, stress, and lessened my depressive issues.  

Currently, I use kratom as a pain management aid (I have alot of aches, pains, cuts, bruises etc muscle soreness from my profession), a sleep aid, and a stress management aid.  It is the best supplement I have ever come across that is legally available, affordable, and relatively benign in it's effects (the effects aren't strong or overwhelming, so I can still function and not be intoxicated or anything like that).

To conclude:  I have personally found kratom to be very useful to me and I would like to continue using it legally.  It does not deserve a outright ban because it is a useful supplement, is benign (i.e. not on the same level as illicit street drugs, does not pose the same amount of threat) and should be available for people to use it freely and legally.

documents.commentText: I suffered from opiate addiction the last 2 and a half years specifically because of managing pain. I woke up everyday with a head full of anxiety and cold sweats, until I took my first pill (hydrocodone) of the day. Every single day I woke up feeling the terrible effects of withdrawal from a prescription granted to me by my doctor and regulated by you. Yes, the hydrocodone does take away my ankle pain but with it comes the burden of withdrawal, tolerance, and constipation. I decided enough was enough and started researching alternative medicines. I couldn't keep living like that. I tried several different ways to self medicate but none of them worked very well, until I first tried Kratom. After reading stories of people suffering like me, I ordered a 50 grams online just to try it and it and im very happy I did. When I received my order, I waited until the next morning to take it so i could distinguish if it really worked as well as I had read. At 7 am the next day, overwhelmed with cold sweats, I took 4 grams and waited. 20 minutes later my withdrawal symptoms as well as the pain in my ankle completely diminished. I couldn't believe it. I continued to take it for the entire week and day by day i would wake up with less anxiety, cold sweats and my constipation abruptly stopped. After about 2 weeks, I no longer had any symptoms of opiate addiction. I hadn't taken my prescription at all during this time. Soon after, I had an appointment with my pain management doctor and told him about my experience with kratom as well as not taking my hydrocodone. He advised me to stop taking it and continue my normal medication even though I killed my addiction as well as being pain free. I got in a rather large argument with him about how I was medicating with kratom and just flat out told him im done with the pills and wont be needing his assistance anymore. Id become more physically active, more social, and just felt much healthier as well as having no ill effects (besides pain) if I didn't take a kratom dose. No withdrawal, no worrying about my next dose, nothing. All this happened about 3-4 months ago. Then, I recently found out the DEA wants to place it as a schedule 1 substance and it devastated me. This completely natural plant improved my lifestyle much more than i could have ever imagined and now the government wants to tell me I cant continue taking it without breaking the law. This stuff is not heroin, I dont feel "high" or dopey on it like I did with vicoden and I dont have any withdrawal from it either. I cant go back to taking that poison, it ruined me for years. I was extreamly dependent on taking my pills, felt lazy, had horrible withdrawal symptoms when i woke up every morning and everytime i had to defficate it felt like i was giving birth to a brick. Furthermore my dosing wasnt even remotely high, 7.5mg hydrocodone every four or five hours. Please listen to people like me, and the hundreds of thousands who share the same story, when we say PLEASE DO NOT SCHEDULE KRATOM. It turned my life around to the point people close to me noticed it. I didnt inform my wife about it until she told me I was acting much more enthusiastic and active than normal. Im actually going to the gym regularly again. Even my boss noticed I was getting more work done in the office as well as not limping around from the occasional bursts of pain. So, I ask one more time, please do not ban this amazing plant. It made my life much better. If anything, ban hydrocodone and its prescription substitutes, they ruined my daily life. To this day, I have not experienced any ill effects from this plant and pray that ill be able to continue taking it. If it does get banned, I will probably just cope with the pain and use aspirin. For the sake of the argument i should tell you how I destroyed my ankle. 3 years ago, I flipped a highly modified kabota (basically a 2 seated quad). When it flipped, my side of the roll cage hit a large rock before dropping of a small cliff. The front left beam of the roll cage (I was driving) broke at the bottom welds and was bent down angled into the floorboards of the kabota. Then my leg was in-between the floor and the broken beam of the roll cage when the kabota fell off the small cliff (7-9 foot drop) and landed on its roof. This forced the beam into my leg, right above the ankle. The ripped steel end of the beam went completely through the bottom part of my left leg, but just barely. Now i have several plates/screws in my leg as well as a reconstructed ankle. The doctors recommended it be amputated it was so torn up, but we decided to try and save it anyway. Im lucky to still have two functioning feet.To this day I still have moderate pain with the slightest movement. Prescription opiates destroy lives, kratom saved me from opiate hell I was in and made me who I was before the accident.

documents.commentText:
To whom it may concern :  I am a 24 year old student out of Colorado. Two years ago in May of 2015, I was in a serious car accident in Dallas, Texas which resulted in my entire life being halted, and dislocating multiple bones and vertebrae.  I had to quit every job I had, withdrew from school, and sunk into a deep depression. I was suffering mentally, and physically while no one really knew what was happening. 

Shortly after I lost access to getting my medications, I started using illegal drugs like heroin and other opiates to help sleep, eat, and be active. Using heroin once a week became twice a week, then everyday and then a full blown addiction. 

I was selling every possession i owned just to get high. 

One day I was searching online like I did everyday to find a solution or a way out of the hell i was living and came across krater on Facebook . Ive compromised every moral in my life for a momentary high or just to feel better. Anytime I tried to stop, I had seizures . I wouldnt eat, I couldnt sleep, and I lost over 100 pounds in 7 months was now at 98 pounds. 

I drove two hours to get a sample at a local shop while I was withdrawing. I literally risked my life just to try anything that would work.

within minutes of drinking it, I remember the calming wave of peace and comfort in my body/ My body stopped seizing , my temperature fell to normal, and for once in such a long time, I was actually hungry. I ate an entire plate of Spaghetti at olive garden. I went from smoking a half gram of heroin a day, to taking nothing  (Not even krater ) in less than a month. My withdrawals had stopped immediately. Almost completely. I am still in shock.  I was fighting suicidal actions just the night before, and now I was in no pain. 

This was all in October of this year. Now its December 1st, and Im sober. Im employed, Im healing, Im happy, Im healthy. My life went from the gutter to outstanding with the help of a simple plant just like anything else natural like coffee or Marijuana.  I never thought I would have a way out of hell, until kratom gave me the tools to pull myself out. I do not feel any cravings for krater . I drink it when I feel pain in my body, and probably only twice a week at this point. I cant imagine ever scamming people or screwing over family for money to get kratom. Thats absurd. For heroin while Im withdrawing, I would do anything. There is a huge difference and If I hadnt had access to krater, I would be on the news for shooting myself. Honestly I had no intentions of living past october, and my life is forever in debt to the people who provided me an amazing, quality product. 

I truly hope you see that banning this plant is going to do nothing but kill thousands of innocent people. Please find it in your hearts and minds to test, research and regulate krater for safe public consumption like Marijuana !

We thank you with compassion from all of our hearts,

documents.commentText:
My name is Randall Smith, I am 58 years old and have been employed by the same company for over 36 years. I oppose any effort to restrict the availability, sale and use of Kratom by adults. 

I have gone from being a healthy, active young man to being partially disabled due to chronic pain diagnosed and treated as psoriatic arthritis. Until I discovered Kratom (Mitragyna speciosa) five years ago, my life was filled with daily pain and depression. I had been very active in my church, gardening, home remodeling and playing an assortment of musical instruments prior to the onset of the chronic pain, and then I lost the ability to do many of the things I loved due to the pain and loss of movement in my hands, hips, back and shoulders. 

Having had some experience with herbal supplements in the past, I discovered Kratom in a search to find a natural, herbal way to combat the arthritis. Even though I was being treated by a rheumatologist, I was having limited success finding relief with the very expensive drugs (which also carry a long list of possible side effects including, lung infections and lymphoma). I read quite a lot about Kratom before trying it and felt that it was far less likely to cause harm than the FDA approved biologic drug I was prescribed (which cost me thousands of dollars every year).

Since using Kratom as an herbal supplement, I have regained the ability to do most all of the activities I enjoyed, from gardening to playing guitar. My pain levels are very low, my attitude and sense of well-being are up. I look forward to life again, rather than simply waiting to die to end the pain. Because of the biologic drug that my rheumatologist prescribes, and the fact that it can adversely affect several of my organs, I have regular blood-work done so my doctor can watch for any adversities. So far, I am healthier now than I was prior to adding Kratom to my diet.

Kratom is an amazingly helpful plant which has been used safely for hundreds, if not thousands of years. It is not a threat to our society, in fact it is more of a miracle helpful plant that has changed people's lives in positive ways all across the USA. Scheduling Kratom to restrict adult use is a shameful choice.

Keep Kratom legal and available to the citizens of the USA! Let us use what nature has provided and do not force us to consume harmful chemicals synthesized by the greed of corporations.

Thank you for listening.

Sincerely,
Randall C. Smith

documents.commentText:
Kratom should not be a scheduled drug. Kratom is no more dangerous than any other legal botanical dietary supplement.. 

I am a 29 year old attorney who consumes kratom regularly. I take kratom because it is a healthy botanical that helps boost my mood and gives me energy to get through difficult tasks. At times, I have taken kratom daily for up to a month. I have always been able to stop taking kratom "cold turkey" for weeks at a time without any withdrawal symptoms. For me, kratom has fewer negative side effects than caffeine.

I know several people who use kratom for a variety of reasons. Every person I know who uses kratom is a respected member of society who has never been in trouble with the law. While taking kratom, none of us feel or act intoxicated. When I take kratom I feel relaxed and focused. It does not impair my ability to think or act. 

Any substance can be abused. As many people have died from water intoxication as have allegedly died from kratom. The possibility of abuse is not a reason for scheduling a substance. Research has made clear that the potential for abuse of kratom is very low. Kratom does not cause respiratory depression. You cannot over dose on natural kratom because your body will cause you to vomit if you take too much. Kratom does not work as a recreational drug because the "high" is so mild. Long term use of kratom does not harm the body. For all these reasons, kratom is significantly less harmful than alcohol or tobacco. 

Basing drug laws on fear and misinformation is a grave injustice to the people of the US. Putting people in prison and ruining their lives for taking a substance that helps them is unacceptable. Given the extremely low risk of kratom, the potential harm cause by criminalizing kratom far exceeds the benefits. If the DEA and FDA actually care about the american people, they will not schedule kratom.

documents.commentText: In 1970, when I was 10 years old, I was hit by a car while crossing a busy highway. Since then, I've suffered from chronic pain in my back and hips. I've been to physical therapists, chiropractors and doctors. While physical therapy and chiropractic adjustments have provided some relief, my experiences with doctors has been less satisfactory. I've declined back surgery because the success rate is slim to none. Doctors have routinely prescribed muscle relaxers and acetaminophen-hydrocodone. In my case, both medications have caused more harm than good. Muscle relaxers left me barely functional and they exacerbated my scoliosis. Acetaminophen-hydrocodone hampered my faculties, and as an opiate was far too addictive (I am recovering alcoholic). When I discovered kratom one year ago, I finally found something that works for me. It blocks - or interferes with - my pain receptors to a significant extent, so that I'm able to stretch, move and exercise - which is the true remedy for my symptoms. I now use kratom in conjunction with exercise (pilates) and physical therapy. It's not a perfect solution, but I can function and work a full time job without the debilitating side effects of opiates and/or muscle relaxers. I also avoid the risk of addiction that acetaminophen-hydrocodone poses. If kratom is banned, I doubt I will find anything that works as well for pain while posing low to no risk of addiction.

documents.commentText:
On August 30, the DEA announced its intent to ban kratom, a medicinal plant used for millennia in Southeast Asia and currently used by millions in the United States. After DPA members and activists sent over 70,000 messages to Congress, 51 Representatives and almost a dozen Senators asked the DEA to postpone their ban.

If kratom is added to any one of the five drug schedules, people who use it will be criminalized and locked up behind bars.

Kratom has been used safely by millions of people in the U.S. and evidence supports kratom's potential as a pain reliever and opioid replacement.

Banning kratom expands the war on drugs, while the public overwhelmingly supports ending it. Kratom should be legally regulated, allowing for quality control measures and product labeling requirements.

Prohibiting kratom will worsen the country's problems of opioid addiction and overdose.

documents.commentText:
Dear Sir or Madam,

     I am an RN and I'm writing to demand that this proposed ban on Kratom be put to rest and that our rights as Americans not be violated one more time. 

    Allowing the DEA to ban Kratom - a PLANT, a VEGETABLE - from use by human beings who have been using it for millennia as a medicine, is an abomination.
 
      I'm sure you've already heard from hundreds of thousands of Kratom users about the benefits of this medicinal plant. I won't bore you with an iteration.

      Not only does this Kratom ban leave citizens without an alternative to deadly pharmaceutical drugs but puts many Americans who make a living through distributing this natural product out of business. This is so wrong on so many levels!
   
     As we approach the November elections, it's likely that marijuana is going to be legalized more and more. The Pharmaceutical companies will be feeling the pinch in their revenues from a decided reduction of sales of side-effect laden sedative and pain drugs when this happens. One doesn't have to stretch the imagination too far to realize that banning Kratom will ease the pain of that bottom line pinch.

       It's no secret that the pharmaceutical industry  stands to benefit by making illegal all natural alternative therapies (which cannot be patented)  and substitute non bio-available profitable 'substances' in their place.

     The states determine what's legal in their area but the DEA can - with one stroke of a pen - make anything  illegal overnight??!! This is preposterous. Then overnight hundreds of thousands of law abiding citizens will become criminals? I say NO.
  
      I implore you. Please exercise intelligence and common sense and tell the DEA to CEASE AND DESIST.

documents.commentText: It is of great concern to me that kratom is being scrutinized.  I myself have dibilitating headaches for which I consumed Tylenol/ibuprofen/bc powder for many years in great quantity in an attempt to lead a somewhat normal life.  That being said, what is in those pills?  How harsh are they on my body?  So much that I was advised medically to refrain from using any NSAID due to bleeding internally that was caused strictly by them!  I found kratom, tried it, not for a high or low but in a last ditch attempt to find a solution to my ailment of which no one but a fellow sufferer could understand.  Kratom was a god send-  no side effects, no fillers, no unknown pill coatings or delivery devices.  Kratom was and is a simple medicinal plant,  - natural remedy long used by those who are native to its regions.  This plant has changed my life , and in a very positive way.  The seller from which I buy has information, pictures, communications, and even trees of her own that come from her supplier.  There are no chemical additives, no byproducts, and no environmental harm that arise from the growing, harvesting, and use of kratom.  The USA is obviously in a predicament with the opioids flooding the street, but we the people/government caused it.  What the commoner does not realize is the heroin, fentanyl, carfentanyl, etc that is flooding our streets and killing our people is due to the fact that the government took away a controlled form of dependency , the pills.   At least when taking a pill you know how much you are taking, if you overdose it's your own fault, you knew how much you were taking.  With the street drugs nobody knows the potency and therefore the first hit is not the same as the second then you die.  This ban is just as ridiculous as the marijuana debate right now, many states allow the use of it, even D.C.  Now that's our nations capital....... yet federally it's illegal?  How ridiculous is that?  Kratom being compared to other drugs as addictive is absurd, and the pitiful poison control statistics related to kratom "overdose"?  What a joke.   Kratom itself prevents too much ingestion by inducing vomiting, I have not seen anyone trying to ban alcohol, it's the most abundant toxic drug next to tobacco that we encounter in our lives.  Kratom is a life saver, I have seen the benefits many times over, addicts taken from the illegal pills/powders, users able to withdraw from other things and still function, and the reduction of pain among other benefits.  The best thing we can do is allow kratom and keep it from being a pharmaceutical money maker. The pharm companies as we all know, and the gov has created/allowed , are making record profits by ripping off the every day consumer.   It's time to quit letting the big companies run our country.   Let kratom keep us healthy and safe .  I would hope the next time statistics or the like are brought up in the public eye that we are seeing accurate numbers, real situations, and a comparison to other chemicals that our gov allows to be in every household in the country .

Hello my name is Kevin Hogan I am 24 years old and work as a security guard. I personally oppose the scheduling of Kratom as a schedule 1 drug, mainly because my personal experience and the experiences of peers of mine have only been therapeutic and life changing in a very helpful way. I was 21 years old and near homeless struggling to make ends meet to buy my daily dose of heroin I needed to not be sick. I started using opiates as a teenager and got hooked in my late teens.  I couldn't afford rehab and wanted more than anything to escape the trap I had got myself stuck in. I had read about Kratom and ordered some online. I brewed the tea anxiously wondering if my withdrawals would go away and whether or not I would get high off it. Well my withdrawals did definitely stop but I have never in all my use of it experienced a high. I will attest to anxiety relief and slight mood elevation similar to a good cup of coffee but nothing that ever came close to impairing me. I have never experienced respiratory depression from Kratom and I am very familiar with how respiratory depression feels due to my experience with opiates and opioids.  I would warn against scheduling this drug in this class. It could very well be the cheap cure to the opiate/heroin epidemic my community has been facing for the last decade or so.
  Sincerely, 
  Kevin Travis Hogan

documents.commentText: I can't speak for others but offer my personal experience. Please regulate rather than eliminate. I've stopped using Kratom since the first potential ban date in September, and have sorely missed it's help in dealing with our conditions. My wife was diagnosed two years ago with rheumatoid arthritis and has used Kratom when needed for pain relief after hundreds of wasted dollars on muscle relaxers and opiate pain medications which caused side effects that far outweighed any relief they provided. The Kratom was more effective than Percocet and Skelaxin combined. It also raised her energy level instead of causing drowsiness, seemed to sharpen her focus instead of causing delirium, did not cause constipation and didn't have a rebound effect or any addictive desire to take more if it was not needed. My personal experience comes from stomach ulcers which prohibit any anti-inflammatory drugs even if I have muscle or bone pain, which I sometimes do from a previous severe car accident and the occasional migraine headache. If I'm experiencing pain that Tylenol isn't able to conquer, which threatens to prevent me from work or household activities, Kratom can eliminate the pain, usually without a trace. My mood is lifted, my energy levels go up, and this for an entire day. It is less expensive and more effective than any prescription I've tried for these same issues, and leaves no lingering effects. Hopefully a solution is possible which dissuades misuse but allows for availability to those who have a real need.

documents.commentText:
Banning kratom expands the war on drugs, while the public overwhelmingly supports ending it.

    If kratom is added to any one of the five drug schedules, people who use it will be criminalized and locked up behind bars.

    Kratom has been used safely by millions of people in the U.S. and evidence supports kratom's potential as a pain reliever and opioid replacement.

    Many people struggling with opioid addiction have turned to kratom to help them cut back or quit, but now all promising scientific studies on kratom's role in opioid treatment could be immediately shut down.

    Side effects of kratom are minimal, and its withdrawal symptoms are weak and nearly inconsequential compared to the suffering of people trying to quit opioids.

    Prohibiting kratom will worsen the country's problems of opioid addiction and overdose.
