documents.commentText:
Please do not ban kratom. It is not the devil drug that the media & government et al makes it out to be.  I advise everyone who is considering banning the plant to read Forbe's journalist David DiSalvo's experience with kratom:  http://www.daviddisalvo.org/the-daily-brain/2013/4/5/results-of-my-kratom-experiment.html

Kratom is a "drug" in the way that caffeine is a drug, it's in the same family. The only difference is that caffeine has actually killed people. Kids overdose on it, middle schoolers pop no-doz like candy. Heck - that was the first "drug" I ever tried! You want to discuss gateway drugs - look at caffeine.  I went to school with kids who literally overdosed on it and ended up in the emergency room. One thirteen year-old boy died...from caffeine and booze. 

 This hasn't happened with kratom. Most of the time, when kratom has been blamed for a death - other real  drugs have been in the victims' systems.   Specifically Xanax. 

Those "OK" drugs are the ones big Pharmaceutical companies push on Americans. Part of the reason this bill exists in the first place (because I guarantee a good portion of government workers had to Google it and hadn't heard of it until it became the media's favorite scapegoat) is because chronic pain patients were seeking out natural alternatives to their legally prescribed dope.  You know, oxycodone, Percocet, Vicodin,  etc.  

The problem is that kratom worked too well - not only did it relieve pain and make life manageable, it lacked many of the negative side effects of the legal stuff. Heroin addicts turned to it to get off life long prescriptions to suboxone and subutex - addiction "cures" that are more dangerous and addicting than actual heroin!  So people talked about it online, dedicated forums to it, and it got the attention of well meaning - but seriously misguided legislators.  Just because kratom has some subtle enjoyable effects (relaxing or energizing depending on the strain) the powers that be don't want us to have it.  

Then, greedy and irresponsible vendors market kratom as a "legal high" and ruin it for the rest of us. 

Yet - no one is pushing to ban tobacco - a drug is guaranteed to kill you (and doesn't even get you high!). Or alcohol - a drug responsible for 88,000 deaths per year.  But suddenly, after decades of demonization Marijuana is OK  (because the war on drugs showed the government just how lucrative that natural herb could be, and all the potential profits they were missing out on).  

Like marijuana, kratom has at least anecdotal healing properties.  Think passionflower. Unlike marijuana - and contradictory to sensational stories - kratom is not psychedelic in any sense of the word.  Kratom's effects on the brain and behavior are minimal, and certainly less than those of marijuana (no one gets paranoid or develops schizophrenia from drinking too much kratom).  Also, as any kratom user knows, if you drink too much, it makes you nauseous.  It's like kratom has a built in mechanism to prevent abuse. Less is definitely more when it comes to this substance. 

it's about as addicting as coffee. If you use it daily for a long time, and suddenly stop - you will feel slightly out of it, bored, and a little lethargic. Approximately, the same level of discomfort as quitting caffeine.  


To say kratom should be banned because it leads addicts back into addiction is as logical as banning alcohol because alcoholics abuse it. Addicts are exactly that - they will try to get high on anything - from huffing glue to inhaling their own excrement to guzzling down Robitussin.   

I could go on and on....but this is already epic. I apologize if this comes off as ranting, but  Kratom has been a lifesaver for me.  I need to defend it. I've suffered from anxiety my entire life. I've tried all of those so-called anti-anxiety drugs - from Xanex to Valium - and they make the problem worse. Guess what the side effects of anti-anxiety meds are when they wear off? Anxiety and agitation. Tolerance builds quickly, so you need to up your dose just to keep it working. And these drugs are deadly. Withdrawls from benzodiazepines can literally kill you. How's that for a "cure"?  

I also have a herniated disk and find kratom works wonders for my chronic pain. 

Kratom is a homeopathic remedy that works. The so-called "high" can't be compared to Darvocet, let alone heroin. It's more like a glass of red wine followed by chamomile tea. It shouldn't be sold to anyone under 18 - the same way caffeine or alcohol shouldn't be.

documents.commentText:
I have been a Kratom consumer for approximately three years. I am a 39 year old male. I am a practicing attorney. I am a father. I am married. I am a small business owner. I am listed as anonymous because I have doubts as to the privacy of these comments. 

Prior to using Kratom as an herbal supplement, I was prone to panic attacks and depression and was prescribed Xanax and Ambien to deal with the anxiety and panic attacks that would come at me on a daily and nightly basis. I was drinking 3-6 alcoholic beverages per night. Since using Kratom, I have had no need to fill my prescriptions - NONE OF THEM. I'll have maybe a beer at night but rarely do I even finish it. This amazing plant, Kratom, is a healthy alternative supplement to prescribed drugs. I'm getting emotional just thinking about how its changed my life for the better, for the healthier!!

Make no mistake, Kratom is not a drug, it is an herbal supplement which should be sold at health food stores. For me, there are no negative side effects of Kratom. My physician and therapist are both aware of my Kratom consumption and both have been monitoring my health with no adverse symptoms to date. In fact, my blood pressure has significantly decreased from pre-hypertension levels to standard levels of a person my age. I can't 100% attribute that to the Kratom, but it could be a byproduct of the decrease in alcohol and medications that is a direct result of taking Kratom. 

I take Kratom 2-3 times per day as needed. It is truly a miracle supplement that should not be scheduled. Regulation yes, scheduling, no. 

Thank you for your consideration. Please do the right thing and keep Kratom legal and available for responsible adults.

documents.commentText:
The DEA should stop any and all consideration of banning the herbal supplement kratom. There should be no prohibition. While the FDA is looking into it as well, most Americans have never heard of it. Why? Because there's NO REAL PROBLEM with it! Quite the contrary...

Kratom seems like a solution to a number of issues, including various forms of drug addiction and chronic pain. Plus, it can perform the pain-killing work of morphine without dangerously depressing breathing -- the way opioids do.

Here's how Kratom works...
It uses a pathway that mediates many of the undesirable effects of traditional opioids such as constipation, respiratory depression. In fact, this knowledge is spurring additional research by pharmaceutical companies.
http://bit.ly/2c8UTI6

About Kratom, a leading researcher notes...
Thailand is considering legalizing kratom as a safer alternative for meth addicts. U.S. researchers are trying to study its potential to help opiate abusers kick the habit without withdrawal side effects.
http://bit.ly/2c8SI7v
There are anecdotal reports of addiction risk. But it appears the addiction can be broken without withdrawal symptoms. Meanwhile, the painkillers currently being used are more addictive, dangerous, and harder to kick. Yet...

The FDA and DEA both appear ready to ban kratom and effectively kill research to further develop this substance. Is the DEA is running cover for a Big Pharma company that wants to monopolize kratom?

As I consider these actions by the FDA and DEA I'm forced to wonder -- WHAT ARE YOU PEOPLE SMOKING?

documents.commentText:
As a clinical herbalist based in Boulder, Colorado I am horrified to think that the DEA is considering restricting access to yet another medical plant. It is highly arrogant of the department to conclude (with little to no research) that Kratom has no legitimate use outside of "getting high."

Have those on the board recommending this decision ever used Kratom? It is very easy to purchase online and can be made into tea like any other herbal infusion. If they haven't, they are not qualified to speak to this issue. Period. It is NOT a recreational drug, it is a medicated herbal tea. And while some may experiment with abusing it, most find that is a poor choice or substitute to cannabis (what they would most likely prefer to use) and never use it again. Like Salvia divinorum (also foolishly restricted and similarly demonized) this is a natural substance that, along with many other plants, can be used very effectively to treat depression and symptoms of opioid withdrawal. It is a far, far safer medicine (with fewer side effects) than many legal pharmaceuticals. Why would the DEA want to restrict the use of this amazing plant? If it is because of the fear that it may be abused, then why not consider further restricting alcohol or tobacco access? Alcohol and tobacco -- while legal -- are far more dangerous and are abused to a much greater extent that Kratom.

Please reconsider scheduling this medicinal plant. By making it illegal you are firming up its place in the underworld, lining the pockets of dangerous drug dealers and creating "criminals" of herbal practitioners, their clients and many otherwise law-abiding citizens.

documents.commentText:
Dear sir or madam,

Thank you for taking the time to accept input about the scheduling of miragynine and the plant referred to as Kratom.

I am a 36 year old paramedic who lives and works in Upstate NY, in a variety of communities from rural to urban. I also was a user of Kratom for approximately two years prior to my employment as a paramedic.

In my opinion, both professional and personal, it would be a disservice to the citizens of the US to schedule this plant or its chemicals. 

My personal experience with Kratom was to relieve social anxiety while I was job seeking during the recession of 2008. Kratom helped with the job interview process. It provided some relief from the depression that also comes with long term unemployment. I also found it useful to give me energy, and provided help to be productive in the search. I was able to stop using Kratom without any untoward effects the day I found employment. I experienced none of the withdrawal that sometimes accompanies other medicines.

As a paramedic, I have on occasion come across patients who use Kratom. In my ten years as a paramedic, no patient has ever called for Kratom-related events. Every Kratom user I have met in the course of work has been using the herb to mitigate chronic pain. The patients claim that it helps them to abstain from, or limit the use of opiate drugs. I do not feel that scheduling this herb will help this patient population, and will cause them to rely on drug with a much more dangerous therapeutic window. I already see a fair share of opiate overdoses in any given week. Anything that is available to limit the spread of this deadly opiate epidemic should be celebrated, not banished to the black market.

I trust that you will see to do the right thing and listen to the scientific evidence available, as well as the people who are leading productive lives thanks to Kratom.

Respectfully,
Kevin Green, EMT-P

Angela Inda

Then there is my mother, who has some so much for me, sand sacrificed so much and I love her so much. Several years ago she had worsening depression and anxiety where everything from Paxil, to lexapro, to Zoloft in conjunction with Xanax, klonopin, ambien, and more. This did not help and I believe made things worse. This killed me to see. The person I loved so much having to live with these terrible mental conditions was too much for me. I found kratom. Please don't take this away from everyone that it has been a miracle for. There is no public safety issue whatsoever. There will be if if is scheduled and I am truly terrified. This is simply wrong and I the only reason for this that I can come up with is pursuit of the interests of some segment of the pharmaceutical industry. Myself and so many in similar situations are very frightened and baffled. Please please condider these messages and please do the right thing. Thank you so much and I pray that you do what's right. Feel free to contact me if you would like to discuss or anything.

documents.commentText: I am 58 years old and I have had terrible chronic back pain for about 18 years now. I have taken prescription opioid pain medications for most of those 18 years. I developed a dependence on prescription opioids. I don't think I was addicted because I didn't take larger and larger doses to get high, I was taking it to relieve pain and did not increase the dose without the physicians OK. But I did develop a dependence, which anyone who takes opioids regularly would. I also ran into tolerance issues where the opioids stop working as well as they once did. Because of these issues I started trying to wean off of the opioids. It didn't go very well, it was very difficult. I heard about kratom, ordered some and tried some. I immediately lost most of the craving that you get for opioids, this effect seems to remain even after the kratom has worn off. I have heard others say this happened to them too. Kratom needs to be studied for this craving reducing effect. If it is put into Schedule 1 the studies won't happen. I was able to wean myself off of opioids with the help of kratom. I am opioid free now and I only use kratom when my pain is really bad. Kratom does work pretty well for pain relief. It does cause dependence though if you take it every day for a long period, and it does causes withdrawal symptoms if you stop taking it after taking it for a long period, although the withdrawal is nothing near the terrible withdrawal from opioids. I only take kratom every few days at the most to avoid dependence. I could probably go without kratom but it sure is nice to have it available when I need some relief. The clinic I was going to recently decided they will no longer prescribe opioids for chronic pain because of the pressure being put on them and the physicians to not prescribe opioids. All the other clinics and most physicians here have done the same. I don't think this is the right way to treat chronic pain patients, but it is how things are right now. So I could no longer get a prescription for opioids if I wanted to. Personally, I would never resort to using heroin to relieve my pain because it is just too dangerous, but other people will use it. Making kratom illegal would just make the heroin problem worse. I think this is a big flaw in the approach currently being taken, making substances illegal and/or unavailable, it just pushes people with chronic pain or pain pill addictions to use heroin, because it is the only thing they can get their hands on. With heroin the strength is unknown, especially with fentanyl and carfentanyl being added to it lately. And that is why people overdose on it, people don't know how much to take from one batch to another. I believe kratom is keeping a lot of people off of heroin. I think kratom should be regulated for purity and strength, but making kratom a scheduled controlled substance would be a mistake.

documents.commentText:
Kratom is a very mild plant that induces a slight feeling of well being. It does not cloud the mind.  I read, do math, have intelligent conversations (that I remember) all while consuming Kratom. I suffered a severe clinical depression 25 years ago when my husband walked out on me and our two young children. It nearly killed me. I am certain if I had known about and had access to Kratom then, I would NOT have suffered such a deep depression and developed a life-time dependence on SSRI antidepressants and anti-anxiety prescription medicine. There are ample reports that Kratom helps people wean themselves from heroin and other opiates. I can show you the science (BTW, I am a neuroscientist with an emphasis in psychopharmacology). I take Kratom very responsibility for anxiety and depression and would be seeking alternatives if it became unavailable.

The report of 15 deaths with Kratom detected in the system have been each refuted that Kratom was a contributor. Besides -- 15 deaths in 3 years?  More have been killed by lightening, sharks or gator shark attacks.  Compare that to almost 50,000 deaths in opiate ODs each year in the US.  I'll show you a woman in Australia who died of an "overdose" of Coca Cola (she was severely malnourished too).

The DEA has lost a lot of credibility over the past 4 decades. This kind of nonsense gives the impression that it is massively over-reaching its mission and making a power grab.  Kratom is far less harmful than cannabis, which we are currently doing a giant public health experiment with.  In both cases, though, making these drugs "Class 1", along with heroin, runs a chill down the academic communities, who are in the best position to do pre-clinical and clinical trials to determine safety and efficacy. I'm a federal scientist (can't say my position or affiliation, as it violates my taking a political stance in the name of my position) but I'm in a position to know first hand the number of top-notch universities and hospitals who refuse to do human work on THC and cannabis because of the conflicting state and federal laws; they are afraid to lose their federal funding.

I hope you will reconsider this ill-conceived ban.
 Sincerely , M. Catherine Bennett, PhD (signature line below is not a working link)

documents.commentText:
My name is Lisa and I am a paralegal and a single mother of 4 children between the ages of 9 and 18. I was diagnosed with a progressive idiopathic disease in 2003. One of the main symptoms of this disease is chronic headaches. Said headaches are not relieved by most pharmaceuticals. Opiates are usually the only option when treating the pain associated with this disease. As a result of chronic pain, I have developed depression and anxiety.  

Following the addition of the herbal supplement Kratom to my diet, I have noticed a decrease in my pain, a reduction in my anxiety level and an improvement in my overall well being. I do not feel drugged or loopy while utilizing Kratom; nor do I notice other side effects normally associated with opiates. When I do not include Kratom in my diet, I do not experience withdrawal symptoms. 

Although my experience is purely anecdotal, there are hundreds, if not thousands of American citizens who share my story. Like me, these people strongly oppose banning Kratom, thereby making it illegal for us to continue reaping Kratom's benefits. Also, rescheduling Kratom as a Schedule I drug, will make researching and studying this amazing herb, all but impossible. 

Finally, in order for a substance to be considered a Schedule I drug, it must meet the criteria: a) a high potential for abuse; b) no medicinal value; and c) dangerous for human consumption. The thousands of personal stories told by the majority of commenters herein, make it obvious that Kratom is beneficial to many peoples' health and is either not habit forming or is no more addictive than caffeine. Since there has only been 15 deaths associated with Kratom in the United States and in 14 of those cases there were multiple drugs found in the deceased person's system, it must be concluded there is little to no risk associated with Kratom usage.

In conclusion, due to my personal experience, along with all available evidence pertaining to Kratom -- it's usages, benefits, extremely low potential for abuse, and doubtful dangers -- I strongly oppose the scheduling of Kratom.

Thank you for your time and consideration.

I am a 31-year-old female working in Organ and Tissue Donation and I have suffered for the last 10 years from debilitating upper and mid-back pain, which radiates around my ribcage, affecting my ability to breathe deeply and digest food properly. documents.commentText:
To Whom It May Concern,

Several years ago I was diagnosed with scoliosis and lordosis which over the years have contributed to a growing amount of back pain. I used to take nonsteriodal anti-inflammatory drugs (NSAIDs) like ibuprofen to treat back pain with success, but eventually had to stop due to bleeding problems caused by the NSAIDs.  I didn't have many options left for treating my pain and started looking at natural alternatives. After doing some research I decided to try kratom. After experimenting with different strains and doses I found that kratom offered a decent reduction in my pain levels.  

About a year ago I experienced stomach pain and diarrhea following Thanksgiving dinner. This persisted for entire month and a half before finally subsiding. I visited my doctor and was told I might have irritable bowel syndrome (IBS).  I did some research and found that many sufferers had food triggers that caused the symptoms of IBS. My diet was not the best at the time and after cutting out foods one by one I discovered that the consumption of gluten containing foods seemed to be the main catalyst for my symptoms. Since this time my diet has improved significantly and for the most part I have remained symptom free. Every now and then I accidentally consume a food item that does contain gluten, and when that happens I am happy that I have kratom handy. When I take kratom after one of these episodes the duration of pain and diarrhea is significantly lessened.

According to a scientific journal article titled "Traditional and non-traditional uses of Mitragynine (Kratom): A survey of the literature." by Singh et al. (https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/27178014) the people of Eastern Asia have been using kratom for a long time and have found it to have good remedial value. It would be disastrous if kratom research became difficult to conduct which is exactly what will happen if the above chemicals are placed into schedule 1. Another article titled "Inhibitory effects of kratom leaf extract (Mitragyna speciosa Korth.) on the rat gastrointestinal tract" by Somsmorn et al. (http://www.sciencedirect.com/science/article/pii/S0378874107006083) describes an experiment conducted on rats that shows that kratom has a slowing effect on the transit of material through the intestine. I believe more experiments like this are needed to determine how kratom can best be used in western society.

One example of a scientist that is already taking steps to understand the chemicals contained within kratom can be found in this article by Angus Chen(http://www.pbs.org/newshour/rundown/without-kratom-promising-research-opioid-alternatives-may-suffer/). According to Angus Chen, the scientist Susruta Majumdar and his team of researchers have been researching mitragynine pseudoindoxyl which is a mu-opioid receptor agonist and a delta-opioid receptor antagonist. According to Majumdar, antagonism of the delta-opioid receptor can mitigate withdrawal symptoms of morphine in mice. This means that this chemical could be a potential tool for helping opiate addicts through withdrawal symptoms when they are trying to quit. Mitragynine Pseudoindoxyl is produced from fermented kratom leaves which means that if mitragynine and 7-hydroxymitragynine are placed in schedule 1, this research will have to halt. I believe that this research must continue.

I strongly urge the DEA to reconsider it's intention to place mitragynine and 7-hydroxymitragynine in schedule 1. This decision will make it very difficult for scientists to conduct the much needed research on this plant.

Sincerely,

Anonymous

documents.commentText:
Hi there,

Just wanted to give my $0.02 on the Kratom conversation.  I have had personal experience with it and believe it is quite dangerous.  Perhaps not Schedule 1 dangerous... but that being said I also do not believe Marijuana should be Schedule 1 and I know that Kratom is significantly more dangerous and physically addicting.  People need to know what they're getting into if they start using it for recreation.

I was introduced to it at the Kavasutra Kava Bar in Denver.  The euphoric feeling I got the first time was intense.  I enjoyed it very much.  I went back again a few weeks later and again had an intensely pleasant experience and could not believe it was legal.  I decided to do some research and most of what I stumbled across online were websites and articles by Kratom advocates... many of which described it as all-natural and perfectly harmless.  That's also when I discovered there were shops around Denver where I could buy it for use at home much cheaper than at the bar.

When I started using it on my own was when things got bad.  At first I was using it in the evenings or on the weekends.  In addition to the feeling of euphoria, I also learned that it had an effect similar to that of Adderol.  Over the next month I was finding it more and more difficult to concentrate on work (I would not use it during work hours).  Knowing at the time it's legal and thinking it harmless, I was not really paying attention to the fact that I was gradually using it more frequently.

Quick disclaimer:  I am a 30yo sales professional working from a home office and I have a prescription for Vyvanse (for adult ADD) and Citalopram (for depression and general anxiety).  However, for the past 10 years my anxiety and depression have been completely under control until this experience.

When I was starting to wonder during the work day whether my Vyvanse had lost it's effect, I made a desperate attempt to meet a proposal deadline by taking Kratom to see if I could get my mind focused again.  It worked!  Or at least it felt like it worked.  Looking back I don't think I was as productive as I felt but certainly more productive than when I had not taken Kratom... so I started leaning on it more heavily for work.

In addition to my inability to focus during work when I had not taken Kratom, I also started to notice increasing levels of melancholy day after day.  Over time, it turned into increasingly intense and constant depression.  I began worrying that my Citalopram was also losing its effect.  

By this time I had also started dating someone who knew I liked using Kratom and she started getting into it as well.  Shortly thereafter she started experiencing similar symptoms.  She mentioned to her psychiatrist she was using it and (according to her) he about flipped out and started listing off all of the risks and dangers associated with it that have yet to be sufficiently studied and even less sufficiently reported or published in ways that it would be easily accessible to people curious about it.  When she stopped using it, she went through about 1 week of withdrawal.

Turns out we had both unwittingly (yet surprisingly quickly) developed a physical dependence on kratom.  When I found out about this, I stopped cold turkey.  The problem was that I had been using it months longer than she had, probably more frequently and certainly in higher doses (I don't know if it makes a difference but I am 6'-5" and 240 lbs).  That's when my withdrawal began.

Withdrawal from kratom is absolute shitty hell.  The first two days were pretty much just elevated anxiety and a persistent, inexplicable gloomy sadness.  That quickly spiraled into an intense, unrelenting depression and anxiety levels like I've never experienced.  Then came the insomnia.  Then came Restless Leg Syndrome (I always thought that was invented by the pharmaceutical industry but learned it is for real and it's miserable).  Then came the headaches and the stomach pain.  It also goes without saying that my ability to concentrate on anything was gone and all I could do was lay on the couch or in my bed wishing I were dead.  I was not suicidal but, based on my experience, I believe withdrawal from kratom would be enough to push many people to a suicidal state if they didn't find out kratom was the source of the problem.

The worst of the withdrawal lasted almost 2 weeks.  After that, I still was not myself again until probably a month and a half later.  I told my doctor what was going on once I had hit rock bottom and he added Wellbutrin to my regimen to assist me through.  I made it through and will NEVER touch the stuff again... and I am someone who enjoys alcohol and recreational marijuana.

Kratom is extremely addictive and I think vendors should at least be required to inform consumers that they can easily develop a physical dependence once they start using it.  There are too many people out there saying it's harmless and it most certainly is not.

Thanks!

documents.commentText:
My name is Vignesh Sekar and I am a recent college graduate. I am currently a software engineer and a quality assurance analyst. I wholeheartedly oppose the proposition to ban Mitragynine and 7-OH-Mitragynine by categorizing them as a Schedule I substance. Kratom has been used by the peoples in East Asia for hundreds of years, and we have hundreds of thousands of anecdotal reports which support the relative safety of this plant. I personally use Kratom to help my Generalized Anxiety Disorder (GAD) and Manic Depressive Disorder (MDD). It provides me a boost of energy and greatly improves my mood in the evenings -- like a more pleasant cup of coffee.

I have been using this plant almost daily for 4 months. I have taken breaks here and there when I have noticed diminishing effects due to tolerance buildup. I have also never upped my dosage continuously to chase the high. I have received only benefits from Kratom's use. To categorize it as a substance with no medicinal value is a travesty and completely against the public's wishes, not to mention the fear-mongering is akin to the Reefer Madness of the last century. 

Do I need Kratom? No. Does it help with my conditions? Absolutely. However, there are those in the Kratom community who depend on it for its pain-killing effects due to chronic physical conditions, and weening off harder opiates like Heroin and Morphine. 

I urge you to reconsider your stance on Kratom and instead take steps in studying its pharmacology. In addition, a regulated market for Kratom similar to Cannabis would prevent less scrupulous vendors from spiking their product with extracts and synthetic opiods like O-Desmethyltramadol (found in 'Krypton').

Thank you for your time and consideration.

documents.commentText:
DEA,

I ask of you to please take a strong initiative to make an educated decision on the Kratom ban currently being discussed. Kratom has had an overwhelmingly positive effect on my life. I would like to give you a small insight on some of the areas it has helped me in. I am a current student that is taking 17 units and just finished taking 19 units in the spring of 2016. I am enrolled in very tough classes that require very much time, that of which I have very little due to my recent promotion to full time at my job where I work the graveyard shift. This means for very busy weeks that I have, and along with all of this I workout just about every other day because I am an athlete and I love fitness, that is what I am studying right now in school.  Another challenge I struggle with is C5-C6 disc herniation in my cervical spine that occurred from all my years of wrestling and football. This can be a very challenging injury since I have already had surgery on it once and do not want to have another surgery soon. The doctors prescribe me with high doses of pain killers to help ease the pain which bring on a whole host of side effects. This is one of the areas of my life Kratom has been life changing for it only results in the relief of pain which leaves me with an extremely enthusiastic state which in return helps me With the very busy schedule that I have. 
I also can use Kratom simply for a slight energy boost rather than multiple cups of coffee which most of my fellow classmates and coworkers do. They end up becoming addicted to it and needing more and more, which I dont with Kratom. In this area is where kratom and began to create major success in my life. Since discovering Kratom I am able to make it through those rough days where I have multiple tests stacked up. I never feel as though I need to have Kratom, it is simply just an extra boost that helps with my energy. With the help of Kratom I have been able to achieve straight As across the board in all my classes, I have been able to make extra money working longer hours at my job, also receiving many awards such as employee of the month. I have had extra motivation and time to spend towards my future which is to open my own gym which I am currently working on. I feel that enough has been said about me to get you to understand the benefits that Kratom has and could potentially have with millions of others. Just understand how big of an impact this would have if the Kratom Ban went through and I can assure that there are many others that feel this same way about Kratom. So I just urge you to take all considerations with an open mind about Kratom and please make an educated decision about the ban. My opinion is that Kratom should be readily available for competent adults to use for the multitude of benefits it brings them.

-Kyle

documents.commentText:
Hello,

My name is Jonathan Mintle, I'm 27 and work as Quality Control Manager for a laboratory in central Florida. I am writing to voice my opposition to the DEA's plan to place Kratom and it's active constituents mitragynine 7-hydroxymitragynine, two constituents of the kratom plant, schedule 1 controlled substances. 

This would put kratom -- a plant consumed safely in the U.S for decades and world-wide for millennia, and one that helps millions of people -- on the same level as illegal drugs like heroin. The DEA scheduling would also prevent further research which, to date, has shown the primary alkaloids in kratom to be beneficial without causing respiratory depression; the main cause of death from opiate overdose. 

I should start my story by mentioning that my father died from complications due to addiction from prescription pain medication, medication that he had a legitimate prescription for. So I have seen first hand how harmful prescription opiates can be, I have also experienced their dangers myself. I first started using Kratom about 2 years ago when I suffered a work injury that completely shattered my right knee. A large piece of faulty equipment struck my leg and incapacitated me for 6 months. I had a 7 inch plate and 13 screws implanted in my right knee. 

When the injury first happened I was forced to take pharmaceutical pain medication as it was a severe break and I was screaming out in pain. The relief from pain was effective, but the side effects were severe: nausea, constipation, profuse sweating, agitation and anger, intense sedation and even hair loss. And during my time of absolute NEED for these pills that I was legally prescribed by my surgeon: I grew dependent on them or the rebound pain I felt without them for a few days was horrible.

The worst part of this though, is where I nearly died in the hospital 2 days after my surgery. I was being given intravenous Dilaudid/hydromorphone and my breathing became so shallow that the doctors had to inject me with Narcan/naloxone, which is what is given to heroin users who overdose. I woke up immediately in agony, my back feeling like it was being snapped in 2, profusely sweating while simultaneously shivering and feeling all the pain in my leg from the lack of medication in my system. My first sight was my fianc and mother standing in front of me sobbing, watching me approach death and hoping that the doctors would be able to save me. 

Needless to say, this harrowing experience scared me so bad that I immediately started looking for alternatives. I found Kratom/mitragyna speciosa after extensive research online. I read hundreds of personal testimonies how it has helped opiate addicts cope with withdrawals and has helped people with everything from pain relief to depression to anxiety to low energy. Considering the fact that I have been prescribed Xanax for anxiety, Adderall for ADHD, all types of pills for depression and pain, I decided the simple leaf from a tree couldn't be any more harmful and it has changed my life.

I no longer take any sort of medication for pain, anxiety, depression or ADHD and instead opt for a few teaspoons of Kratom leaf every day. The side effects are negligible compared to the flurry of problems I experienced with pharmaceuticals, the main one being that I cannot have more than a single light beer when I consume any kratom at all. I get a guaranteed hangover the next day if the two are combined. I would say that's a deterrent enough, but when I take kratom I don't have the desire to drink or get a buzz in any way. It puts me in a good mood, gets rid of my pain, cures any anxiety I have and gives me the same energy that a cup of coffee gives me but without getting me jittery.

I believe that this miracle plant has a place in our great American society but that it should be respected. I propose legislation that monitors the sale of kratom and prevents sale to minors, but a complete ban and scheduling it Schedule 1 would make hundreds of thousands of Americans felons and would put a huge halt on any research being done on it. More thought needs to be put into scheduling Kratom and its active constituents on the Scheduled substances list as this plant without a doubt has valuable and numerous medicinal and therapeutic uses.

Please keep this amazing plant off the Scheduled Substances list and available for all autonomous adults.


Gratefully,

Jonathan Mintle

documents.commentText:
My name is Stacy Pickering. I am a 42yo Healthcare IT developer from Iowa.  I adamantly oppose the DEA's plan to put Kratom, a natural herb that has been used for hundreds if not thousands of years in Eastern medicine, as a Schedule 1 controlled substance.  There has been no proven research that Kratom is an addictive substance and in fact research in Israel showed that Kratom was an excellent means of helping people with severe opiate addiction get off  opiates completely and safely.  I completely support  doing more research into all the pluses and minuses of this herb and all herbs! 

For me personally, I have been a chronic pain patient since I was 12yo with Endometriosis and Interstitial Cystitis for the 1st 20 years and then Fibromyalgia diagnosis in 2004.  I had taken every anti-inflammatory, antidepressant, and narcotic that there is and the side effects were HORRIBLE and my symptoms just continue to get worse to the point that I missed so much work that I ended exhausting all my FMLA level and lost my job. A few months after that I found Kratom and I haven't felt this good in decades. Soon after my Mom and Sister, who also have Fibro and other conditions,  tried it will similar results. My sister is Bipolar and since she started taking Kratom, she has been able to lead a much more normal life having both her pain levels and mental state improved. The best part of all of this is there are no side effects from this all natural herb.  It is the only thing that has ever helped with the mental fogginess, poor concentration and continual exhaustion that have plagued all 3 of us thanks to Fibro. 

Kratom has been a godsend to my family by giving our children back active and happy parents. At the very least more research is needed to explore all of the possible benefits that this substance has to offer.  What if this herb can cure Multiple Sclerosis or Cancer?  

PLEASE do not classify Kratom as a Schedule 1 Controlled Substances when there is no evidence that this natural herb is anything harmful at all. This herb has given me my joy back and I do not want to go back to the days of being in so much pain and depression that I was essentially confined to bed.

This gave me my life back. I am back at the gym getting myself healthy again. I couldn't go to the gym on all those strong prescription painkillers. I might also add that being a full time student, the prescription painkillers made it incredibly difficult to get schoolwork accomplished, but using Kratom instead as my solution to back pain on the days it's at its worst, I've been able to maintain a 3.83 GPA in my courses and am near graduation. documents.commentText: Kratom is not a danger to the public.  It is a danger to the wallets of corporations which would like to keep their medical and economic stranglehold on the public, shilling medications that are demonstrably more dangerous than kratom (or marijuana, for that matter).  If the DEA acts to ban kratom, we who have minds will know that your service to the public is empty (a service to large corporations disguised as service to the public). I have a PhD myself (in the humanities rather than the sciences), and a friend who takes kratom and has a PhD in microbiology, which he uses to treat cancer.  Please find something better to do with your time than ban useful plants (useful to humanity, not useful to corporations that want to make money by holding the public hostage, keeping us dependent on their demonstrably more dangerous drugs).

documents.commentText:
I am writing to express my strong desire that the question of making Kratom a schedule 1 drug be put down. I am not one of the many people that have used Kratom to get off of opiates, or one of those that use it as a natural, non processed aid with physical pain. I am, however, an individual that has suffered from depression my whole life. I never wanted to take medication that might alter my natural creativity or much worse make me dependent on a drug. Many of the medications to combat depression create more problems than they help. I have a brother and a cousin that both committed suicide while on anti depressants. 

Kratom for me is a highly effective means of combating depression. I am able to use Kratom when needed to manage heavy emotions when they arise. I take a minimal dose of 1-1.5 teaspoons as needed maybe 1-3 times a week. I am energized and motivated once the effects kick in. Instead of slipping into a deep depression, as I may have years ago in these moments, a little Kratom is the difference between getting hopeful and motivated or spiraling into a potentially suicidal episode that could last for weeks. This small dose is beautifully motivating and energizing. My focus is increased and I am very productive.

I recommend Kratom to anyone suffering from depression, but I do caution that, like anything, you want to be careful not to overuse. 

Kratom is a natural unprocessed medicinal plant. Like any medicinal plant people should be informed of recommended doses and contraindications. This would help people use the plant more safely. 

If Kratom were to be made illegal, it would be deeply disappointing to a person like myself that uses it responsibly and with extraordinary benefit to my life and productivity. It deserves more research not to be locked away from the public. Alcohol, tobacco, prescription meds are dangerous far more so than this plant that has the power to be so beneficial to mental health and wellness for people like myself.

Thank you for your time and efforts,
Nailah Heckerman
documents.docketTitle: Schedules of Controlled Substances:  Temporary Placement of Mitragynine and 7-Hydroxymitragynine into Schedule I
documents.title: Comment on FR Doc # 2016-24659

documents.commentText: I understand the motivation to assign Kratom as a schedule 1 substance. After all it is a substance that has been associated with death. However the key word here is associated. Quoting from the DEA site, "DEA is aware of 15 kratom-related deaths between 2014 and 2016". However the DEA also note that 14  of which also involved other potentially lethal drugs. Therefore     , further investigation is needed to understand the true dangers of the substance. Yet for there to be be studies done on the substance, the agency should wait to assign Kratom as schedule 1. I worry about the public's reaction if the agency does not be patient. Since there are far more deaths from alcohol and cancer from cigarettes than the 15 from 2014 to 2016, the public would not understand why Kratom would be banned whereas alcohol and cigarettes are not. Time and research is needed to understand the true nature of the substances and what benefits/dangers it carries. Before that is done, I recommend the agency warn the public about the potential dangers of the substance but wait on the scheduling.

documents.commentText: Kratom is a leaf. A leaf that is related to the coffee plant. It is about as powerful as coffee, but without the addictive qualities of caffeine. I have read erroneous stories about withdrawal, and addiction etc. but I can tell you that stories like that do not come from people who are using plain Kratom leaf. I have used Kratom medicinally for over 5 years, to combat depression and anxiety. Much like a person using caffeine as an alertness aide, I am using this natural leaf to take the edge off of my anxiety. It does not cure my anxiety, or remove it completely, however it does provide relief. Kratom provides the kind of relief you would expect from a natural plant used medicinally. Occasional recreational use, I can see that. I can see wanting to grab that sense of well-being that it can provide. A mild, often undetectable in some, sense of general well-being is all this plant has the capability to provide. It does have analgesic properties, and falls into the same category as using oatmeal on a sunburn. It is a natural home remedy, that provides relief to sufferers of pain and anxiety with no addictive qualities, no behavior changes, and no side effects. Again, the stories about such things are not from users of this plain leaf. It simply does not have those qualities, or capabilities and the science that is surely to come will bear that out. As a person who has relied on this leaf for the past 5+ years I can tell you straight out that there is no addictive property beyond that of a mental one, similar to chewing gum when one is nervous. It does not withdraw, and it is not necessary to increase the quantity endlessly chasing a 'high.' This is just not that kind of leaf. It is not something people smoke, it is well known that the plant is most effective when ingested. People are not shooting it in their veins. Kratom does not cause car crashes, or violence. For the life of me I cannot imagine how an effort to ban this leaf has gotten this far. People are selling all kinds of harmful things on the internet, but to ban a harmless substance in an effort to curb the misdeeds of online scammers is not a viable solution. Spend your time going after people selling things that are not what they say it is, by all means. People mix all kinds of things together and create something dangerous but we don't ban the whole recipe. This effort to ban Kratom represents a needless infliction of pain on people who find relief from this leaf. An effort to create more prisoners, perhaps? Whatever the goal is here, it is not public safety. Nobody has ever died from JUST kratom - period, full stop. It is nonsense to try and convince the public otherwise, and again, science will bring to light the true capabilities of this plant and it will be easy to see that this effort to ban Kratom is about something other than safety. People can use this plant to ween off of dangerous opiates, people can use this to REPLACE opiates in many cases. Clearly in the midst of an opiate epidemic in this country, anything that is effective at alleviating that should be distributed freely, not made illegal. As for making this plant a schedule I substance, there is obviously no justification for that, just as there was no reason to make marijuana schedule I. This is the same type of effort, and it is easy to see. I am making my statement anonymously, because I don't trust that I won't be targeted if the DEA/Big Pharma plan succeeds and possession of this harmless leaf becomes subject to a federal prison sentence. This leaf is competition to the opiates peddled by big pharma and that is the only reason it is even being considered for a ban. That is plain for all to see.  People use this leaf to get off of, or stay away from opiates and so in the interest of public safety this ban should be taken off the table completely. Please do not ban this beneficial, harmless leaf.

documents.commentText:
I am writing to oppose the proposed ban on Kratom, or more specifically the move for it to be set as a schedule I drug. I myself have fibromyalgia, a disease which keeps me in significant pain most days. It is through the patient community that I learned of Kratom, as a medicine that can be used to alleviate the symptoms of this illness, and many other illnesses in which chronic pain and depression are a component.

It is sad to me to think that, if this law is passed, many Americans could be taken out of their homes, away from their families, and thrown in jail. And for what ill against society are they guilty? Of trying to treat their pain and depression with a plant God gave us. That to me goes against the very idea of individual freedom upon which is said to be a founding principle of the United States. Not to mention it's just plain, ethically, wrong.

A better solution would be to invest in regulation and mental health resources.
If people really have a health problem, the answer is NOT to discard them by throwing them in jail and out of society.
No, the answer is to help them. This should be obvious!

The proposed move would certainly do more harm than good. It could put many patients back into great suffering from which they have received some relief from due to this plant's medicinal properties. It could drive people to seek out pharmaceutical opioids. While that's great for pharmaceutical companies' profits, these drugs are known to be FAR, FAR more dangerous than Kratom! This is a known fact and has even been stated clearly by ruling government agency heads. And worst of all, this move would lead to government agents spending their time arresting sick people. How sick is that!? Not to mention the taxpayer dollars that will be spent arresting these people, handling their court cases and putting them through the justice system, and then keeping them in jail, and perhaps paying for parole services after jail. What a waste. I don't want my taxpayer money spent in that way.

I'd rather our taxes be spent investing in resources to help people who are suffering, rather than trying to punish them further. The war on drugs has done far too much damage to the lives of individuals and communities. Enough is enough. 

Oh, and don't forget the many people who have used Kratom to get off an addiction to pharmaceutical opioids. That means they are actually improving their overall health, by lowering their total risk. Is this not a good thing? Well, if you are invested in a pharmaceutical company which is losing sales revenue from opioids it might not be, but for actual people who are struggling to live well each day, it can make all the difference in the world.

documents.commentText:
I am a 28 year old pharmacist and practice in the Southwest part of the US. As a healthcare provider, I have seen every type of individual come into my pharmacy. I have patients who are honest, who lie, and ones who don't know what they are getting into when they start taking prescription painkillers. In the month of October I had 5 patients come ask me what is the best thing for withdrawals from Oxycodone and related medications because they took to much of their Rx and the MD wouldn't up the dose or kicked them out of their program. It hurts me to seem them like that, even if they, themselves, got into that situation. I know Kratom would help them immensely  

As for me, I have been in the field of pharmacy for 3 years now and I stand for 8+ hours a day. I don't get breaks, I don't get to sit down, and I am constantly running around. I found Kratom because the pain in my legs became something out of a horror movie. I would wake up in the middle of the night with horrible shin splints and aches that would cause me to tear up. During my longer shifts (12-14 hours) you can most likely see me on video wincing and moving my legs around as much as possible. I have very little experience with prescription painkillers. One time for wisdom teeth and another when I had a testicle infection and taking those pills made me weird so I at least have something to compare to. 

I have taken Kratom everyday now for 2.5 years and I have yet to have a side effect beyond nausea. That nausea was brought upon when I accidentally took a Tbs instead of a tsp. It lasted for 1 hour and was not fun but compared to the nausea I have gotten from binge drinking in college, it was a walk in the park. I can honestly say that I never felt like I was getting away with anything when I take Kratom. It was a part of my routine and involved, for me, complete relief from any leg pains after a long day at work. I should also note I have only used one reputable company for the product and it has never been an issue. 

Overall, banning this product would be a very bad idea. It has potential to be something that a lot of people can take advantage of if they are considering alternative therapies. As a pharmacist, I would never put something in my body that could hurt me, pharmacodynamically. I understand the mechanism of action, its potential side effects and drug interactions so for me, it was a no-brainer to try it. I have immense success with Kratom and with two and a half years of usage under my belt and no side effects worse then nausea I can say it works for me. Of course we need to study it and make sure it isn't dangerous in unknown populations.

I am a mother to two young children, wife of a veteran, college graduate, and accountant. But i also suffer from anxiety and degenerative disc disease. If you have never had a panic attack consider yourself lucky. One minute you are fine and out of nowhere and for no reason it strikes. It starts in your feet, this warm sensation working it's way to the top of your head. Then your heart starts to repeatedly skip beats. Your hands start to shake uncontrollably. You get tunnel vision and you can't breath. It feels as though someone has punched you in the stomach while sitting on your chest. And this is all happening while your just standing in a store, or the middle of a staff meeting with your whole firm, or driving down the interstate with your children in the car. 
 I have tried every medication possible for both conditions but everything i tried left me feeling void of emotion, dazed, lethargic, nauseous, and useless. That is until i found kratom. I have quit taking any pain medication for the degenerative disc other than Tylenol and only take a low dose of Trazadone for the hand tremors caused by the anxiety. I have not felt this free in years. I am able to play with my kids without pain, go into any social or stressful situation without having a panic attack.
This herb has given me life back, my children their mother, my husband his wife. A plant. 
All the pharmaceuticals and doctors have done nothing but made my life worse, and this simple herb, a plant, has made it better than ever.

documents.commentText: To start out I am a hardworking member of society, I am a follower of Jesus, a dedicated husband and father. I am not a drug addict and never have been. I began using Kratom approximately 10 years ago. I suffered from anxiety and mild depression. Once I found Kratom I was able to push aside the anxiety and depression completely making my daily life much more enjoyable. I had tried a number of different prescription depression medications such as Zoloft and Lexapro. I hated everything about them, I felt like a zombie with no emotions so I stopped taking them and started drinking Kratom tea. I don't have any strange side effects while taking kratom and I can't possibly see how someone could become addicted to it. In my opinion it is like any other supplement a person would use daily after realizing their benefits such as protein shakes, green tea, multi-vitamins, fish oil pills, etc. Just because I use it daily doesn't mean I couldn't stop easily which I have done multiple times over the years just to ensure this. I can also attest to the pain relieving properties of this herb. Approximately 2 years ago I was in a accident that left me with broken ribs, a broken nose and  fractured cheek bone. I received the pain medication prescribed by my doctor and after taking it for 2 days I realized it was having no effect, it made my skin itch and made me irritable. I had also stopped taking kratom at the time to ensure there would be no interaction with the medication. I quit taking the pain medication and started drinking my tea again and immediately the pain was not only tolerable but almost non existent. I can definitely see how the pain relieving properties of Kratom could prove beneficial against taking what are known to be highly addictive pain medications. I have talked to my doctor about Kratom tea and have actually done blood work to make sure my body was not suffering any ill effects from the herb. Aside from the earthy bitter taste of the tea I have yet to encounter any negative mental or physical issues from it. documents.commentText:
Pain is a way of life for the 100 million+ chronic pain sufferers in America and with the growing dependency on prescription opioids for pain, addiction rates continue to skyrocket. I am both a chronic pain sufferer and a recovered opiate addict. Yes, I say recovered, because I truly believe I will never struggle with addiction to opiates again, thanks to Kratom. 

Even with the problems and dangers of prescription pain medicines aside, OTC pain medications can be harmful and deadly, too. Acetaminophen (generic for Tylenol) is responsible for well over 56,000 emergency room visits a year and countless deaths. So people want better, safer alternatives with few or no side effects that work to help relieve pain by giving a general overall sense of health and well-being. All without having to take a handful of pills every few hours or adjusting daily life to accommodate heavy side effects.

I found Kratom after spending nearly a decade sick and scared, in and out of doctors offices identifying and attempting to treat, my late stage Lyme Disease. Countless appointments with specialists, led to countless prescriptions (mostly heavy painkillers), little relief, and turned me into a person I didnt recognize. Here I was in my mid-thirties, when all my friends were marrying and having kids, a once successful non-profit campaign director with a masters degree, a once accomplished hiker and mountaineer, now bedridden and zombie-like, relying on my parents to care for me.

I became addicted to opiates and was willing to try just about anything to help me when someone in my Lyme Disease support group led me to Kratom. I started taking Kratom daily over 2.5 years ago --in the form of dried, powdered leaves in tea and dietary supplements -- and it started giving me my life back.

The FDA and DEA would have you believe Kratom is a new street drug causing an epidemic of fatalities (when there have been none tied directly to Kratom world-wide since it does not cause respiratory depression) with no medical use in the U.S., Yet Kratom  leaves have a long history of safe, medicinal use (all the way back to the 1830's). 

There has been a small problem with "adulterated" Kratom products around the world; a problem that does need to be addressed and can be done so by regulating Kratom as any other dietary supplement is regulated, requiring tests for consumer safety.  Responsible  Kratom consumers do not support these adulterated Kratom concoctions or the deceptive marketing techniques being used to sell them. Further, safe, responsible users believe Kratom should be regulated for minors, similar to how  tobacco is.

If you discovered someone adulterating chamomile tea (or any of the hundreds of herbal plant teas used by many generations for a variety of medicinal needs) and marketing it as a way to feel high, would you prohibit the sale of all chamomile products? No, youd go after the people doing it. Rather than make Kratom a scheduled substance, turning approximately 3 to 5 million consumers into felons, why not go after the people, the criminals who are turning the natural Kratom plant that's providing millions of Americans with safe, natural relief into something dangerous? 

This lack of understanding and recognition of this significant distinction (the Kratom plant, vs. adulterated Kratom products) has led to regulatory efforts by misguided, but well intentioned legislators in several states.

It's my mission and the mission of the American Kratom Association, a non-profit organization that represents the majority of the 3-5 million Kratom consumers in the U.S.  who use teas and products with the natural Kratom plant responsibly, to bring out the facts and the science about the Kratom plant. Rather tthan try to do that myself here, several scientists and our law firm will provide these to you during this public comment period. 

Kratom consumers are nurses, teachers, construction workers, police officers, lawyers, chefs, moms and dads who have found a natural way help alleviate the symptoms of many chronic conditions like pain, fatigue, depression, anxiety, fibromyalgia, and my very own Lyme disease. Its returned us to jobs and families and to life itself. It is by no means a treatment or a cure, but it provides us with a general sense of health and well-being that allows us to be productive members of society. 

I urge you to consider all of the facts before taking action to prohibit responsible Kratom use and research into a plant that could help the opiate epidemic.

documents.commentText:
My name is Adam and I am a 38 year-old resident of Montgomery County PA. I am writing to ask you to please reconsider your efforts to schedule the alkaloids found in the Kratom plant, effectively making it illegal.

I was diagnosed with firbomyalgia and depression, which often go hand-in-hand, about 15 years ago. I suffered from chronic back pain, sleeplessness, anxiety and other symptoms and was prescribed pain relievers, muscle relaxers and benzodiazepines, none of which were effective long-term treatments. About 10 years ago an accident left me with a herniated disc in my back and I was taking prescribed opiate medications for a year which was very difficult to stop. 

I have had chronic pain nearly my entire adult life but since I discovered Kratom I have been happier than I can ever remember and comparatively pain-free. I have also stopped seeking out prescription medications for these conditions. Professionally, I work in Information Technology and have received several promotions during this time.

Sadly, I have seen this natural plant sensationalized by the media, comparing it to synthetic drugs, which, when used in its natural form, could not be further from the truth. Based on my personal experience, and what I have read of others, I do not feel that Kratom is any more dangerous than caffeine, and certainly less so than alcohol, tobacco, or prescription medications. 

I feel the pursuit of scheduling the compounds found in this plant is not in line with public opinion, common sense, or the scientific literature and that we should be doing all we can to research alternatives to the pharmaceutical epidemic in our country instead of taking actions to impede such research.

Please keep Kratom legal for upstanding, responsible, adult Americans.

documents.commentText:
Banning kratom expands the war on drugs, while the public overwhelmingly supports ending it.
If kratom is added to any one of the five drug schedules, people who use it will be criminalized and locked up behind bars.
Kratom has been used safely by millions of people in the U.S. and evidence supports kratom's potential as a pain reliever and opioid replacement.
Many people struggling with opioid addiction have turned to kratom to help them cut back or quit, but now all promising scientific studies on kratom's role in opioid treatment could be immediately shut down.
Side effects of kratom are minimal, and its withdrawal symptoms are weak and nearly inconsequential compared to the suffering of people trying to quit opioids.
Prohibiting kratom will worsen the country's problems of opioid addiction and overdose.

documents.commentText: On August 31st the DEA filed a Notice of Intent to place the active compounds in a plant called Kratom, Mitragynine and 7-Hydroxymitragynine, into Schedule I effective September 30. I know it may not seem like a big deal to you, but it's a huge deal for me. I have a disease called Ankylosing Spondylitis. It's a seronegative autoimmune spondyloarthropathic disease that makes your joints (primarily the spinal joints) become inflamed pretty much constantly, which eventually can cause the growth of excess bone and random fusions. I have been afflicted by this disease in some form or another since I was around 13 years old; I am now going on 36. I've had 21 spinal procedures, some of which were fusions to break and correctly reset the fusions the spine did on its own. I've tried to hide how much it has progressed but it's gotten to the point that I really can't anymore. The past few years have marked a sharp decline in my mobility and my quality of life in general. Part of my sternum is fused in place now by the disease, making breathing sometimes difficult and painful. Two of my bottom ribs in the back have fused together, which also doesn't help with the breathing thing and twisting around in certain positions is literally impossible. Over the past few years I've had increasing degeneration in pretty much every major large joint (hips, knees, shoulders, etc.) that is incredibly painful - painful as in I don't even know how to tell people the type of pain I deal with on a daily basis - and it doesn't stop. The hip involvement sometimes incapacitates me - I spend days on end more or less bedridden (luckily I work from home) and miserable. This past year the disease has kicked itself into overdrive - I've been suffering compression fractures in my spine, the discs in my jaw (I didn't even know you HAD discs in your jaw!!) have become involved making it difficult to open my mouth to speak or eat. At a random benign eye doctor appointment to get new glasses it was discovered that the disease has also affected my eyes with a fun round of Keratitis Sicca and Uveitis. I've tried very hard to hide the pain, but it came to a culmination during a series of steroid injections in my spine earlier this year - one of the compression fractures became super inflamed (you know, the *opposite* of what was supposed to happen) and made pretty much any type of movement excruciating. I've been through well over 2 decades of pain management, physical therapy, surgeries, experimental treatments, meds, compounds, biologic medications, holistic treatments, reiki, yoga - you name it, I've likely tried it, and it likely either failed or it is an opiate or a narcotic which is near impossible to have an enduring prescription of where I live. In an hour of desperation I was reading one of the AS support group message boards I frequent when the subject of Kratom came up. The more I read, the more I was convinced these people were insane. I was in so much pain, I was bordering suicide just to stop it. I was at the point that I couldn't take the pain anymore - so I figured "Hey, might as well make one last attempt before I throw myself in front of a train." I researched Kratom vendors to make sure they were legitimate and strains of the plant, selected a couple of little pouches of powdered leaves and ordered. When the pouches arrived I gulped down a teaspoonful and watched the clock. As the minutes ticked by I felt that I'd been had, then gradually I felt a calmness I hadn't known in ages. I bent down to pick something up off of the floor and realized... There was no pain. None. I started crying - full on sobbing. I didn't remember what it felt like to *not* be afraid of moving, of taking a breath... Of LIVING. I wasn't stoned and spacey like with MJ, I wasn't launched into the ether like with Percocet, I wasn't throwing up uncontrollably like with Vicodin. I could think clearly, I could move - I could FUNCTION. I played with different strains and dosages to find one that works for me, and I've slowly been learning how to live again. I had this life taken from me, and I never thought this could be my reality again. While I know this is in no way a cure, it has enabled me to function like a normal human being - something I haven't done in years. I went from crying in bed for days, watching endless TV, popping pills and getting painful spine injections to... now. I ran 2.8 miles Wednesday. Thursday I ran 2.5 miles.  Friday I hit a summit at 3.15 miles. I scrubbed my floors, did my dishes, built contraptions to keep cats out of the bookshelves, dusted all of the said book shelves and I have begun rearranging the bathroom - and that's just last week alone. So please - I know I'm only one case, but there are many, many people like me.

documents.commentText: Kratom helped my mother get her life back. She had been in and out of rehab struggling with her OxyContin addiction. Within 4 months she had gotten completely off of OxyContin, and still uses it to manage her pain. I feel as if she is a new woman, and I wish she had found it years ago. I can not believe a plant that has changed so many lives for the better would even be considered being illegal. Please do not take this chance for a better life away from the people who need it.

documents.commentText:
Now is not the time to ban kratom as the American public now believes the War on Drugs has been a failure.  Nothing will be gained by criminalizing the people who use it, while their lives will be devastated by being treated as criminals.
Kratom has been used safely by numerous people in the U.S. and evidence supports kratom's potential as a pain reliever and opioid replacement.
Many people struggling with opioid addiction have turned to kratom to help them cut back or quit, but if you criminalize it then all promising scientific studies on kratom's role in opioid treatment would be shut down.
Side effects of kratom are minimal, and its withdrawal symptoms are weak and nearly inconsequential compared to the suffering of people trying to quit opioids.
Prohibiting kratom will worsen the country's problems of opioid addiction and overdose.

documents.commentText: I would just like to add my input as somebody who has dealt with hard to diagnose and hard to treat but very real chronic pain all of my adult life. I would like to see Kratom remain legal and be taken seriously in terms of research into its efficacy as a pain reliever. I am a person in long term recovery from drugs and alcohol, and while I have never taken Kratom up to this point nor would I without serious contemplation, I am very much interested in finding effective relief from my chronic pain without resorting to actual opiate pharmaceuticals or anything else that is physically habit-forming. I just think that the more options which are available to people, the greater number of people can experience relief from their various symptoms, given that different people respond to different drugs in different ways. For example, I feel as though I could safely utilize marijuana in a medical context but I personally find the side effects too unpleasant  so I probably wouldn't go that route even if it were available to me, but I heard about Kratom and from the description it sounds like it could be a safe and effective treatment for my chronic pain. I appreciate this forum and hope that the decision would not be made lightly to criminalize Kratom until much more research can be done, because I've heard that once done this is very hard to undo. Thank you very much!

documents.commentText: I would like to take this opportunity to reach out to the members of the DEA , as well as all others associated with regards to the status of Kratom.  I've been making tea with this great herb for approximately 5 years now.  I have done extensive research on it,  and would never consume anything that wasn't pure and mild on the body.  My friends actually refer to me as  "The most O.C.D person they've ever met" due to the fact that i'm such a naturalist when it comes to plants, and staunchly opposed to harmful substances of all kinds.  I can tell you that Kratom is most definitely helpful without the menace of ill-health or addiction. It made me furious to hear that some vendors are tainting the plant matter with things like caffeine,  ephedrine, and God knows what else - giving it a bad reputation. The main reason I enjoy Kratom so much is that it doesn't get you "high" in the least,  due to the fact that the opioid-receptor agonist properties are no more potent than that of peppermint,  coffee,  green tea,  or even myrrh,  as well as no risk of overdose. It's a very impressive plant on it's own,  and is very safe in it's pure form.  Please reconsider any ban on it,  and I would greatly support an FDA regulation to ensure that no more crooked vendors are allowed to poison it with rogue chemicals.  Many, many people would be greatly appreciative for that,  and it would re-motivate a lot of people to be appreciative of our natural freedom in the U.S.   -Thank you very much for taking the time to read this statement.                           Cordially,  Chadwick Rogers.

documents.commentText:
Kratom has changed my life.  Before I was introduced to Kratom, I lived in near constant pain.  I serve lower back disk degeneration, spina bifida that went undiagnosed until 2012, ankylosing spondylitis, arthritis and bone spur growths on my L3-L5 vertebrae as well as sacralization of my L5-S1 (this is where the bones fuse together over a long period of time).  For a really long time I was a lot of pain and no one could tell me what was wrong with me. Using the pain scale that is popular with doctors and hospitals I lived with a constant 5 pain level everyday, and that was AFTER taking more medication then I should have been taking.  I was told that it was weight related, that I needed to be more active, to take tylenol and ibuprofen - lemme tell ya nothing worked.  I was never allowed to actually take any sort of narcotics because I have a major depressive disorder and narcotics are like candy to people like.  They spin you up and get you really high without actually taking all of your pain away.  And...of course...I went through a period time where I was very resentful of people who could take narcos.  So jealous in fact that I started stealing my friends medication to take and got myself in a lot of trouble.  
I sought rehab, went to group therapy and went back to taking aleve and motrin and praying that it would help the pain and nothing did.

Then my friend told me about Kratom.  She helped me get my first couple of samples and I couldn't believe it.  It took a day or so to kick in but I woke up and had not pain for the first time since my early 20s.  I mean, like seriously 15 years.  I walked to take my bus, walked the mile to my job, pain free.  And the next day was the same.  And the next, and so on.  Now I don't know what I would do.  I really just can't see myself having to go back to being in as much pain as I was in.  There isn't a procedure that is going to help me, nor will physical therapy.  I've done physical therapy, I've looked into it all and I literally just have to live with it for the rest of my life.  If I don't have the ability to take Kratom to assist with my pain, my quality of life will be severely diminished.  I'm getting to point in my age and disease that I will have to start looking for some aids to help with walking long distances (which is something I do everyday since I have to take the bus and walk to get to work).  
Please, reconsider putting Kratom on the schedule.  Also consider removed Marijuana.  Nature was intended to help mankind.  Kratom helps so many people get off narcotics and heroin, it would be travesty in the face of the opioid epidemic to take away something that helps so many people avoid overdose and death and improves their quality of life.  
Thank you for considering this.

documents.commentText:
Kratom holds great promise as a step-down from opioid addiction. It has low abuse potential with likely efficacy as a supplement/medication for anxiety and pain control. It should not be scheduled in such a way that access is limited. It should be carefully studied in a wide variety of settings with Chronic Pain, PTSD and SUD populations. If it were a drug manufactured by a pharmaceutical manufacturer it would be rapidly approved for use and probably not be scheduled at all.
Furthermore if it is scheduled: 1. research into it's uses would decrease and 2. an illicit market would soon develop, the price would go up, and as distribution systems were set up by smugglers, read cartels, it would be "marketed" on the streets and on school yards and competition between distribution systems would undoubtedly result in increasingly stronger formulations that would inevitably result in the addition of powerful and dangerous contaminants such as what we are now seeing with opioids/heroin and cathinones.
If the DEA wishes to minimize the feared "dangers" of these compounds it should NOT establish conditions in which huge sums of money can be made by skirting the prohibition scheduling would certainly assure.

documents.commentText:
I am a 40 year old counselor with a specialization in addiction. I am also the victim of a drunk driver. A drunk driver hit my car head-on at 45 MPH. As a result, i have long term severe chronic pain resulting from my injuries. For many years, I was prescribed strong opiates including a fentanyl patch supplemented by 6-12 norco per day. It struck me, while working closely with heroin and opiate addicts, that the same medications I was prescribed legitimately, were killing people. So, I took actions to taper off of these medications. I felt like a hypocrite using medications that were killing my clients. I took nothing but ibuprofen for nearly a year before I heard about Kratom. I was still experiencing severe pain, that ibuprofen only took the edge off of. I have been pleasantly surprised by the results. My pain has been under better control than when I was on the narcotics. However, I never feel high or 'out of it.' Kratom has been an immense help in coping with my medical issues. I also believe that I should be the person who decides what goes in to my body. I am well educated and don't feel that the government should decide for me, what I put in to my body. Please do not schedule Kratom. I do not want to return to prescription medications to manage my pain. I am gainfully employed and would hate to be unable to work due to my pain. Kratom works and presents no imminent risk to those who utilize this plant. 

Thank you,
