documents.commentText:
I am commenting on the DEA's proposed rule of controlled substances: Placement of Mitragynine and 7-Hydroxymitragynine into Schedule 1 status. 

My name is Katie, and I am a 36 year old IT Professional from Ohio. I am one of millions of average Americans who go to work, pay taxes, and contribute to my community. I have also used Mitragynine, aka kratom, many times.

A little less than a year ago, I damaged the sciatic nerve in my right leg. After developing a dependence on legally prescribed painkillers for a similar injury several years before, I had no desire to subject myself to the mind-numbing effects and subsequent withdrawal from them again. After searching for a possible route to alleviate the intense pain I was experiencing, I stumbled onto an online forum talking about kratom.

Dubious, I nevertheless decided to order a sample and see if it did what other users described. Imagine my surprise when after one dose I was finally able to sit without pain. I could make it through a day at work without having to get out of my chair and walk around every 15 minutes. I could drive without crying. For the next six months, while my leg healed, I continued to use kratom in order to help me get through each day. 

I bought some for my father, who has similar leg and back issues. Exactly as it had for me, it allowed him to continue to live his life with minimal interruption. It turned chronic, debilitating pain into something manageable. And, most importantly, we were both able to stop using it with no withdrawal effects whatsoever once the pain was gone.

I understand the purpose of the DEA is to protect the American people from the harmful effects of illicit and illegal substances. However, before that happens, I would like to know that due diligence has been paid to determine what--if any--those are, and to ensure all the potentially helpful effects have been discovered as well. Without further study and classification of this family of plants, there is no call for putting something that helps millions of people into the same category as drugs that harm or even kill. Making kratom a schedule 1 substance before it can be properly studied and evaluated is not only irresponsible, it needlessly harms thousands of users in this country who use it responsibly. That is why I urge the DEA and the rest of the United States Government to reconsider scheduling these substances, and instead to pursue the action of study to determine what, if any, the short- and long-term effects might be, and then and only then to take action if necessary. 

Thank you for reading my comment.

documents.commentText:
1) If kratom is prohibited, it will immediately give power to those who are willing to profit from selling it illegally.  How concerned do you think the drug dealers will be about ensuring the safety of their product? Due to the inevitable lack of regulation, prohibiting kratom will worsen the country's problems of opioid addiction and overdose.  Kratom should be legally regulated, allowing for quality control measures and product labeling requirements.

2) Otherwise law-abiding citizens who use it (for relief from physical and emotional issues) will be criminalized and locked up behind bars.  Kratom has been used safely by millions of people in the U.S. and evidence supports kratom's potential as a pain reliever and opioid replacement.

3) What the government doesn't seem to understand is that a drug which is made illegal becomes MORE affordable, MORE available, and MORE enticing to those who, due to poverty and lack of education, struggle to make good decisions for themselves. Banning kratom expands the war on drugs, while the public overwhelmingly supports ending it.

documents.commentText:
My entire life I have dealt with chronic pain. As I child I cried myself to sleep almost nightly and the many doctors I went to could only tell my parents I had "growing pains". At 16 I was started on Darvaset after no other medications helped the constant pain. I tried sports and dance hoping exercise could help, but I got injured too frequently and just could not keep up with the other kids. So, I used my time on schoolwork and learning graduated both high school and college with a 3.6 gpa earning a Bachelors Degree in Biology and then went back to get a second bachelors in Secondary Education. I became a high school Biology teacher got married, had a family, and went on to earn a 3.98 gpa in my Masters Degree Program in Environmental Education. I taught for 5 years but eventually had to leave my job because the pain was getting worse all the time and I could barely make it through the day and missed many days due to illness and complete and total exhaustion and fatigue. I am now a 35 year old woman with 3 children and just want to give my kids the best life that I can as a stay at home mother. Through the years I saw many different doctors and specialists and was diagnosed with many things, such as Lupus, Fibromyalgia, Degenerative Disc Disease, and more. My narcotic medication needs grew and grew until 5 years ago I was on the strongest fentanyl patch available and Nucynta as break through medication. My life was nothing but laying around feeling out of it. I was basically dead at 30 and my children were unable to enjoy so many things kids should because I was unable to leave the house most days. 

After 2 years of fentanyl, I couldn't take it anymore. I found out about Kratom after researching alternative therapies and herbs for pain control and decided to give it a try. It has given me my life back. I slowly got off of fentanyl and went down to a low dose Nucynta that lasts all day. I can play with my kids, do things with them outside of the house, go to the grocery store, and I can clean my house again without becoming completely drained! During the time period that I was getting myself off of fentynal I also saw a new doctor who sent me to the Genetic Diseases Department at The Cleveland Clinic with a hunch he knew what was wrong with me. After visiting with a geneticist and genetic testing I was finally diagnosed with Ehlers Danlos Syndrome, a genetic connective tissue disorder that is degenerative and at this time is only managed through symptom control. I know I will continue to get worse and will lose a lot of mobility, so I want to enjoy every minute I can. I now have braces to stabilize the joints in my hands, back, and ankles and have had 2 surgeries since my diagnosis, and will need more in the future. I still have bad days and my pain will never be completely gone, but Kratom has saved my life so I can live it and saved the memories my children will grow up with. I have never had any of the awful side effects I did when on all the prescriptions over the years, but I cannot stress enough that I have NEVER EVER experienced a "high" as I did with opiods, and cannot imagine Kratom could ever become an issue and abused for non-medicinal purposes. Please don't take away what could be a shinning light in helping chronic pain sufferers and a real hope for decreasing opiod use and fighting this epidemic. I know we need something to help fight against drug abuse and use for non medically necessary purposes, and I don't think it's fair to be punished for that abuse by losing Kratom, an amazing herbal remedy. I also hate having to jump through hoops to get my monthly prescription for the Nucynta I still take. I will need opiods to help me for the rest of my life and I hate seeing what this war on drugs is doing to all the real chronic pain sufferers. We have to be important too, and matter just as much as the abusers that are creating the problems! The last year has definitely made me feel like my government has chosen the abusers who don't follow the laws, over me and I have been left behind to struggle to be physically able to get my medications and am now constantly treated with suspicion.

I fear what will happen to me. Without Kratom I'll be back to my life of not living due to heavy prescription narcotics, or be paralyzed from pain and fatigue. What choice is that? What kind of mother is that for my girls? I'm not a drug addict, I just want to be able to be close to normal and experience my life. Please fight for my family and fight for every pain sufferer like me who doesn't want to be high, just desperately wants to live! I have fought for so long for my life to matter, to be full of love and learning, and to give something back as much as possible. Now, I need someone to fight for me and to prove I am important, my suffering and pain is important, and my government supports me so I can live my best life even though I'm not a drug abuser, illegal user, or a criminal. Please hear me.

documents.commentText:
I am a licensed attorney, an expert in immigration law and policy, and a regular kratom consumer. I appreciate the DEA's willingness to reconsider its "emergency" classification of kratom, and this opportunity to share what kratom has done for my life.

I was formally diagnosed with anxiety and depression eleven years ago, and social anxiety has dominated my personal and professional lives for as long as I can remember. It is not "shyness," or necessarily even an indicator of introversion. It is a very specific reaction to social stimuli. For me, it manifestsreliably, almost every timeeither in loud, crowded rooms or at any time in which people (especially strangers) are raising their voices in my direction. My heart races, my voice doesn't work, and my flight instincts take over. Even after ten years as a practicing attorney, it can still strike anytime there are other people around, for nearly any reason.

I spent the next eleven years after my diagnosis dedicating myself to a legal career, and the balance of that time building the solo law practice (now a three-attorney firm) which I still run today. On paper, my day-to-day sounds like a social anxiety nightmare: regular court appearances, lengthy client meetings, managing staff and attorneys, and spending far more time than I would prefer on the phone with strangers. And it can be, even for as much as I have learned to manage and mitigate the worst of it while getting results for hundreds of clients.

Kratom both stimulates and gently relaxes my mind and body in a very specific way which leaves me more engaged and attentive to the people around me. It helps me to let go of the constant internal battles which anxiety otherwise create for me so that I can truly be in the social moment in a way that I have never experienced before. (And not in the loose, fuzzy, careless way that drinkers or cannabis enthusiasts know, but with myself fully intact and operating with a near-perfect lucidity and precision of language.) In short, it does everything for me that prescription anxiety medication promises consumers with none of the side effectsup to and including physical and mental dependence. I routinely go three or four days without consuming kratom with no noticeable physical or mental side effects. 

I informed my doctor at my annual physical in October that I had started using moderate amounts of kratom to curb my anxiety. He certainly would have been within his rights to give me a stern warning about the dangers of buying exotic, unregulated powders from the Internet... but he just nodded. He told me that he had only just recently looked into it after a few patients had asked, but that from what he understood I was not taking any risks with my health so long as I continued to responsibly consume in moderation and without mixing it with other substances.

And he was right. I have been in good health for the past year; no mystery ailments. I had a round of blood tests (including a liver checkup) done in October after a year of semi-regular kratom use and everything came back healthy.

If the DEA pushes forward with this historic mistake, I will lose something which has demonstrably improved my quality of life. But I lived without kratom for 35 years, and if it comes down to risking federal prison or finding other ways to cope with social anxiety I know that I can live without the additional benefits of kratom.

Far more than for myself, I am concerned for those who have been able to manage chronic pain and overcome their opioid dependence with the help of this amazing plant. It is kratom's unavailability, and not its legality, which poses the real "imminent threat to public safety." It deserves careful study and consideration. 

I read and studied the original Notice of Intent, and was frankly appalled both as a citizen and an attorney how poorly-sourced and conclusory it was. I remain convinced that kratom has never been the sole cause of death or disability for anyone, and I do not believe that it ever will be. If the DEA truly intends to take the extraordinary step of classifying kratom as a Schedule I substance, it must meet the equally extraordinary burden of proving that kratom actually meets this standard. I commend the DEA for withdrawing the NOI and permitting a period of public comment, and hope that it will act with similar thought and consideration as it considers next steps.

documents.commentText:
Please don't make Kratom a Schedule I substance. I whole-hardly believe that this product, which has been used safety for thousands of years in SE Asia has no place on a scheduled substance list. I am in my 20's and suffer from a condition that has caused significant curvature of the spine (scoliosis - 24% spine curvature). As I have worked to remain active, it has caused a myriad number of back, neck, and other muscle related injuries. I have used kratom since 2010 on an as needed basis to help manage these problems associated with scoliosis. I was born with the condition and after having visited numerous doctors, the overwhelming consensus was to simple work around the condition, strengthen the surrounding muscles, and not have any type of surgery. Kratom has helped me successfully manage these issues and it has always been a mild, 100% controllable form of natural relief. I am perplexed by some of the news stories that have been linked to kratom and wonder if the journalists are even discussing the same product that I have used. In more than a half decade of taking this product, I have never once encountered any sign that indicates kratom is a dangerous substance much less something that merits a Schedule I classification. I absolutely agree that more research should be conducted but banning a product without understanding its full merits seems, at best, short sighted as our nation seeks meaningful solutions to the opioid epidemic and how we manage physical ailments.

Thanks,

John

documents.commentText:
Hello,
My name is Bobby.  I am a technical architect for a consulting firm in Chicago.  I strongly oppose the DEAs proposal for making the alkaloids mitragynine and 7-hydroxymitragynine schedule 1 controlled substances.
I started using Kratom 3 years ago and have not had a single health complication due to its use.  Please read below my personal journey as to why and how I started using this amazing plant.
As a child, I grew up in a violent and abusive household.  Being exposed to my fathers dealings of drugs and violence on a daily basis had caused me to suffer from post-traumatic stress and anxiety as an adult.  Before using Kratom, I would wake up in the middle of the night with severe panic attacks. Intense fear because of my anxiety would overwhelm me throughout the day for no reason which had affected life decisions, my marriage, and the ability to maintain relationships with co-workers, family, and friends.  At some point it became very apparent that changes needed to be made. I am not one to take prescription pills, or products that claim to be derived from natural sources as they are filled with many processed chemicals, so it was very important for me to find a product that was completely natural and had proven results. After tons of research and very careful consideration, I chose Kratom, and it has helped with not only coping with the effects of a trauma filled childhood, but also dealing with life issues.
I am a father of 3 year old triplets, two boys and a girl, and a 1 year old daughter.  My triplets were born prematurely and had to spend 2 months in the NICU.  One of my sons had intraventricular hemorrhaging (bleeding on the brain) and my daughter has downs syndrome.  Two of my triplets have special needs, and receive multiple therapies on a daily bases, which can be overwhelming at times. Being a father of four under the age of three has many rewards, but undeniably has just as many challenges. My biggest gift to them is to be the best dad that I can be despite my personal obstacles. 
Please take the necessary measures to preserve the integrity of this plants use and availability, so that there is continued scientific research to further develop its purpose.  More importantly, make sure it stays available for millions of people that are suffering from a variety of mental and/or physical illnesses as a truly natural non-addictive product that works!
Thank you for your time and consideration on this matter.

There are anecdotal reports of addiction risk. But it appears the addiction can be broken without withdrawal symptoms. Meanwhile, the painkillers currently being used are more addictive, dangerous, and harder to kick. Yet...

As I consider these actions by the FDA and DEA I'm forced to wonder -- WHAT ARE YOU PEOPLE SMOKING?

documents.commentText:
RE: Docket No. DEA-442W - my comments

My name is Tracey Kilpatrick.  I am 48 years old.  I am the Director of Data Operations for an international digital content measurement and monetization company.  

I oppose putting Kratom on the list of schedule 1 controlled substances. Schedule 1 controlled substances are thought to have no medical use, which is not
the case with Kratom.  

I have had chronic pain since my early 20's.  First with migraines, then with extremely painful menstrual cycles. Most recently, I have
neuropathy in my leg and restless leg syndrome.  I also suffer from social anxiety.  My doctors have always treated my pain with opiates and
my anxiety with SSRIs.  I was at the point where I had a prescription for codeine, zoloft, xanax and gabapentin.  These have various side
effects; nausea, weight gain, increased sweating, tremors, drowsiness, headaches, irritability, depression, and addiction.

I was very tired of taking pills in the morning, lunch and evening just to make it through the day.  I wanted to improve my life, so I did some research into
naturopathic medicine.  During this research, I came across people who used Kratom.  A local store sold it so I spoke to them about their
experience with it and decided to try it.  The thing a like about Kratom is that it has many strains and can be used to treat various symptoms.
I can take a small amount and have the same effect of drinking coffee.  If I use a different strain, it calms me and allows me to concentrate.
I can take some to help me fall asleep at night without having a hang-over feeling that some sleep aides cause.  Most importantly, I can
use it as an analgesic. The best thing about it is not having to take an opiate. I no longer take so many pills just to stop pain that I make myself sick
and cannot make it to work.

When the company I purchase Kratom from announced the DEAs intention to put it on the Schedule 1 controlled substance list, my heart sank. All
I could think of is having to go back to the opiates and anticonvulsant medication.  

Opiate addition continues to grow in the US.  In 2014, 18,893 overdose deaths related to prescription pain relievers
 (www.asam.org/docs/default-source/advocacy/opioid-addiction-disease-facts-figures.pdf).  The DEA has stated there
were 15 Kratom-related deaths between 2014 and 2016. This statement is a bit misleading as there were many other factors that contributed
to these deaths (www.snopes.com/kratom-banned-by-the-dea/).  

I simply don't understand the DEAs position on placing Kratom on the Schedule 1 list.  The Kratom community is made up of people that simply want an 
alternative to prescription medication that has a less risk of addiction and adverse side-effects. 

Thank you for your consideration.    

Tracey Kilpatrick

documents.commentText:
My name is Eric, and I wanted to make a short comment on the state of placing Mitragynine and 7-Hydroxymitragynine (commonly called Kratom) into Schedule 1.  I believe it is unjust when comparing this product to already legal (and far more dangerous) substances like alcohol, tobacco, and opiates.

I have served honorably with a 60% medical discharge from the United States Marine Corps Reserve after being diagnosed with an Inflammatory Bowel Disease (Ulcerative Colitis).  I started taking kratom in October 2016, due to complications with refractory disease and years of looking for relief from associated chronic pain.  Kratom has provided me with relief from chronic intestinal pain in a way I haven't experienced while either in the hospital on opiates or from being prescribed different pain relievers (more opiates can I want to remember) from Pain Management Clinics here in town or from the local VA Medical Center.  It has done more for alleviating my depression than the majority of antidepressants I have tried, which to date is approximately 7.  To put this chemical, which is letting me live a normal life both physically and mentally, into Schedule 1 is a poor decision when you can, in good conscience, allow opiates and tobacco and alcohol to remain legal.  Think of the preventable body count that could be avoided by restricting those substances.  I believe there should be further clinical tests to search for any deleterious long-term effects, before a rash move to Kratom as a schedule 1 substance.  I have yet to experience any negative side effects from the small or medium doses I take when I'm experiencing increased pain from bloody bowel movements or active inflammation in my intestinal lining.  Kratom has quickly become a way for me to feel normal again, in a way that I couldn't maintain being on opiates or most antidepressants.  It has also prevented me from needing copious amounts of Tylenol (I cannot take ibuprofen or NSAIDs for my disease, which severely limits my options for pain relief) and doing long-term damage to my liver (I often take the maximum of 4,000mg a day).  I think it should remain legal and citizens should have the choice to partake in Kratom in the same way I can partake of any other legal substance that may or may not have negative side effects.  And again, as I have not experienced negative side effects, it baffles me that it is set for Schedule 1.  Please reconsider, there is good evidence that Kratom works for pain relief and relief from the torment of clinical severe depression.  Thank you.  -Eric

documents.commentText:
I have lyme. I was bitten by many many ticks when I was 11 and 12 years old, during the time of some experimentation being done on mycoplasma germs about 30 miles away. I also coincidentally happen to have a very debilitating form of mycoplasma. I told doctors I was sick for many years after my body started to tell me it wasn't well, but they did not believe me. I got progressively worse as time went on, starting with neurological symptoms, progressing to nerve sensations and pain, and then overwhelming fatigue. I was told it was in my head, or that it was all due to depression. Some doctors told me I had growing pains when I was still fairly young, and others blamed it on lack of exercise. Why would they even say that, when the whole reason I was complaining is because I could not do the things I used to do?

I used to run close to five minute miles, but now I'm lucky if I can even make it upright for five minutes on my really bad and fatiguing days. Running and doing other active things outside was sort of my downfall. If I had stayed inside leading an inactive lifestyle, I wouldn't have had nearly as many chances to get bitten by ticks. I started to lose faith and trust in all doctors, since they kept ignoring me when I told them I was sick, and as all the medical professionals I saw gaslighted me into that belief, I eventually believed I was imagining it all, that it really was in my head, so I gave up for a long time. Certain things helped me over the years, and other things seemed to help, but also caused me other problems (alcohol for example). I am surprised I lived through this, and that I continue to be as strong as I am. I might just be lucky, since it hasn't yet attacked the places where it can with others, causing death within months to a few years.

I have over twenty various conditions, most chronic and some fully systemic. Some I can slow progression by taking supplements and other things, and most have no permanent cures. Some will take constant medication, and some can be prevented to a degree, or at least masked to some extent. There have been times where I've taken over 60 pills a day. It's very hard to live like this, and when I was healthy, I never imagined a person could feel this way, even on my worst days, or in my worst nightmares.

When somebody asks me what it is like, I explain that it is like a constant flu most of the time, but instead of being able to sleep through it as a sick person would, and having it go away in a few days, it never ends. On top of that, I have to perform and function in life while I have the flu, unlike the people that get a lot of rest. They get better. I cannot rest twenty-four hours a day, and it's pointless to do that, since my muscles would only atrophy, and it's too painful to sleep for very long periods most of the time anyway. I have a lot more symptoms constantly barraging me aside from a simple flu, but I describe it this way, since most people know what the flu is like. The other stuff is a bit more difficult to get into with somebody healthy.

Why are we focused on scheduling HERBS, not even something as bad as alcohol(WHY IS THIS NOT SCHEDULED?  IT FITS MORE THAN ANYTHING ELSE BY DEFINITION), where they are actually changing it from its natural form. Alcohol was responsible for a third of all traffic-related deaths last year, and kills over 100,000 people a year. Medications like NSAIDs kill 8,000+ a year.  Why is addiction considered worse than death in this country?  I have CONSTANT PAIN! I don't get it. Addiction is treatable, and is very temporary, compared to a lifetime of non-stop pain. Doctors will not provide poor people with adequate pain medications when they have pain, unless it falls under specific types. Only high self-pay doctors prescribe pain medications, so there is a discrimination gap, and banning kratom will only increase that gap, allowing doctors and big pharma to monopolize more pain medications, and keep people who need it in agonizing distress. It's sadistic, and if there is one, I hope God is going to pass judgement on those that are doing this to people who suffer. The ones who take these things away don't even know what one percent of this suffering is like, and never will in their lifetimes...  We are the ones who deserve the most given to us. Our lives are harder than most other people, and taking away even more from our functionality only makes things worse.

Kratom helps me and others like me function in an already unfair world where we are at a disadvantage economically, emotionally, and add almost every aspect of living to the list. Adding yet another herb, related to coffee at that, to schedule I here will just hurt many because of... who?  Why is there even talks of a ban?  I don't see anybody robbing banks because of their kratom addiction. It's laughable to me, but big money is no doubt behind it. Don't let it win.There is just not enough room here to explain my condition properly,this is preposterous.

documents.commentText:
Please do not ban or restrict Kratom.

    Banning kratom expands the war on drugs, while the public overwhelmingly supports ending it.
    If kratom is added to any one of the five drug schedules, people who use it will be criminalized and locked up behind bars.
    Kratom has been used safely by millions of people in the U.S. and evidence supports kratom's potential as a pain reliever and opioid replacement.
    Many people struggling with opioid addiction have turned to kratom to help them cut back or quit, but now all promising scientific studies on kratom's role in opioid treatment could be immediately shut down.
    Side effects of kratom are minimal, and its withdrawal symptoms are weak and nearly inconsequential compared to the suffering of people trying to quit opioids.
    Prohibiting kratom will worsen the country's problems of opioid addiction and overdose.

documents.commentText:
My name is Brad Bell. I'm a 31-year old from Virginia, and Im your constituent. I'd like to voice my extreme opposition to the DEAs Intent to Schedule the alkaloids Mitragynine and 7-Hydroxymitragynine, which would make the herb Kratom (Mitragyna speciosa), a schedule 1 controlled substance. Doing this denies it has medicinal value which is entirely false. Kratom is a plant helping millions of people suffering chronic and acute mental and physical conditions naturally and more safely than prescription medicines that are used for these conditions. There are numerous military veterans using it to treat their PTSD and pain issues from war as well.  It is also safely easing the nation's opiate epidemic problem and helping addicts recover to become functioning citizens again. This scheduling would prevent further research which, to date, has shown Kratom to be an effective painkiller that does not cause respiratory depression; the main cause of death from opiate overdose.
I was in a bad car accident at age 19 and injured discs in my low spine as well as my neck. This has affected every aspect of my life. After exhausting literally hundreds of conventional treatments, I had to have back surgery. The surgery failed and my pain has only gotten worse over the years and Ive had to redo many of the treatments. My treatments included physical therapy, painful steroid injections, trigger point muscle injections, dozens of anti-inflammatory drugs that have eaten away at my stomach lining, chiropractors, acupuncture, and massage therapy. As a last resort I was prescribed to opiate pain medications and nerve pain medicines that gave me such horrible mental deficits that I had to leave my job working for the federal government supporting our troops in the military. I decided that I would no longer take these awful medicines and started researching medicinal herbs.
I was unable to get a job again until I discovered Kratom. It is the only thing in 12 years that controls my pain without killing my brain and making me unable to function physically and mentally. Kratom has entirely saved my life and allowed me to be a productive member of society. It does not intoxicate me like the pain medicines did so I am able to think clearly and function normally. After finding Kratom, I was able to hunt and fish again, enjoy my vacations, go to social events with my wife, and help around the house. It has given me the ability to do all the things I loved doing before my back injury. Before finding Kratom, I was almost completely unable to participate in anything like that. My wife and I felt for the first time that we had a handle on my problems, and felt we could finally be happy again. That was until the DEA announced their intent to outlaw this miracle cure! It literally feels as though my life is imploding again like it did when I was 19 years old. I truly believe I will be forced to stop working and go on disability. I will once again be unable to do any of the things I enjoy in life. 
Im asking you to please not deny the medical uses and take away this miracle herb that helps so many people.. I fear this action by the DEA will only lead to more tragic deaths of victims of the opiate epidemic and will cause millions of chronically ill people like me to become disabled again. I know that my own quality of life as a productive member of society will not be the same without Kratom.

Sincerely,

documents.commentText: Hello. My name is Steven Hadley, 37, former professor of art. I am writing in regards to oppose the DEA putting the supplement kratom on the list of schedule 1 controlled substances. Four years ago, I developed a pain in my left abdomen and flank that plagued me every day since. I lost my job, suffered severe depression, anxiety, and suicidality as a result of the intensifying pain. One year ago, I qualified for Medicaid and am now on a hopeful path to diagnosis and treatment but there has never been any medication, surgery, or treatment that has alleviated my pain completely or qualitatively since onset. Under Medicaid, I have established a relationship with a PCP and numerous specialists who are now helping me. One method is through pain management via opioids. Even then, I would still spend much of the week in bed, trying to sleep through the pain. Two months ago, that changed. After reading an article about the possible banning of kratom, I researched the subject regarding its uses, effects, and possible adverse effects. Upon learning that it could treat chronic pain, I decided to order a sample and try it. This supplement, a naturally occurring plan, has given me back a quality of life that I thought I might never experience again. I have been able to cut my opioid dose in half and spend much less time prone, trying to wait out the spasms. I implore you to please leave kratom off of the banned substances list. Now that I have some semblance of a life again, I am extremely fearful about your upcoming decision. If kratom is placed on the schedule 1 list, my dependence on opioides will have to be increased despite the opioid crisis America is currently facing, and I will undoubtedly go back to a life spent primarily in bed. I understand the interest that the US government and pharmaceutical companies have in kratom and the damage it could do to their profits but, again, I implore you, please put the welfare of an ever growing community of kratom supporters above the profits of Big Pharma. None of us know what the future holds nor how long we have. What I do know is that kratom has given me back something I had lost years ago, hope. Please don't take that away from me.

Hello,

I, like many, have found kratom to be a God send.  You see, I suffer from Marfan's syndrome, a connective tissue disorder which also affects my heart valves.  I regularly dislocate joints doing daily tasks, and it can be quite painful.  I never really wanted to go down the painkiller route because I have seen first hand what it can do to people's lives, and how it's ruined and killed hundreds of thousands of people in America.  And about 3 years ago, I was introduced to kratom.  Kratom, in it's purest form, is a perfectly safe alternative to dangerous prescription drugs and alcohol, as well as an effective anti-depressant if used correctly.  I know that there are probably hundreds of people who claim to be addicted to the stuff, but that is no reason to ban something that hundreds of thousands of people use responsibly for real reasons.  That is why I'm writing today, to urge you not to ban kratom and ruin what for so many people has been a way to manage pain.  

Take for example, Alabama.  Alabama recently banned kratom in April, and in May and June, heroin and other opiate overdoses more than doubled in Alabama because of it.  While i have never been addicted to any opiates, i have read hundreds of testimonials of people who do struggle with it and have found that kratom has literally given them their lives back.  We as a country cannot risk banning something like kratom with the fentanyl/heroin epidemic like it is.  It would be putting thousands of lives in jeopardy who otherwise would probably be using if kratom was still legal instead of heroin/other dangerous opiates.  Please see it in your heart to not rush to a decision and allow for proper medical research on kratom to come to fruition before a decision is made.  

Sincerely, 

William Coons

I go to church every Sunday and I am a member of the choir. I am in good physical condition but have had arthritis in my knees for several years that I treated with ibuprofen, Meloxicam, Tramadol for flare ups, and cortisone injections 2-3 times a year. I come home at the end of the workday and take walks and play with my granddaughters instead of falling into my recliner until bedtime. I can work in my yard on the weekends and not be a burden to my children. I am much more active now than I was before taking kratom.
I was so proud of my state earlier this year. Instead of blindly passing proposed SB830 our elected leaders listened to the people of North Carolina and amended the bill to restrict Kratom to those 18 years of age and over, and ordered a study by the Senate Health Care Committee to determine the safety of its use, which is a very sensible approach. Kratom needs to remain available to the American citizens as a natural supplement - please do not put Kratom on a controlled substance list!

documents.commentText:
Below is a testimony written by my colleague who wishes to remain anonymous. He is a father, husband and sole bread-winner of the family:

Dear DEA,

Please remove Mitragynine & 7-hydroxymitragynine which is in Kratom from becoming a Schedule I substance.
 
I am 29 and suffer from a herniated disc, chronic neck pain, TMJ, arthritis in my neck. I support a family of four on a single income. I have been to many doctors with little success for treatment. I have found that Kratom improves my quality of life after a hard days work. It isnt comparable to any drugs, marijuana, alcohol or other stimulants.  Kratom helps to improve my quality of life that I suffer with chronic pain. Please dont make this herb illegal. Cervical injections, botox injections, chiropractic care, physical therapy, acupuncture, massage therapy, yoga exercises have not helped with my pain.
 
Kratom is a well-known, well-researched herbal substance drawn from the leaves of trees within the coffee family. The number of cases of documented harm from kratom use is remarkably low, both as an absolute matter and when considered against the extensive history of use of kratom, both inside and outside the United States
 
Mitragynine and 7-hydroxymitragynine are two of the primary alkaloids of this plant. These two compounds are not synthetic and should not be lumped together with  "bath salts" or "spice".
 
Kratom has been used as a medicine by many people for thousands of years. It is a potent remedy for physical pain, anxiety and depression, and could be used to aid with opiate withdrawal by those who would like to quit using illicit drugs such as heroin. Kratom is NOT a hallucinogen and should not be classified as such. Adding mitragynine and 7-hydroxymitragynine as a Schedule I substance is rash and unjustified prohibition, resulting in a foreseeable increase in street drug-related crime, as well as a punishment to those who are currently using it responsibly to treat various ailments.

The reason that there are no deaths solely attributed to Kratom is because Kratom does not affect your respiratory capacity. It does not slow down your central nervous system. It's potential to do harm is virtually impossible.

Kratom has very limited recreational capacity.  The White House petition has over 100,000 signatures for the "Please do not make Kratom a Schedule I Substance." 

The federal government has invested significant resources to develop alternative pain management strategies. This includes a study funded by the National Institutes of Health in partnership with the University of Massachusetts and the University of Mississippi to investigate the use of Kratom as a remedy for opioid withdrawal. This study led the researchers to apply for a patent identifying the Kratom extract, mitragyinine, as a useful treatment for other addictive drugs besides opiate derivatives. The DEAs decision to place Kratom as a Schedule I substance will put a halt on federally funded research and innovation surrounding the treatment of individuals suffering from opioid and other addictionsa significant public health threat. Remember the DDear Colleague Letters of Senator Hatch and Congressman Mark Pocan.
 
We hope you realize the threat this scheduling causes the people seeking legitimate use of this special plant to improve our quality of life. Attached are testimonies and facts about Kratom along with other facts listed below. 

Sincerely,
 
Anonymous

I wish I could say it's been easy but it hasn't. It has, however, been possible because of Kratom. Kratom is not a cure, or a treatment, but it does help me prevent possible relapse because I know combining Kratom with alcohol is a very bad idea. So once I have so much as a sip of kratom, I feel safe for the night. 
Please, I beg... for the sake of those like me who wish to never drink again.... for those struggling with a myriad of addictions, kratom is a miracle. Please don't make me face this daily struggle alone. I can't afford rehab and I can't afford expensive medical intervention.

documents.commentText:
To whom it may concern,

I have been using kratom for over two years. Prior to that time period I was addicted to prescription painkillers and heroin. My life was in shambles and I wasn't able to function and be a productive member of society. Today, through using kratom, utilizing the AA program, and through therapy, I am able to have a life. I have a job, a girlfriend, a home, and pay all my own bills. I view kratom no differently than a maintenance drug like suboxone or buprenorphine. The incident rate of relapse for opioid addicts is extremely high. I have not relapsed since January of 2014 on prescription painkillers or heroin.

Kratom has had a very positive impact on my life. The kratom community is one of the strongest I have seen. We are all there to help one another. This plant has properties unlike any other that practically prevent abuse. I believe the DEA along with the FDA or any other government agencies should invest in researching this miracle plant. I don't want to see the active alkaloids patented and sold like another pharmaceutical drug. This country is in an opioid epidemic and I was a casualty. Now, more than ever, we need kratom. 

I implore the DEA to not schedule kratom and to allow it's continued sale whilst more research is done. If it is made illegal I believe a lot of those using it to treat chronic pain/drug addiction will return to dangerous prescriptions and heroin. There will be more unnecessary deaths. Thank you for your time. 

Regards,

Tim Woloszyn

documents.commentText:
To whom it may concern:

Hello, I am an American citizen living in Mexico, forty eight years old and while I am Human Resources Manager for a local chain of gasoline stations, also two years ago my wife and I opened a small High School that integrates an ambitious academic level with emotional intelligence via mindfulness techniques.
I am also a firm supporter of keeping kratom legal for adult consumption.

As a diagnosed sufferer of Delayed Sleep Phase Disorder (DSPS), I discovered kratom a year and a half ago, while researching online about how to alleviate the acute anxiety generated by my lack of ability to sleep when I want or need to.
While kratom may not directly help me sleep, it works great for reducing the stress caused by my condition.

Soon after I realized that kratom had generated a positive impact on other aspects my life:

Kratom brought my Irritable Bowel Syndrome under control.
With two slightly worn lower vertebrae, I occasionally suffer from painful lumbar spasms, and kratom has helped considerably whenever such an episode occurs, instead of going for the Tramadol, as kratom does not depress my breathing.
Finally and maybe most significantly, kratom stopped my binge drinking on its' tracks, I have had no desire whatsoever to drink alcohol for the past year and a half, now instead I go for the ice cream and cookies.

On multiple fronts, there has been a marked improvement in the quality of my personal life since discovering kratom, so I was horrified by the announced DEA ban, as well as baffled by its' assessment that it possesses no medical value as a key component of said ban, when my personal experience has been evidence to the contrary.

It is therefore that I feel compelled to share my story and to ask you on my behalf and of those who have any number of physiological and/or emotional conditions more severe than my own, to exercise compassion by keeping kratom legal and available for responsible adults, to not prematurely ban the use of kratom as it is researched more deeply and results are published on the topic.

Thank you very much for your time.

Sincerely,
Juan Rudametkin

documents.commentText:
Im a 53-year-old IT journalist, married and with one child, who has been imbibing kratom tea for the past ten years, mainly to help control my anxiety. Im writing to urge you to keep Kratom legal and available in the United States. I was stunned and upset to hear that the DEA was considering banning the plant in the U.S., as it is a very mild, harmless leaf that helps far more people than it could ever harm. 
My experience with kratom began over a decade ago when my anxiety became severe enough to hurt my ability to be a good parent and to function at work. While I had a daily medication  Effexor  I still suffered from periods of high anxiety, and initially asked my physician for Valium. When she declined to prescribe more than few pills per year, I realized I needed something else to help me cope. Drinking alcohol was one option, however hurt my ability to work and be a good parent. After some research, online, I came across kratom and decided to give it a try. 
Kratom not only calms my anxiety, but has also curbed my desire for alcohol.  It relaxes me enough that I can work productively and have no need for a drink to escape anxiety. If I had gone with Valium instead, I might well be addicted to it, forced to look for illegal sources of the drug. 
Kratom is no more addictive than coffee. If you use it every day for a long time, you can become mildly dependent. But coffee isnt illegal, nor are cigarettes and alcohol, which are much more addictive.  On kratom forums, very few mention troubles quitting kratom, while most others praise it for helping them get off opiates or alcohol. Ive often heard people say that kratom has helped them manage chronic pain and avoid having to take opiates in the first place. 
Ive never had a bad experience with kratom, except for once or twice when I became nauseated from drinking too much. That is why you cant overdose on kratom  you vomit first. Ive also dealt with many kratom sellers, and none have sold bad kratom or cut it with other substances. 
Banning kratom will pull the rug out from thousands of people who need it, like me, and force many to seek it illegally, no doubt leading to more decent people crammed into prisons already overflowing with minor drug offenders. 
Kratom isnt a dangerous plant and any such reports are either invented or based on kratom being combined other substances. If a person drinks coffee with alcohol, opiates and valium, and they wind up in a hospital, is it the fault of the coffee? Look to the real culprits  the drugs with potentially fatal, effects. Kratom simply isnt capable of killing someone, unless they drown themselves in a vat of kratom tea perhaps. 
In your war on drugs, please remember that kratom is your ally, not your enemy. 
Respectfully, 
a mom in Massachusetts

documents.commentText:
Personally used for occasional anxiety issues over taking medication that 1) could potentially require I remain on for the remainder of my life and/or stop working after taking daily for a number of years (such as Paxil or other SSRI/SNRIs) or 2) that I could become addicted to (a drug in the benzodiazepine family). I have also known people who have used kratom to help them get off opiates for pain and/or help them with withdrawal symptoms to help them stay off opiates they had become addicted to. Kratom itself does not appear to be addictive. I have not experienced any adverse side effects from kratom use. If it were to become unavailable to me, I could potentially miss work/school because of the lack of sleep anxiety causes as doctors are highly reluctant to prescribe medications that help because of their adverse side effects or their fear of reprisal for prescribing too much/too often.
The negative incidents I am aware of involved combining kratom with another prescription medication that caused seizures. In response to this, I consider other natural remedies such as St Johns Wort, which, if taken with certain prescription medications renders them either too effective or not effective. Warnings come with prescription medications that interact with supplements or food to inform patients of these potential harmful side effects and the same could be done for kratom.

documents.commentText:
My name is Alicia Zvonar and I think making Kratom a Schedule I drug is a mistake.  I have several medical issues that cause me to have chronic pain.  I have several bulging and degenerating discs, bone spurs on my spine and scoliosis.  I also suffer from osteoarthritis that is continuing to get worse; some days I find it hard to tie my shoes, write or even type.  Typing is essential to me because I am in school to get my MS in Substance Abuse Counseling.  I also have a job in retail as well as a job cleaning corporate apartments for another company; being able to move is essential to me.  
     My story begins back a little over 10 years ago, I began seeing a pain specialist who began treating my chronic pain with Percocet and Vicodin.  I believe he was over-prescribing me when I stopped seeing him.  I then began buying oxycontin on the streets.  Soon I was doing heroin to treat my incessant chronic pain.  I got help to get off the heroin with Subutex but the withdrawals were worse than the heroin withdrawals.  After consulting with my regular doctor, I went off the Subutex cold turkey with the help of beta blockers and Klonopin.  As I am sure you are aware, I could no longer take prescription pain medications due to my addiction.  I did some research on natural, herbal solutions to manage my chronic pain.  I found Kratom.  
     Although Kratom does not completely eliminate my pain, it makes it tolerable so that I can do everyday things like work and cook dinner for my husband.  Kratom does not cause the euphoria that prescription pain medication or heroin did.  It only helps to manage my pain and the depression that coincides with that pain. I have never had a problem with taking too much Kratom.  I did, however, overdose on heroin once and Percocet several times.  When I am not in pain, I have more energy; I was even able to enroll into a Master's degree program to become a substance abuse counselor.  I am studying to be a drug counselor and Kratom is helping me to do that.  What kind of example would I set if Kratom should become a Schedule I drug? 
     There is a severe epidemic in this country of prescription pain pill and heroin addiction.  Making Kratom a Schedule I drug would leave some people no choice but to go back to prescription drugs and illicit drugs.  I wasted too many years of my life in a euphoric stupor to help ease my pain.  Please do not take away the only thing that helps me that lets me maintain a clear head and is not lethal.

Thank you for your time,


Alicia D Zvonar

documents.commentText:
I am a sixty-seven-year-old author, and Im not like other people. I cant just run to the doctor and have her prescribe something for the chronic pain from a debilitating back injury and fibromyalgia. I was born with bipolar disorder and any medication that warns of mood changes can quickly trigger life-threatening side effects, so I dont even risk them. Opiates guarantee depression, so I cant take them either. And Im not content to spend my life fighting pain rather than write and enjoy my family.

That is why Kratom has been such a godsend. Not only does it help me manage my chronic pain, it doesnt affect my mood any more than a good cup of coffee does. Unlike many prescription drugs, it helps me sleep, but doesnt leave me stupid and hung-over the next day. I havent needed to up my dose and am still taking the same four grams at night and two in the morning that Ive been taking for over a year. Nor do I crave it, like I once did the taken-as-prescribed benzodiazepines (which triggered a suicide attempt, by the way). Kratoms side effects are minimal, especially compared to most prescription drugs. And finally, Kratom costs me less than $100 month instead of the $300 or $400 I would spend on prescription meds, which is a pretty big deal for someone like me on a limited income. 

Please remember that Kratom has been used in Southeast Asia for thousands of years without societal collapse. The people there enjoy it as tea, which I find hard to imagine, because its so bitter that I do not relish drinking mine every day even though I greatly appreciate the pain relief it affords. 

I am writing to tell you that scheduling Kratom would seriously diminish the quality of my life, because Ive yet to find a safe, effective substitute, and I really do not want to resort to swallowing handfuls of ibuprofen, which will ultimately destroy my liver. Why schedule this herb and complicate research into its many uses, including its potential to stem Americas tragic opiate addiction problem? Why not suggest common-sense guidelines and keep it available to the countless thousands of people, like me, who benefit greatly from its use? If you must err, please err on the side of compassion.

Thank you for your consideration.

Sincerely,
Kitty Roxanna Connell

documents.commentText:
Hi,

Prohibition doesn't work. Banning kratom will simply push it onto the black market which cannot be policed, lead to more arrests of non-violent people, and most importantly, it will harm people who are trying to break free from opioid addiction by using a plant substitute. Look at what happened with alcohol prohibition: Alcohol went on the black market and people died from dirty batches. Legalizing, taxing, and regulating it eliminated this problem and led to a profitable market; the same should be done for kratom. Right now, you have very few reported deaths from kratom use, many in which kratom was mixed with other substances which then led to injury and/or death. If it becomes schedule I, it is essentially outlawed as is much of the promising research on it and the number of deaths will skyrocket because people will simply buy it on the black market thereby creating a far worse situation. So, I respectfully request that kratom remain legal as a ban benefits no one but drug companies who view it as their competition to far riskier, expensive synthetic drugs.

Have a good night.

I played college football in my early 20's and had my kneecap sheared almost all the way off during a practice. This tore off nearly all the cartilage from under my kneecap and after numerous surgeries, the doctors were unable to replace that cartilage. So, long story short I have almost no cartilage under my kneecap, leading to daily, constant pain.  The only solution doctors provided was to prescribe me opiate pain killers. This lead to a terrible quality of life. It is very tough to enjoy your friends, family and daily activities when you are either in terrible pain or an opiate induced haze.  When I discovered Kratom for myself, all this changed. It dulls the pain but without the impairment that comes with opiate pain killers. To be pain free without being intoxicated has literally changed my life. I can hike with my wife and dog again without being in terrible pain during and afterward, whereas I wouldn't have been even able to hike on painkillers.  I can also use kratom without fear of addiction, withdrawal, or possible overdose. I have gone periods without kratom with no withdrawal effects, which is definitely not the case with opiates.  To sum it up, this plant is something I rely on for pain relief and I think it would be very irresponsible to make this a scheduled drug, because it is not a drug. To me it has literally been life saving.

Thank you for your time,
Jake Simon

documents.commentText: I am not a kratom user but I have researched the subject extensively and it is clear there are many people who find relief from chronic pain, opiate addiction, general anxiety disorder and depression by using this plant. This plant has been used safely in SE Asia for hundreds of years, and there are no records of deaths solely from the plant. The handful of deaths (far less than acetaminophen, alcohol or tobacco) associated with kratom were in combination with dangerous opiates, including the horrible product krypton, which contained o-desmethyltramadol. Because there is clear medical utility, low potential for abuse, and no real health risks (including respiratory depression), it makes no sense to put kratom in schedule 1. People will turn back to dangerous opiates, and people will die. I understand there are pharmaceutical patents being pursued for analogues of kratom alkaloids. If this is why the DEA is considering scheduling kratom, its a treasonous betrayal of public health for private profit. Keep kratom legal!

documents.commentText:
I strongly disagree with the banning of Kratom, below are just a few reasons.

*Banning kratom expands the war on drugs, while the public overwhelmingly supports ending it.

*If kratom is added to any one of the five drug schedules, people who use it will be criminalized and locked up behind bars.

*Kratom has been used safely by millions of people in the U.S. and evidence supports kratom's potential as a pain reliever and opioid replacement.

*Many people struggling with opioid addiction have turned to kratom to help them cut back or quit, but now all promising scientific studies on kratom's role in opioid treatment could be immediately shut down.

*Side effects of kratom are minimal, and its withdrawal symptoms are weak and nearly inconsequential compared to the suffering of people trying to quit opioids.

*Prohibiting kratom will worsen the country's problems of opioid addiction and overdose.

Please do the right thing and stop the senseless criminalization of millions more people.

Sincerely,
Amber Angel

documents.commentText: Schedule I drugs are claimed to have no medicinal value. This is outrageously untrue in the case of Kratom. It has value in the control of pain, anxiety, depression, and insomnia, to name a few. Of even more importance, it has the ability to help those truly and hopelessly addicted to narcotics kick that habit without side effects, withdrawals, or getting addicted to some new substance. I and many others can attest to each of these claims. From experience, it is about on par with coffee in terms of its addictiveness and one does not get "high" from even very high doses. The worst effect that can happen is nausea.  If the ultimate goal is public health, this decision is going to make us all worse off as a nation. Kratom is a safe alternative with important medicinal uses and has changed the lives of so many Americans. I fear any negative action towards it will only lead to more tragic deaths and cast victims of the opiate epidemic back into the fray. We should be looking for positive solutions to addiction, not creating more problems.

documents.commentText:
Thank you for taking the time to reconsider this issue.  While I have never used kratom myself, I know that it has helped many people avoid opioid use, cope with chronic pain that cannot be managed other ways, and cope with mental illnesses such as PTSD.  As we have seen deaths due to illegal drug overdose skyrocket, I believe we need to reevaluate how we look at illegal drug use and begin to practice more harm reduction.  Allowing (or allowing but regulating) the use of kratom would be one way to practice harm reduction.

So far, there is no evidence that kratom is any more harmful than many other legal substances, and it seems to be less harmful than many -- for example, alcohol causes many deaths each year.  I have not seen any reports that link kratom use (alone, without other substances being involved) in the US to deaths, and certainly not the number of deaths directly caused by alcohol and tobacco.

Before this (or any substance) is banned or classified as a schedule I substance, more studies should be done to determine possible benefits of kratom, as well as possible adverse effects.  I believe that currently there is not enough evidence to merit this classification.

Thank you for your consideration.

documents.commentText:
I am a 78 year old native American. I feel the state and federal governments have overstepped their bounds during my lifetime. There is a water fall near Fairmont, WV, called Valley Falls. We used to go there and swim during the summer. Now we are restricted from even going down on the rocks that create the falls. I do not really know why the restrictions were imposed on the public but I think they were imposed to protect us from ourselves. This is the action of persons in the government taking away the publics right of self determination. They assume the power and the right to point a finger and decide what is best for other people without seeking the opinion or consent of those affected. It should be the unrestricted right of every citizen to decide for themselves what risks they will or will not take with regard to such things as where to swim or what kind of naturally occurring drugs or pharmaceuticals they wish to use to address their health or recreational needs.  It should not be the role of government to dictate to individuals concerning such small aspects of a persons life. If I want to risk hurting myself at Valley Falls swimming that should be solely for me to decide. 
     I feel the same about such things as Kratom and other natural things many people consider medicines or recreational drugs. I do not use Kratom or marijuana but I do use the leaves of the Neem tree for infection control. Since early childhood I had bronchitis almost every year at least once. The last case I had I treated it with the Neem leaves and I haven't had another case of bronchitis since then. That was four years ago. Never in my life have I gone that long without bronchitis. 
     I respectfully appeal to the DEA to protect the right of the American people to be self determining in the use of Kratom and not schedule it at all.  I would request the DEA treat Kratom, marijuana and other such drugs with the same hands off policy used in regulating alcohol products. Alcohol is a far more destructive substance to society than any of these plant substances (excluding tobacco) put together. Tobacco is another freely available substance that is even more destructive than alcohol. It would seem that alcohol and tobacco being readily available to the public would relegate Kratom and marijuana to an equivalent status in view of their low incidence of harming society or even individuals. As with alcohol or tobacco the choice by an individual to use such personally harmful substances should be left to that individual.
     Allowing public comment on this has raised my respect for the work the DEA does. Making arbitrary laws and policy with arbitrary enforcement on the people of our country without their consent is undemocratic to say the least and,at worst, dictatorial, which creates resentment and resistance toward government agencies for what is viewed by many as an abuse of power. Thank you very much for the chance to share my thoughts on this topic.
Stanley Roger Boyer

documents.commentText:
Dear Sir or Madam,

I am a 43 year old man that has been safely using kratom as a safe dietary supplement for the last four years for certain mental health issues with no negative side affects.  On the other hand, the positive affects it has had on my life would be too numerous to list in this short letter.  

I spent my career as a public servant: first as a Captain in the United States Marine Corps and, for the last twelve years, as an Assistant Prosecuting Attorney.  I am currently assigned to our Special Victims Section and primarily prosecute crimes in my county against women, children, and the elderly.  In my career, I have also prosecuted hundreds of drug related crimes.  I understand why certain drugs are illegal and agree 100 percent that certain drugs should be controlled and made illegal to possess.  Everyday, I witness first-hand the devastation that certain drugs can have on a person and on the community.  Kraton, however, is no such drug. 

Kraton is a safe natural dietary supplement that is in the same family as the coffee plant and is just as safe.  I have been using kratom, as needed, over the last four years to combat certain mental health issues with great success.  I have discussed kraton with my doctor who very much supports my use of this beneficial plant.  

I appreciate the DEA giving me the opportunity to express my personal thoughts and experiences about kratom.  I hope you strongly consider my views and others who have expressed their opposition to scheduling kratom as a controlled substance.  In my opinion, it would be a travesty of justice if kratom was wrongly listed as a harmful controlled substance and would rob thousands of responsible kratom users of the many benefits this plant has to offer.  I urge you to please reconsider scheduling kratom as a controlled substance.  Please feel free to contact me should you have any questions.  Thank you for your consideration.

documents.commentText:
Dear Sirs;
     Due to the absolute foolishness of a few, it amazes me that it is acceptable to wage a battle against various pain medicines. There will always be those who abuse prescriptions regardless of consequences. I am one of the people who suffer from not only degenerative disc disease, but also have survived several auto accidents, in addition to congenital defects in my lumbar spine. I have had a large spinal fusion a few months ago after 14 years of putting it off through fear of potential disability. I am only 45, and have a 4 year old who I want to have a good life, and memories of a father who could actually play and otherwise interact with him.

     So for several years, I had been in pain management. Which my previous doctor's approach was to throw 120 hydrocodone or oxycodone at you, and you were supposed to shut up for a month. I fired him in February 2016, as I didn't want to be stuck on that junk for the rest of my life, and worked with my GP until September and my fusion surgery.

     Kratom has greatly improved my life. I can get good pain relief, while also being able to interact with my family/coworkers. I feel better, as I can get away from opiate medications and allow my body to rest. This has slowed down my tolerance to the opiate medications, and allows me to stay with a consistent dosage. Typically, the kratom makes me not need the opiate medications, except on very bad days.

     I hope you can see the sense in not banning kratom due to how much it helps people like me. If too much is accidentally ingested, your body will vomit it back up, instead of opiates causing respiratory distress, among other effects.

documents.commentText:
I oppose the DEAs Intent to Schedule the alkaloids Mitragynine and 7-Hydroxymitragynine, which would make Kratom (Mitragynaspeciosa), the most severe classification of schedule I.  I have consumed kratom a handful of times myself. I found out about kratom from a tea shop that served kratom as a relaxation aide, along with kava root, chamomile, and other common herbs and spices that are rather well known and DEA/FDA approved for food. Kava and chamomile are both touted by retailers as relaxation aides as well. I have a clinical anxiety disorder and find kava root to be helpful. With my limited experience of kratom, it seemed to be helpful in the same regard. Not once did I feel a compulsion to continue significant use. In the 10+ years since I first tried it I've only done so maybe 5 times. On the other hand, I am a recovering alcoholic; haven't drank since March 16th, 2015. I clearly have the genetic disposition for addiction, but have no desire, intent, or compulsion to consume kratom any more than I do coffee, green tea, or kava. It's obviously not an availability issue, as a simple Internet search to buy it from numerous vendors is a mouse click away.

This notion is echoed by existing scientific literature. Studies have shown kratom has a low risk of dependency or addiction. Furthermore, their observations clearly show potential for use as an aide in opioid addiction treatment. Given that opioid abuse is seeing a resurgence in recent years, and has been an ever-present problem for humanity, there's a dire need for further inquiry into the potential for kratom's clinical use. I have had conversations with multiple people that have suffered an opioid addiction, tried kratom, and found it a useful tool in their recovery. They're not stealing from their families to find their next high anymore, and are ostensibly living healthy and successful lives now as hard-working, tax-paying fellow citizens. I personally have nothing to add to this particular objection, as I have never abused opiates, but their stories of being able to kick a well-known, painfully strong addiction with help from a simple non-addictive herb, is astounding.

Despite all this, I am not necessarily an advocate of the substance for any particular purpose. My main objection, as stated above, is that we're considering as a nation to place a felony ban on a substance that apparently

a.) has a LOW potential for abuse.
b.) HAS currently (albeit preliminarily) accepted medical use in treatment in the United States.
c.) There is an ABUNDANCE of accepted safety for use.

Kratom has records of use since at least the 19th century, yet to date not a single person has died as a direct result of kratom consumption. Studies have shown it doesn't cause respiratory depression, the leading cause of death in opiate overdoses. The kratom plant nor it's constituents are not classified as an opiate, as they are not a part of the opium family of plants. Rather, kratom is a member of the coffee family. Let's also keep in mind that hundreds of thousands of people die every year of heart disease, often precipitated by the federally-approved yet medically-confirmed lethally high diet of fats, sugars, and tobacco.

It is estimated that fatal doses of caffeine for humans are between 3 and 20 grams taken orally, depending on body weight and tolerance. An average cup of coffee contains 1/15 or less than an estimated lethal dose. Yet America drinks this substance daily, with no fear of this threat. If the concern is for public health, we're looking in the wrong place. The DEA's current proposal is to criminalize kratom with the same severity as heroin. This comparison is patently false given the current literature. Despite this, and sound evidence for a potentially highly effective method of drug abuse recovery, the DEA is proposing that we regulate and add more legal mechanisms to waste our tax payer dollars, and our nation's finest law enforcement's time, trying to enforce this to keep our society safe from a substance that's very likely as safe for human consumption as the traditional coffee plant.

IF the DEA must schedule kratom, let's be reasonable and place it in schedule V so that clinical testing for potential as an addiction remedy may continue. However, it's not currently shown to have dependency or abuse risks, so my opinion is to leave this concern for the FDA to review its existing approval as a food additive or dietary supplement. Further research is necessary, but please do not lock kratom into a scheduled status where history proves it will never return from. I'd rather not see my tax dollars wasted worrying about a non-toxic species of coffee. I think there are far more pressing issues both of these agencies need to attend to, such as protecting us from the very real, very dangerous and predatory drug cartels, both black market and corporate. Thank you for your time.

documents.commentText:
I ask that it be understood that kratom is not a "drug". As far as the psychological changes the plant inspires, they're much more akin to kava kava (without the liver toxicity) or coffee (a close relative of the plant, with the difference here being that fatalities from a kratom extract are unheard of whereas caffeine poisoning is well documented).

There seems to be some confusion that came about because kratom seems to alleviate some of the excruciating withdrawal effects that come along with "cold turkey" cessation of opiate use. This causes someone uninformed to think that kratom causes euphoric effects associated with opiates, which isn't reality. As well from this, some are lead to believe that there are some of the same dangers, specifically respiratory depression. This isn't the case, and kratom "overdoses" without other substances being involved are unheard of.

My personal experience is that the effects of kratom are self-limiting. Unlike opiates where X amount may result in a "buzz" and Y amount will result in respiratory depression and possibly death, X amount of kratom results in a mild but perceptible improvement in one's sense of well-being and Y amount results in a queasy stomach with no increase in beneficial effects. 

This same self limiting effect is undoubtedly partly responsible for kratom's reputation as a "cure" for opiate addiction. Ex-opiate users frequently state that kratom doesn't combine well with other drugs, opiates especially. It's not that kratom increases the lethality of said drugs, it simply makes them far less enjoyable. To put a complicated biological process in layman's terms, kratom blocks the avenues (receptors) that drugs use to produce their euphoric effects. This is why kratom overdoses are unheard of (receptors are blocked with harmless, plant based substance) and why kratom is considered by many to be a superior, safer option in contrast with Suboxone or methadone treatment (although I don't completely discount those treatments as viable forms of harm reduction as opposed to no treatment at all, or worse yet, incarceration).

documents.commentText: My name is John Kelly, and I've been taking Kratom for about 4-5 years off and on. I am troubled about the DEA classifying a non lethal plant as a schedule 1 drug. From my perspective its shows the DEA needs to do further research, and allow citizens to pursue our own paths to health. When I first heard of Kratom it had a negative reputation, then I looked further, and spoke with people firsthand, and soon found a totally different story. A story of how it has benefited people who otherwise were less than functional for various reasons from addiction to chronic pain. I began using it as more of a supplement for preventive health maintenance, taking about .1 to 2 grams of whole leaf daily, on average. I found a definite increase in my overall well being, less body aches, quicker recovery, I'm an active 52 year old, so that alone was incentive to continue, and improved sleep. I'll forget to take at times, or bring it with me when I travel, with no sign of withdraw, seem benign to me. So why on God's good earth would anyone want to prevent or inhibit a person from using this herb to further their quality of life is beyond me.  I hope this short letter provides insight about those of us who use Kratom and are better off for it. I implore you to reconsider this ban, it is unnecessary, and will do far more harm than good.

I see no reason why kratom should be scheduled. This is ridiculous. It's a harmless plant. You can't overdose on it and there are little to no negative reactions from use. I know people who say kratom has saved their lives. There's just no reason for this. 
It's a great alternative to opioids, which can be very dangerous and can ruin (and end) lives.

The DEA should stop any and all consideration of banning the herbal supplement kratom. There should be no prohibition. While the FDA is looking into it as well, most Americans have never heard of it. Why? Because there's NO REAL PROBLEM with it! Quite the contrary...

Kratom seems like a solution to a number of issues, including various forms of drug addiction and chronic pain. Plus, it can perform the pain-killing work of morphine without dangerously depressing breathing -- the way opioids do.

Here's how Kratom works... It uses a pathway that mediates many of the undesirable effects of traditional opioids such as constipation, respiratory depression. In fact, this knowledge is spurring additional research by pharmaceutical companies. http://bit.ly/2c8UTI6

About Kratom, a leading researcher notes... Thailand is considering legalizing kratom as a safer alternative for meth addicts. U.S. researchers are trying to study its potential to help opiate abusers kick the habit without withdrawal side effects. http://bit.ly/2c8SI7v

There are anecdotal reports of addiction risk. But it appears the addiction can be broken without withdrawal symptoms. Meanwhile, the painkillers currently being used are more addictive, dangerous, and harder to kick. Yet...

The FDA and DEA both appear ready to ban kratom and effectively kill research to further develop this substance. Is the DEA is running cover for a Big Pharma company that wants to monopolize kratom?

As I consider these actions by the FDA and DEA I'm forced to wonder -- WHAT ARE YOU PEOPLE SMOKING?

My name is Richard Bell. I have been involved in harm reduction since 1999. I live in Lucas County Ohio. Ohio is hard hit by the opiate crisis. We have four cities in the top 10 cities, with a populations over 400,000, for opiate overdoses.
Lucas County Ohio has 16 private detox beds and 16 public detox beds. The latest  estimates from the Lucas County Sheriffs Department estimates we have 10,000 active opiate addicts. At a recent opiate awareness event Sherriff Tharpe estimated it at over 15,000 based on statistics for arrests for DUI. Kratom is a safer alternative to heroin and or pharmaceuticals that are being abused while waiting to get into these limited spots. 
Kratom has been used for hundreds of years to help individuals to safely abstain from using opium and heroin. I have personally seen individuals turn their lives around.  There are 97 overdose deaths a day in the United States according to the Surgeon General. If Kratom is made illegal or made so restricted that it is unavailable to those adults in need there will be an increase in opiate overdose deaths. There will be increases in suicide from uncontrolled pain. 
We have a plant that has been helping addicts for hundreds of years safely. Restricting its use by adults would be sentencing individuals to death. Im not being dramatic, Im being a realist. There is no scientific data to support the banning of this beneficial plant. If there was the DEA would release the documents they used initially to start this counterintuitive measure.
