documents.commentText:
I am a 61 year old rheumatoid arthritis patient who suffers from chronic pain due to badly damaged joints in my wrists, hands, and cervical spine. While my physicians have offered prescriptions for various opioid pain medications, I prefer to avoid them because I find them too sedating to allow me to function in a job that requires clear thinking. documents.commentText:
To Whom It May Concern,

After years of suffering chronic pain, I recently discovered Mitragyna Speciosa, commonly known as the kratom leaf. Kratom is a natural supplement derived from the  tropical trees of Southeast Asia. Before explaining how my life has changed as a result, I should provide some background information as to my lifelong struggle with chronic and often debilitating pain. 

I was born with scoliosis, and suffered both chronic neck, back, and shoulder pain for as long as I can recall. I also have endometriosis, which significantly affects my ability to function for one to two weeks of each month. I was ultimately diagnosed with depression, anxiety, and attention-deficit disorder in addition to (and potentially resulting from) the near-constant pain. I became unable to work, and was granted Social Security Disability Insurance at 30 years old. Prior to this, I was employed at a residential music school for young adults with intellectual disabilities. The pain and resulting anxiety/depression became too much to manage, and I was given no choice but to leave after 8 years at the school. 

The following two years were spent going back and forth between appointments:  x-rays, physical therapy (3x/week), individual psychotherapy, OB-GYN appointments, chiropractic sessions, etc. Each of these were financed by state-funded health care, which cost tens of thousands of dollars per year. I personally spent hundreds on therapeutic massage, at-home electrotherapy, joint pain relief, acupressure pillows, and daily medication to manage my symptoms. For depression, I was prescribed (at different stages) Prozac, Wellbutrin, Zoloft, Lamictal, Clonazepam, and Methylphenidate for ADHD. I was also prescribed a low-dose estrogen birth control, to control endometriosis. I felt very little relief from my symptoms, and ultimately began to spend my days in bed, utterly useless to myself, my family, and society in general. Those around me (including medical professionals) encouraged me to try medical marijuana, but my tolerance was so low that it only exacerbated my anxiety. It was then suggested that I try a natural supplement known as kratom.

I had heard about kratom, but was dubious of any natural supplement that boasted not only pain relief, but focus, energy, and minimization of anxiety. After months went by with no reprieve from my pain, I asked myself: Why not try it? What could I possibly lose that I havent already lost? Though I read articles on the addiction potential, I was fully aware that much of what is presented online derives from personal opinion, and often leans towards catastrophic thinking and fear-mongering. I already knew what opiate withdrawal felt like, due to having been prescribed opiates for pain relief in the past. I now felt prepared to try something different, and would do so independently. Once the kratom arrived, I carefully measured 2 grams, and mixed it with water. It tasted like a cold, somewhat bitter tea, and I didn't have much hope for relief. Then, I gradually found myself unaware of the pain. For the first time, it seemed to naturally dissipate, as though the scoliosis and resulting disruption of my cervical spine were mere afterthoughts; distant memories rather than constant reminders. I did not feel high as some may suggest. Nor did I feel euphoric. I simply felt well enough to resume the activities of daily living that I had previously felt unable to do. 

There are questions about whether sudden termination of kratom use will result in withdrawal symptoms. I can attest to the fact that I did not personally experience these symptoms. As with any substance (or in this case natural supplement), a person will typically revert back to how he or she felt prior to having taken it. So do I feel unwell when I do not take kratom? Yes I do. But that is because I felt unwell for YEARS before discovering it. Recently, my anxiety has resurfaced in the form of kratom regulation in the United States. I must ask- what is the purpose of this? Is it easier to force people to take potentially damaging substances which have become increasingly difficult to obtain medically? Should we take kratom away from those who benefit for fear that a small percentage of individuals-already predisposed to addictive tendencies- may abuse it? The same argument could be said for alcohol or even cough syrup, but we still offer people the opportunity to demonstrate personal responsibility through safe use in moderation. 

Since I began taking kratom, I have resumed my degree (which I abandoned a decade ago). My hopes are to continue my path to wellness, and someday be less reliant on others to exist. I urge you to consider my story. I am a truth-seeker, with no immediate gain by writing this. Everybody deserves a quality of life, and kratom has been such an invaluable asset to so many people in our country.  Thank you for your time. I strongly appreciate your consideration of this matter.

documents.commentText:
To Whom It May Concern, 

I am a happily married mother of three young girls, all ranging in age from seven to less than two weeks old. My kind, compassionate, active and humorous husband has been struggling with a pinched nerve in his neck from a car accident since he was a young child. The pinched nerve is a medical condition that has hindered his ability to work, to play a more active role in our young girls' lives, and his capability to generally live a happy and pain-free life. On top of his chronic pain this wonderful man suffers from mild to severe anxiety. 

Due to his diagnosese he has been prescribed multiple medications in his doctors' various attempts to manage his anxiety and pain. The prescriptions range from Xanax and Valium to Percocet and Vicodin. The list of his prescribed medications continues in a seemingly endless pattern but I won't bore you with too many of the dark and disturbing details. As you can imagine, many of these prescribed medications treated some of the symptoms and conditions he suffered from, but at the expense of creating worse symptoms and conditions. These medications temporarily took away my husband's physical pain, but they also took away my husband. He became an addict. 

Recovering from his addiction has been a long and tedious road, and it continues with both its ups and downs. It's a hard balance when your only relief from unbearable pain is becoming a person your closest family and friends cannot recognize as their loved one. In this long and sometimes seemingly hopeless journey, there has been only one form of relief: Kratom. 

Kratom has offered my husband a solution to his chronic pain without the side effects of the drugs that had been previously prescribed to him. 'Side effects' seems too mild of a term to describe the way he has suffered from overdoses, withdrawals, drastic personality changes and multiple grand-mal seizures due to prescription medications. He is able to use Kratom to manage his pain without becoming lethargic and the worst version of himself. 

I have watched my husband suffer from his addictions, suffer from pain, suffer from suffocating anxiety, and he is the last person in the world who deserves to suffer. I know that it takes a tremendous amount of strength every single day to not become lethargic from prescription medications as a coping mechanism for his unwarranted suffering, because I see his strength everyday. He choses to be there for me and our kids but I know that without the opportunity to ease some of his chronic pain with Kratom this would not be a possibility. Kratom has honestly given me back the unbelievably kind-hearted and patient man I married. Kratom has given me back the man that prescribed drugs and medications and doctors took away from me. 

I began writing this to explain the impact that Kratom has had on my life. With everything that Kratom has given me, and done for my family, it seems impossible to put the positive impact Kratom has had on my family into words. For the DEA to consider classifying Kratom as a schedule 1 drug without further research into the benefits and positive solutions this plant has to offer is still simply mind boggling to me. I cannot beg enough for the DEA to reconsider this decision and conduct more studies about this plant and its impact on individuals and families who have suffered as mine has suffered. I will not stop fighting for my husband's right to live his life as pain free as possible. I will not stop fighting for Kratom to be readily available to him to ease his suffering. Nobody deserves a happy and healthy life more than my husband. And nobody should have the right or power to take that ability from him.

Without creating the withdrawals would have probably kept me out of school. Taking Kratom to get off narcotics  is the only reason I was able to stop and continue going to school with only minimal withdrawal symptoms.  I now take  Kratom three days a week which are Monday Wednesday and Friday. because of crate him I can function normally at school and be pain-free.
         Kratom is not addictive, and can be used to help people stop taking narcotics. It also helps with anxiety and depression. I suffer  from both, and Kratom allows me to function normally without pain. I was taking 3  l5mg Clonazapam for years, the switched to, 3 a day,10 mg Valium .  I also take Lexapro for depression, two 100 mg tablets a day .  Because of  Kratom, I no longer need to take any (Valium) anxiety medication, and my doctor cut my dose of Lexapro to only one 100 mg tablet a day. 
         Kratom  has been a godsend for me, and I know for a fact that the scientific research shows that there's hardly any negative side effects.   I know this because in my English comp to class ,  I wrote a research paper on Kratom.  I found all the scientific research and studies using Vincinnes University online library, particularly Academic Search Premier  database. I used 10 different academic and scientific sources to write this paper. Meaning I've read the research.

I met personally with my congressman yesterday about this particular topic. beg you, please do not make powderd  Kratom (Mitragyna-Speciosa)  illegal and hard to get.

I am a chronic pain sufferer- 28, underweight, active as I can be - with bulging discs and arthritis. Since removing opiates and beginning Tramadol, my pain wasn't covered or relieved, I was lethargic, and the medication makes me throw up easily from anything (too hot? Throw up. Too hungry? Throw up. Etc.) - then I found Kratom. My pain is controlled and I have no ill side effects. My stomach feels better and I feel like a functional member of society again. 
Please do not ban kratom. You are the same people that have begun strict laws on painkillers to the point that pain management patients can't control their pain any longer - and now you want this? This harmless, effective plant. If you ban kratom, you are taking away a significant option for the very same people that you have already taken options from. If you take everything we have - then what?
Thank you for your time.

documents.commentText:
I struggle with Multiple Sclerosis, a painful, at times debilitating, and potentially fatal disease for which there is no cure, and hardly even a treatment.  For those of us dealing with this horrific disease, there are essentially 3 options: 
1) Suffer indefinitely, unable to get through simple daily activities. 
2) Take opiate painkillers that are some of the most addictive substances on earth, which cause withdrawal symptoms worse than my disease itself, and can contribute to the behavior that is causing the opioid epidemic of which I'm sure you're well aware.
3) Take small amounts of kratom, a plant from Southeast Asia that is extremely effective for dulling minor to moderate aches and pains, isn't nearly as addictive as opiates, is cheap, and readily available.  

I am a productive, middle class American worker who wakes up in physical agony every day of my life, and kratom is what enables me to work my way through it.  I haven't missed a day of work, been forced to abandon plans with friends or family, canceled appointments, etc. since discovering this plant, and as I've learned through MS support groups online, mine is certainly not a unique story.  This plant, to so many of us with MS (and plenty of other diseases, I'm sure) has been an absolute revelation, one that has given us our very lives back, and the DEAs claim that it has no valid medical uses is one of ignorance, not science.  Banning this plant serves only to punish those of us who've already been punished enough.

documents.commentText:
To the FDA, et al.:

Please register my commentary regarding proposed regulation of Kratom, a natural product originating in various plants.
My interest is that of a concerned citizen who has two primary concerns - 
First - We have enough regulations covering natural products - I see no reason to regulate something that grows wild. If you wish to regulate, regulate concentration and combination with other substances which are not natural, i.e. drugs - thats your agency mandate, not to worry about what grows wild or under human cultivation.
Second - Several members of my family are chronic pain sufferers. They need access to natural alternatives to the synthetic pain killers and pharmaceutically enhanced  natural opium byproducts which are killing so many today. If you regulate Kratom, they will no longer have the option of trying something natural with less abuse potential.
I have other concerns a plenty, starting with the proposition that there ought not even be an FDA to begin with, but this isn't the place to assert such matters. Suffice it to say I am against regulation at the national level, and respectfully resist further expansion of these efforts on principle. Lets face it, America is sick to death of this, please stop. 
Thank you

documents.commentText:
Thanks for taking the time to read my comments, and hopefully answer my questions. I am a 29 year old, working, law abiding citizen. At age 24 I developed a chronic pain disorder that will be with me for life. I pursued all traditional forms of therapy and still work closely with my doctor for physical therapy, the occasional injection, etc. 
I would like to make it very clear that kratom doesn't replace modern medicine for people who are chronically ill. We still need our doctors. For my particular condition, opiates are not only undesirable, but completely ineffective for my condition. Its not that I need an opiate that is stronger - quite the opposite. I need something that modern medicine cannot give me. I do not need another opiate; I need nature, exercise, meditation, vitamins, and physical therapy. I need a balance of old and new medicine. I achieve pain relief that takes me through a work day, and has kept the ever daunting reality of disability at bay for now. I am still paying taxes, still paying into the system that keeps this country and the DEA themselves afloat. My choice to use kratom certainly does not hurt anyone else, and actually benefits society by allowing me to continue working and paying into the system. Without it, I would be nothing but a burden on the system.
I have read a lot about "15 deaths being associated with kratom". I would like to know how many of those people also had coffee in their system? Could caffeine intake not also be correlated with health issues? I would like to know how many of them were on SSRI's? I would also like to see some type of scientific evidence that can explain visually, how kratoms alkaloids caused anything to go awry in their bodies. Can you please have an expert paint a picture for us, and detail how it affects the body and what happens, leading to death? I am very curious, as the 100000 people that I interact with are alive and well.
Further, I would like to know what exactly the goal is with a kratom ban? If there is nothing to protect us from, than what is the purpose? 
Thank you for taking the time to read my commentary and questions. I do not wish to come across as rude, but since this decision will impact the rest of my life, I would like to know that its being made only after the most sound research from a non-biased third party. 
Sincerely,,
Anonymous tax payer from MA

documents.commentText: I was diagnosed with Paranoid Schizophrenia, Paranoid, Schizoid and Depressive Personality disorders, later consolidated somewhat to Schizoaffective disorder (Schizophrenia + Depression) along with the personality disorders in 2010 after having battled these illnesses most of my adult life. As a child I was bullied and dehumanized consistently by my peers, I do not know if this was a symptom of my problems or a cause. All I know is the harsh anti-psychotics I was put on after I went into the hospital following a suicide attempt that (lucky for me) my hallucinations and voices helped stop, as "they" did not wish me dead at that time, and allayed my fears of hospitalization. Once I was out things were not so good. I was on a dopamine antagonist even though I was severely depressed. Any physician should understand what a mess that is.  My psychiatrist heard my same complaints of constant depression, lack of willpower to do anything, and chronic insomnia for five years and just kept writing the same scripts. Things have gotten better for me with two new psychiatrists in the span of a year. One thing I must mention is that persistent insomnia is one of my greater battles, it determines whether my next day will be livable or totally suck. I was recommended Kratom by a Naturopathic Doctor, whom my state does not recognize, and while using it only twice a day I was definitely doing better. I could be energized during the day and actually do things like write fiction, my only calling, and in the evening I could gradually get tired and fall asleep with little outside management. This compared to without it when I'd sleep or lie down 18 hours a day and do nothing more than play video games for an hour or two. I had to quit Kratom after a few months because my insurance of course would not cover it even though they can cover 30 pills of Latuda, or pharmacological Satan as I call it, at $1155 dollars a bottle. Kratom reduces all my symptoms from anxiety to depression, prevents me from using alcohol to fall asleep, and altogether gives me a greater quality of life. I have not done it in a few years but with the businesses scared and cutting prices I may actually be able to afford it again. I only ever took it twice a day as a tea, sometimes for months and the only side effects were mild constipation followed by very mild diarrhea when I stopped. Nothing of consequence, in other words. Do not schedule this plant as you will hurt many. I know you are in bed with the Pharma industry but their pills cause only early death (look up Latuda's side effects) while this plant immensely helped my quality of life. I have never OD'd and never suffered from it. I would personally take a natural plant any day over the junk the pharma companies are spitting out without even understanding what their true effects are. We must see a sea change in this country. Let what's natural heal us, not the unnatural that costs billions to create. Please allow me to be one of the people you can proclaim "healed" by Kratom. If it becomes illegal that will just be one more excellent answer to my problems gone.

documents.commentText:
Please, listen to what I have to say. My name is Kristen, and after being pregnant, or breastfeeding for 5 years straight, I found Kratom. After I weaned my last child I became sad and lethargic. At the time I wasn't quite sure whether I was sad that I weaned, or whether I was depressed due to hormone fluctuations. I visited my OBGYN and explained how I was feeling, and they prescribed Zoloft. I know that Zoloft is a godsend to many people, that was not the case with me. It made me feel 100x worse and when I decided I would just stop taking it the symptoms were unbearable. I was having electrocution feelings and severe migraines. Migraines are pretty typical with me, have been since the age of nine. I decided to look for natural remedies for depression and migraines. After much online searching I came across Kratom. I ordered myself some and waited. The shipment arrived and I took half a teaspoon, my life has been better ever since. I fairly quickly got over the sad feeling a few weeks later, making me think it was a mild depression due to hormone fluctuations. This was two years ago. I still take Kratom on a daily basis and have only had FOUR migraines in two years. I couldn't be happier. I am flabbergasted that Kratom is made out to be some big bad heroin/cocaine cross addictive drug. That's very misleading and false. Kratom is addictive, just like my two coffees per day. Coffees also help with my migraines, but for maintenance of my migraines Kratom is my go-to plant. It's all natural, doesn't alter your feelings or energy levels and works subtly but wonderfully. I stopped taking Kratom for two months to try other herbals and my migraines came back with a vengeance. There absolutely was not no severe withdrawal symptoms. For me, I got the typical symptoms I get when I don't drink coffee. I was tired, headaches, not sleeping well, or over sleeping. These symptoms were mainly gone in about three days. For me coffees withdrawals last well over a week. This plant isn't bad. I have no idea why it got a bad rap. My only assumption is the Dr. Phil show that aired about Kratom. Unbelievable. It was then I realized that people believe whatever the TV tells them. It's a simple as having a few people go and try it. You will see that the misinformation is widespread. It's a simple plant. It helps so many people. So, PLEASE don't do this to us. We want to have the choice to treat ailments naturally. Have a wonderful day, and I hope you truly research and see that it's an amazing medicinal plant.  It's not killing people and it's not hurting people. Yes, some people have died with Kratom in their system, but they've also had antidepressants, alcohol and other drugs in their systems. There's no way it was Kratom alone. Every years tens of thousands of people die from prescription related deaths. Please, don't make us take prescriptions that don't agree with our body.   

Have a wonderful day,

Kristen DeWitt

documents.commentText:
I am a medical doctor, a general surgeon by training. I have considerable experience with pain management and the treatment of addiction. I have personal experience with the use of Kratom. I first began taking Kratom just over 1 year ago, for the treatment of pain arising from bilateral Achilles tendinosis. Before taking Kratom, I was taking a maximum dose of ibuprofen. I have a brief history of opiate addiction and would not allow myself to take prescription opiates. I knew I would be at risk for recurrent addiction and require escalating doses. The pain relief has been excellent and I have maintained my dosing schedule for the past year. I also have a history of depression that was never treated successfully with prescription pharmaceuticals. With Kratom, I have noted additional benefits in the area of mood stabilization, with an overall Improvement in my general feeling of well-being. I know that I could very easily be on 4 or more different prescription medications for the treatment of my orthopedic problem and depression. I doubt that their use would result in the current quality of life that I enjoy with Kratom. I must  point out that each specific  effect  of Kratom is subtle at most. There is no specific effect that  is anymore  significant  then other  effective herbal remedies. There is absolutely no opioid-like euphoric effect. For that reason the addiction potential is nonexistent. For me, it is simply safer than chronic high dosages of ibuprofen. Therefore, my personal experience with Kratom has been excellent.

As mentioned above, I have experience in the treatment of addiction. Without going into detail, I believe that Kratom is an excellent aid for someone experiencing opiate withdrawal. I would be happy to explain this further if requested.

I believe that the Kratom available from reputable sources, ie coming straight from nature, offers a complex and extremely well-balanced blend of positive benefits, not matched by any available prescription pharmaceutical or combination of such. I strongly support further research into its chemical composition, the varieties of available strains and their medicinal benefits.

I have reviewed the available data on the reported deaths and complications the DEA attributes to Kratom. I absolutely believe that it is not only safe but also extremely beneficial and should remain available to the general public. It is absolutely absurd to place it in the same category as the current schedule I drugs. I am aware of innumerable stories of other people benefitting tremendously from Kratom.

I strongly encourage the DEA to refrain from scheduling Kratom.

Sincerely,
Brandt Lapschies, MD

documents.commentText: Hello, my name is Evan Michael Biter. As a previous opiate addict, I found kratom to be the best way to relieve all withdrawal symptoms. I have tried drug rehabilitation of all types. The one that worked without causing serious side effects and adding more vices to my list was kratom. I'd mix it with maple syrup. Usually a couple tablespoons to every 3 grams of dried leaf powder. I started off taking up to 10 grams per dose 2 times daily. Usually daily. Some days, i didn't feel the need to redose. People confuse the real nature and effects of this plant because of the horror stories that are posted online. I'm here to tell you that kratom is not this nightmare plant that needs banned by our newly and overly conservative government. Kratom has never killed a human being. That is a fact. Ill effects can happen, but they are mild at best. I'm here to spread the news to the reactive thinking humans of the great country I live in. Being proactive in my thought process and being conscious and rational at all times is necessary to progress as mankind. By banning this natural remedy, not "drug" nor "substance",  you are taking lives away from the people of this country. This should be promoted not made unobtainable by our people. Kratom in its natural form is the only way it should be legal. Ban the extracts. Ban the chemical form of mitragynine and its fellow alkaloids. Keep these leaves and the powder form open to us as a supplement to benefit our health. Do not control it and let the private sector turn this into another chemical that causes overdoses due to their inability to correctly distribute such chemicals that affect the central nervous system. Kratom has never caused a death because kratom on its own has a variety of alkaloids at low potency. When kept as a powder it is hard to consume more than 10 grams of it. Even in its capsule form. I'm a 22-year-old male from the northeast area of the United States. I have my index and middle fingers on the pulse of the youth of this country. I have nephews and nieces between the ages of 1 month and 15 years old. Trust me when i say that the youth that are doing drugs, aren't looking to go through the internet to purchase this bitter and rough powdered leaf and down 40 grams to get high.  That dose is far more likely to cause intense nausea and a headache than it is to cause any type of rush. At its core, pure, without any additives, kratom relieves anxiety, stress, and balances one's mood at its best dose of 7 grams. I'm 220 pounds so I take more than most to get the best effects. I've never had the urge to try more than 10 grams. It's mellow at its peak and after that its not even worth taking more because of the side effects. None of which, by the way, are dangerous. It might make you vomit or very itchy, but it will not make you want more. I've taken it on and off to deal with the downs of this rollercoaster we call life. I felt level headed, rational, free from basic stress and anxiety, and as if I could finally think clearly for the first time in my life while being able to handle the pains of being on my feet at work for sometimes 10 hours per day, 7 days a week. You're making a mistake if you ban kratom. It helps addicts in remission live and be productive citizens because kratom eliminates the feeling of needing heroin, oxycontin, morphine, or even suboxone. If place a ban on unaltered kratom powder, you're only hurting the society you work so hard for. Please excuse my language but when you are done traveling to D.C. and are feeling beaten down by the country you work your ass off for while trying to keep out freedoms, sit down, and take 5 grams of the powder and see what it does for yourself while its legal instead of basing your laws on perspectives of perspectives. Put yourself in our shoes and hold us undesirables in your hearts... Because some of us work hard to become desirable and reinstill ambition in our lives and this PLANT... It helps. It truly and honestly works. If its not fatal, why the rush to ban it, make it into a pure chemical form to see what it does, and let the private big pharma corporations market it as a new and manmade dangerous narcotic. Leave this plant alone, and you will save lives in more ways than one. Thank you for your time. I appreciate everyone who reads this and I am for trying to make better lives out of the broken souls of the people in this country. With a clean record, clean nose, and clean heart, I put my faith into you all.

documents.commentText:
Dear DEA Decision Makers:

The following is a testimonial from the perspective of a non-Kratom user, based upon experience with and observations of my long-term partner of 10 years.  Given the nature of the topic, I would like to withhold my personal identifying information from the public in order to protect my professional reputation.  That being said, I am willing to be portrayed as Stephanie G., Pennsylvania to offer some credibility to my statement.

My partner has suffered from chronic pain for the past 15 years.  This is a result of a combination of bilateral meniscal tears in his knees due to a dirtbiking accident in his teens; and years of hard labor, working in the carpentry and electrical trades in extreme conditions.

He was thoroughly vetted by his primary care physician, who has prescribed multiple different NSAIDs that did not relieve the pain.  To seek other methods of relief, he obtained referrals to both orthopedic surgeons and pain management physicians.  These practitioners also prescribed oral and topical NSAIDs, and, at other times, oral or injectable steroids.  MRI imaging revealed no repairable condition, but his pain persists despite treatment.

In addition to chronic pain, he also suffers from debilitating anxiety.  Again, he has been prescribed several different medications, ranging from antidepressants to antipsychotics and anxiolytics.  At best, some of these took the edge off, and at worst, muddled his consciousness and restricted his ability to function.

Frustrated with repeated treatment failures, he began to seek alternative therapies to relieve his pain.  He found Kratom, and perused every bit of information he could find about it.  After locating a reputable distributor, he began trying different strains.  Please understand how sincere I am when I say that Kratom has made a more positive effect on his life than any of the dozens of prescribed medications that conventional medicine relies on.  With Kratom, the pain and the anxiety wash away, leaving his mind clear and his body active.

I am not speaking on behalf of an addict.  I am describing the hardworking man that rises long before dawn to put in 8 to 12 hours of hard work in sweltering summer heat and freezing winter cold.  The doting father that comes home to spend time with our 5-year-old son, and strives to teach him everything he can to be sure he grows up to be an honorable, respectful member of society.  There is no evidence of addictive or immoral behavior, by any definition of the terms.  He does not drink, and he does not do drugs.

He takes Kratom to live a normal life, and I plead with you as a partner and a mother  do not rob our family of the one thing that lets him be happy and comfortable.

documents.commentText:
I am an ordained Christian pastor who has 35 years of parish experience. During that time I have been very involved in helping many addicts. I write regarding the status of the herb Kratom.

In recent years, I have helped many people get off of prescription drug addictions, primarily opioids.  Withdrawal from opioid addiction is a horrible, horrible experience.  I went through it once after having to be on a pain killer for nearly a year due to a severe chronic sinus problem.  Fortunately, we were able to correct my problem with surgery and I no longer need medication.  But the physical withdrawal was dreadful.  The medications my doctor prescribed to "help" the withdrawal did very little - almost nothing in fact.

After that experience, I learned that Kratom could be used to alleviate the withdrawal symptoms - it seems to be better than any other for this use.  I have recommended it now to a number of people who are getting off of prescription opioids, and it has been remarkably successful.  It is now the "go to" street approach for many getting off opioids, with very limited side effects.  Certainly none of the problems associated with methadone, etc.

I did quite a bit of research myself before recommending this as an avenue for others to use.  The small number of incidents where problems occurred (emergency room visits) seemed almost entirely to be confused by concurrent use of "designer party drugs" in addition to the Kratom - drugs which are known to cause seizures, etc.  While my research was anecdotal, I could not find an incident where someone had a serious problem that was clearly the result of reasonable Kratom consumption alone.  

The FDA and DEA must not ban or heavily regulate this hugely beneficial herb, particularly not in a sudden way.  To do so will leave thousands with no way to effectively get off of opioids.  Any such decision must be based on SCIENCE, not on anecdote or scaremongering.  THAT SCIENCE IS CURRENTLY NOT IN PLACE. Even placing Kratom on Schedule 2 as a prescription without several months of warning will create a vacuum until the standard medical/pharmacy pipeline is figured out.  And "big pharma" will have little interest in providing Kratom.

I urge you to set up proper scientific studies and undertake the SCIENCE that is needed here, and to make any decision about changing the categorization of the herb based on the research.  I believe firmly that such research will reveal a number of beneficial uses of Kratom for chronic pain relief, but also document the hugely useful method of combating our current epidemic of opioid addiction.  Right now, in the midst of this epidemic, is NOT the time to remove one of the most effective methods of coping with withdrawal.

documents.commentText:
First off, thank you for taking the time to listen to the input of the public on this matter.

I have been taking kratom for about 2 or 3 years now, with some time off in between but consistently for the past 4 months. To be specific, about 2.5 to 7.5 grams spaced evenly through-out the day.

Kratom is a tool people use to help better themselves, whether it be relieving pain, helping with anxiety, improving mood, or even just a nice energy for the day.

Kratom is safe, as people have been taking it for thousands of years, with any negative effects being comparable to drinking to much caffeine.

Kratom has saved many people. For some, it is the only way to stop the use of hard drugs, such as heroin or prescription painkillers. With out kratom, these people have nowhere else to turn but the very drugs that are killing them.

Kratom is no worse, and in fact safer, than alcohol and tobacco, and should be treated as such.

Please hear what the people have to say and remember that more harm than good will come of a ban.

Thank you.

documents.commentText:
I am a 40 year old IT Professional.

Kratom should not be listed as a Schedule 1 controlled substance.

I started using Kratom about two years ago. Around 6 years ago I was diagnosed with Lyme Disease which was reported to the CDC. I did receive the proper antibiotic regimen which greatly improved my health; however, I still had several lingering symptoms. Working with my doctor, I went through several pain, inflammation, and anxiety medications that would subside my symptoms but did not give any further benefit. My days were numb, forgetful, and groggy. I had problems sleeping, grew fat and lazy, and didn't function at 100%. I did not feel like a productive member of society, so I went looking for alternatives. I worked with a naturopath to find natural alternative cures to my symptoms. After a couple of years of experimenting with various supplements, exercises, and diets, I came across Kratom. Since using Kratom I have been able to become healthy again. I am a father, a great employee, and a husband again. I'm able to control my symptoms, and keep them at bay. I have been able to get regular sleep, can function better at work, be able to keep up with my children, and help out my family when needed. I know exactly where I would be without the use of Kratom today, stuck in a rut while constantly band-aiding multiple symptoms without resolving the root of the problem and getting myself healthy. 

Kratom has helped me greatly and I've heard several stories about it helping others. Kratom should remain available while further tests / studies are done, so that so many like me can remain healthy and productive. I would hope to see eventually that certain controls are put in place by the FDA, and it sold as a typical supplement.

documents.commentText:
I am a PhD. biochemist. 

Kratom possesses a high likelihood of creating hepatic (liver) damage. There are many anecdotal case reports on internet forums and other online communities of acute hepatitis, hepatic cholestasis, and other serious liver conditions developing in very close correlation (bordering on causation - but there is a lack of controlled research) with kratom use. 

Kratom may not cause hepatotoxicity in all users, but the prevalence of anecdotal reports on the internet, my personal experience trying it (resulting each time in upper right quadrant pain and elevated liver enzymes), is concerning. This substance should not be allowed to the public freely. Especially not in "head shops" and other locations that sell "legal highs."

There have been rat and mouse studies done on kratom which directly show damage to liver cells. 

The talk about kratom "saving lives" and helping people is a lame excuse to keep a legal high, legal. Claiming that it is of plant origin is not a good reason to maintain its legality. There are many naturally occurring plants that are exceptionally toxic, and many man made chemicals which are exceptionally benign. 

There is no quality control surrounding kratom. The shops that sell it are merely capitalizing on a high margin, addictive substance. Users think they are doing themselves a favor because kratom is "natural," but that is not good logic for assuming it has not toxicology concerns. 

Moreover, people are just trading their other addictions for kratom addiction. The majority of people pressuring the DEA to keep kratom unscheduled, are selling it, or addicted to it. People can potentially develop irreversible damage to their vital organs by using this, all the while thinking they are doing something healthy. 

The drug interactions between kratom and other substances and prescription medication are unknown. This is highly dangerous, as kratom has more than one (in fact, many) active alkaloids. 

If kratom is to be sold, it should be studied, and then forced to adhere to rigorous quality control standards. People may be ingesting leaf powder (which is all coming from Southeast Asia) that has pesticides, mold, bacteria, or other toxins present.

I have not personally used Kratom or purchased it. However, after listening to Chris Bell and doing some independant research of my own I have found that Kratom has a massive potential for helping people deal with opioid withdrawal. Making this drug illegal would cripple efforts to study it and cause a significant number of people to turn back to opioid addiction without this option. 

It is my belief that the only crime Kratom is guilty of is having a shitty name. When someone says Kratom the first images that come to my mind are eastern europeans in some Chernobyl type housing project injecting themselves with this stuff. But, that isn't the case. Kratom isn't sending people into crazy highs or a drugged out state. Instead most users seem to agree that it acts like a 5 hour energy shot combined with advil. There is nothing dangerous that results from this drug at least not at first glance. Long term affects aren't as clear so more research is necessary. 

Please do not make something illegal without at least researching it first. I understand that there are claims it has killed people, but those claims need to be investigated more thoroughly. Besides overdoses on opioids kill millions more than the fifteen or so anecdotal accounts credited to Kratom. 

I'm not sure whose job it is to read these comments or what your personal views are on this matter. But, please do two things. 
First, take a break from reading these comments I'm sure they are very repetitive. 
Second, have an open mind and try not to get sick of us comment writers. I'm sure we sound annoying as hell, but the intent behind the comments is a good one.

documents.commentText: I am a 37 year old small business owner (my business produces custom software and web site infrastructure for companies).  I discovered kratom about 6 years ago.  After doing research into the nature of the substance and its mechanisms of action, I gave it a try.  I never experienced any sort of 'high' similar to what I am only familiar with from the Vicodin I was prescribed when I had my wisdom teeth removed (and once when I hurt my back).  I did, however, feel more energetic and motivated like I do when I drink caffeinated beverages, but without the 'jittery' feeling.  This has been a great benefit as I have gone through the process of starting my own business.  Most notably, it does not interfere with my thinking, something which is of the utmost importance to me.  I do not consume alcohol or other intoxicants because of their mental effects.  Even in a relaxed setting or for entertainment, I simply do not like anything which degrades my ability to reason.  I was surprised when the DEA announced their intent to make kratom a Schedule I substance through abuse of their power to do so under 'emergency' conditions.  There is clearly no emergency whatsoever in terms of kratom.  Those powers were used appropriately when synthetic cathinones ('bath salts') were scheduled.  But in the case of kratom, harm is non-existent.  I do not insist that no harm could ever be found, but that is clearly something which has not happened yet.  The deaths that the DEA reported in their motion as kratom being "involved" with were all, to a one, concerned with people who died with cocktails of many different drugs in their systems.  Not a single one of them could be argued by an honest person to have been unlikely had kratom been omitted from the mix.  Research also does not support this, showing that kratom does not contain an agonist of the specific opioid receptors which result in respiratory system depression.  Unless or until legitimate peer-reviewed research shows a clear health threat greater than all legal substances, I can not support scheduling kratom (or any other substance for that matter, that standard applies across the board).

documents.commentText:
Some Reasons Why Kratom Should Not Be Illegal
*Illegalizing Kratom will deprive the American people of their right to help themselves by stopping the war on opium addiction. Kratom is a natural herb that is very close to, but different enough from the molecular composition of opium that it doesn't get you high like opiates do, is non-addictive, inexpensive and allows heroin and other opiate addicted people to kick the habit with no withdrawals and minimizes the craving for the drug. It is all natural and has no negative side effects, is non- addictive and it is also a very effective natural treatment for breathing ailments such as asthma and insomnia and anxiety disorder. In a nutshell the hardest heroin user can switch to Kratom with no withdrawals and quit after 2 weeks with no cravings. The problem is it's natural, non- addictive, it gets people off the pharmaceutical tit and the street drugs and there's no money to be made from it, much like many other natural, but effective cures and treatments as has recently come to light with cancer.
*There are numerous problems for the pharmaceutical and heroin industry if Kratom is allowed to continue to be sold.  Because it is gaining popularity with people who want to get off insomnia and anxiety medication and pain killers, heroin and other addictive and unhealthy drugs rather than treat themselves with addictive, expensive and dangerous pharmaceutical drugs it is being illegalized and turning many law abiding sick people who choose to treat their illnesses with natural, inexpensive and healthy herbs into felony criminals.
*In the pharmaceutical world there are two drugs, which are basically the same, but one prescription has two drugs for treating opiate addiction. They are suboxone, which contains the strongest known opiate subutex and naloxone. Subutex is the Opiod and naloxone nullifies the effects of all other opiates accept subutex, and the other prescription is plain subutex. Subutex is acknowledged as the most addictive opiate or opioid in the world, more so than herion and oxycontin or oxycodone. But it is the medical worlds main alternative to heroin, oxycodone,  oxycontin and hydrocodone addiction. They switch the addicts to a more expensive and more addictive drug and call it pharmaceutical rehabilitation.
*The reason I keep bringing up subutex and suboxone is that it is a large part of why there's so much opposition to illegalizing kratom. I used to have a roommate who was a heroin addict for 20 years. After getting out of prison he went to a doctor and got a prescription. The doctor visit was $300 and the prescription for 90 8mg tablets of suboxone  was about $300, My roommate was unemployed and just out of prison, but he got the doctor's appointment and prescription and it continued for years. The only way he could afford to pay the doctor, the prescription, rent and other bills was by selling his extra suboxone pills for $20 each. 
*The average prescription for suboxone or subutex is 90 to 120 tablets of 8 milligrams that cost between $250and $400 a month.  Each tablet is equal to about 1 gram of high quality heroin. The hardest addict can't use more than 1 to 2 tablets of subutex or suboxone per day. It costs $250 to $300 for the doctor's office visit each month and $250 to $400 for the prescription for every month. It is well known to everyone inside and outside the medical community that the only way 95% of jobless and homeless patients can afford this drug is to sell it to other drug addicts, especially since it is impossible that any human could take and feel the effects of even half of this standard prescription.
*Before the U.S. invaded Afghanistan they grew and produced no opium, it was a death penalty offence. Since the U.S government conquered Afghanistan, they have not only become the number 1 producer of opium in the world, but they produce more than the rest of the world combined. To understand this you must know that many of our soldiers spend their tours protecting the poppy fields of the drug lords. Look it up on Yahoo and YouTube to see countless soldiers' testimonials and their objections to aiding this insidious business.
*I can't prove who is behind the heroin trade, but some group with the power to control our military is and they will definitely profit from the illegalization of Kratom. If you have a family member or someone you care about who is or has been addicted to an opiate drug, please, contact you legislatures, go to websites and sign petitions to stop this illegal ban on this natural cure of one of the most destructive plagues in our world.

documents.commentText:
Hello. I have been permanently disabled and on SSI since 1993. I want to offer you a slightly different perspective on the Kratom ban and what it means to government money. My 23 diagnoses are not material here. My 40+ different pain medications and supplements throughout that time are also not important. This... is:

I have benefited from kratom's alkoloid properties for chronic, debilitating pain for almost one year now. I have successfully postponed additional surgeries intended to help in relieving more pain (very small chances for very expensive, government paid procedures). Where I used to spend up to 85% of my life in bed or on the sofa incapacitated, I now run errands, clean my home, help my neighbors, have a garden and even went on a camping trip. Before the September ban announcement, I was looking for employment, and to begin the process of ending SSI and medicare benefits. I was looking to become a part of my community again. I was no longer bogged down with prescribed narcotics that make me high, addicted and dysfunctional. I am under several Dr's care, who are aware that I have safely withdrawn from and ceased the use of prescription narcotics and are supportive in managing my health and all of its improvements through our new health plan. 

Because I was no longer bound to bed/sofa, I became more physically active, lost weight, and built up core muscles which are crucial to my particular disabilities. I was getting better as a side effect to kratom, not just "managing" my pain from a depressing indoor prison. Please fund testing, make it available for research and regulate for the safe purchase a supplemental tea that has the potential to not only help individuals like myself, but potentially benefit the federal balances as well.

Id like to add that I searched out healthier options to my health plan after I was told I needed to have a morphine pump implanted into my body, forcing me to take drugs even if I didnt want them. documents.commentText: Morphine is schedule 2 because of its use as an analgesic. Heroin is just diacetyl morphine, meaning it has added acetyl groups. It's actually used in the UK for the same purpose. Moreover, kratom is not like heroin and morphine in that it has more selectivity to delta opioid receptors leading to weaker, less addictive, and less harmful effects. Don't let your ignorance lead to the miscategorization of a drug that has helped tens of thousands.

Jose Robles

documents.commentText:
Mr. Rosenberg, Acting Administrator of the Drug Enforcement Agency , I am requesting your reconsideration to classify Kratom as Schedule I under the Controlled Substances  Act so the two main components can be evaluated for possible medicinal usage.

It is my understanding that with Schedule I Classification, there is supposed to be no medical use. Yet the National Institute of Health (NIH) Biomedical Research Excellence (in partnership with the Universities of Massachusetts and Mississippi) gave two grants to a team led by Chris McCurdy to investigate the use of Kratom as a remedy for opioid withdrawal. Preliminary scientific analysis shows that Kratom could offer substantial harm reduction, considering more than 28,000 deaths in 2014 alone from accidental overdoses of opioids including legal painkillers and illegal drugs like heroin. Mitragynine Pseudoindoxyl,compounds derived from the active ingredients in kratom (mitragynine) look promising.  The compounds appeared to more effectively relieve pain in mice, compared to morphine, without many of the dangers and unpleasant effects caused by opioids. Also, mitragynine pseudoindoxyl developed analgesic tolerance more slowly than morphine, showed limited physical dependence, reduced respiratory depression, and reduced constipation. This study led the researchers to apply for a patent identifying the Kratom extract, mitragynine, as a useful treatment for other addictive drugs besides opiate derivatives.  In another article, I read that there are at least three patents pending for medical uses for the Kratom derivative. I can't remember all sources, but one was Larry Greenmeier, Technology Editor of the Scientific American. September 30, 2013 and another source was The Journal of Medicinal Chemistry,a study conducted by Susruta Majumdar, PhD, assistant attending chemist at the Memorial Sloan Kettering Cancer Center. If kratom remains classified as Schedule I, researchers would have to apply for a Schedule I research license and hope that the DEA would be able to supply enough quality kratom to all of those hoping to study it, although it is unclear how that would occur. And it takes five years to grow the plant in a lab setting.

I have not forgotten the 15 known deaths related to kratom between 2014 and 2016, stated by the DEA. I read that two partners of the law firm, Hogan Lovells, representing the American Kratom Association (AKA) had serious concern over the 30 fatalities that the DEA had linked to kratom possession or ingestion. After further review of the reports, it was determined that Kratom alone was not the cause of the 30 deaths. 

Although you asked for facts instead of anecdotal remarks or stories, I will try to make it short. I am a 62 year old caucasian female and my occupation was Registered Diagnostic Medical Sonographer, also registered in Xray Technology and Mammography for approximately 30 years. In 2009 I lost my job because of episodic memory lapses and cognitive impairment. I was having skeletal pain which started several years earlier. After I lost my job, I was diagnosed with Fibromyalgia. The IBS, sleep apnea, insomnia and polyneuropathy followed. I had been on Norco, an opiate-based prescription medication for more than several years when my pain management specialist discontinued the listed painkiller. Since April 2016, I am in daily pain with the exception of three days in the past 30 day period. After reading a few Internet blogs, I chose to try Kratom. I have never smoked pot or taken any illegal drugs. Kratom, when I take it, some of my pain is relieved and I don't experience any euphoric "high". If there was no kratom, I planned to drive to the beach in another state and just stop eating and drinking water. I have no quality of life when I am in pain! I have tried other Fibromyalgia medications and complementary therapies without success, so the remaining options are miniscule. Based on 2011 statistics, I am just one of 100 million U.S. adults, living with chronic pain. Kratom helps relieve pain.
         
Mr. Rosenberg, thank you for taking the time to read my comment. If you have already decided  that Kratom is as dangerous as heroin and LSD, again I ask you, please reconsider.

documents.commentText:
I understand the need for certain substances to be properly regulated to help protect the public as a whole. Heroin and methamphetamines are two primary examples of drugs that should be properly regulated to help protect the public and our society. 

That being said, the government should not unreasonably restrict substances that haven't been shown to be significantly detrimental and have been shown to have significant benefits. 

This is the case with Kratom. It has been shown to reduce/eliminate the withdrawal effects of opiate abuse while being much safer and less addictive. This has allowed many opiate addicts to better their lives, deal with pain, and stop using opiates. 

Little to no one is claiming that no studies should be done on Kratom. I can confidently speak to the fact that everyone i have spoken to believes proper trials and studies should be conducted to better determine its uses and dangers. That being said, since it has been generally known to have little dangers and significant benefits, scheduling it as schedule 1 is ludicrous. Not only will this prevent people who may seriously need it from getting it (such as opiate addicts), but it also prevents studies from easily being done on it and will likely lead to it being permanently schedule 1 despite its legitimate uses. 

All of this is especially relevant considering the growing opiate addiction and abuse epidemic that is present in many (especially central) states of America. 

So with all of this in mind, scheduling Kratom as schedule 1 is unreasonable. Instead it should be scheduled as 2 (or more, ie schedule 3 or 4 or etc.) so that trails may be done to properly determine its effectiveness while people who are still in need of it are able to get it so they don't instead turn to opiate abuse again.

documents.commentText:
I cannot even begin to explain what repercussions the DEA's ban on Mitragyna speciosa, Kratom, will have on my life. I am a chronic pain sufferer - costochondritis, a dislocated/popping floating rib on my left side, reversal of cervical lordosis, and fibromyalgia. Not until I found this incredible, healing plant was I able to live without pain, but also without dependency or addiction. Painkillers stop working and require a higher amount for pain relief. They form physical, as well as psychological dependency. Painkillers and pharmaceuticals also harbor incredibly high incident rates and deaths by accidental overdoses. On another note, it is so wonderful and convenient to use Kratom as an herbal and all-natural pain remedy without needing a prescription for it. Many people have Kratom plants, which they pick the leaves off of. Nature is a beautiful thing, and when we bring in the question of making this wonderful, natural plant's leaves into a synthetic prescription drug, issues will arise. Kratom must be kept legal, and there is no doubt in any of our minds as we fight for the right to Kratom that if scientific research was conducted, the results would be in the plant's favor. 

I have been taking Kratom daily for many years. Due to other gastrointestinal medical conditions, painkillers caused constipation and terrible side effects. I wish I could have a video diary chronicling my daily struggles pre and post Kratom. This plant is ABSOLUTELY medicinal by nature, yet mild enough to where one can continue performing work and daily tasks without any of the terrible side effects of pharmaceuticals. Those who take Kratom truly cannot comprehend how or why this plant can even remotely be questioned. It is the equivalent of having melatonin or chamomile for insomnia. Mitragyna speciosa (Kratom) is a tropical evergreen tree in the coffee family (Rubiaceae). With this logic, coffee should also then be banned by the DEA.

I CANNOT believe the DEA would like to schedule this plant in the same category as heroin and cannabis. Cannabis is now legal in certain states, yet even cannabis has an incredibly powerful effect and a high from its THC content. There is absolutely no high with Kratom. 

There are many individuals who abuse anything they can get their hands on. Our very cleaning products are abused through huffing. Nutmeg has psychedelic properties if ingested in large quantities. This fight is NOT about Kratom being "dangerous," but about a mindset and an understanding that is incredibly lacking. I can go on and on... 
Please take a moment to search "IAmKratom" on YouTube, and watch the thousands of videos of sufferers who have found relief through this natural herb. 

Please, please help those who responsibly use Mitragyna speciosa, along with chamomile, sage, and other healing herbs. This will have devastating effects on those whom take this plant for its medicinal purposes. The concern should be on DRUGS such as bath salts, K2, and other synthetics sold at head shops, if we don't want zombies running around consuming other's faces. NOT Kratom.

documents.commentText:
Thank you for putting off the emergency scheduling long enough to allow public commentary.  

My wife suffers chronic stabbing pelvic pain due to endometriosis. Her doctor had her on norco and it wasn't helping and after doing some DNA testing she determined that her body does not metabolize opiates very well. That is why it helps with some of her pain like toothaches, but doesn't even touch the stabbing sensation she feels every day of every month because of her incurable condition. Even hysterectomies do not always take away endo because it can spread to intestines, and even other organs like the lungs. It causes legions and scar tissue everywhere and is extremely painful. She had a surgery that didn't help at all.

This plant mitragyna speciosa (aka kratom) is a mild plant related to coffee. It's not an opiate although it acts similarly. It is much more effective against pain and it doesn't give her the high, fuzzyheadedness of pain pills. It leaves her clear headed, virtually pain free and she can take care of our daughter while I work and feel like she has a wonderful mother. Before She found it She was suicidal because she just wanted to enjoy her life with the baby we always wanted and not be curled in a ball in pain all day. She doesn't want to feel like a burden to me and our daughter and her other loved ones.

Please do not take my wife away from me.  I only just got her back from all this pain a couple of years ago.  Her doctor is aware that she takes this plant and is glad she found something that helps her.  Don't take her from me and our daughter.  She is so happy right now and so full of life.  She wants to teach yoga when our daughter gets in school.  Don't take her dreams away from her by forcing her back into her chronic pain and suicidal thoughts.  

This plant should be available for responsible adults.  Teens and children probably shouldn't have access to it until more research is done, but it has had no ill effects on my wife in the 2.5 years she's taken it or any of her friends that take it.  It's only given their lives back.

Thank you for taking the time to read this and thanks for letting us comment.  Please have some empathy for chronically ill people and don't turn them into criminals or take their plant away.

Sincerely,
Casey

documents.commentText:
Banning kratom expands the war on drugs, while the public overwhelmingly supports ending it.
If kratom is added to any one of the five drug schedules, people who use it will be criminalized and locked up behind bars.
Kratom has been used safely by millions of people in the U.S. and evidence supports kratom's potential as a pain reliever and opioid replacement.
Many people struggling with opioid addiction have turned to kratom to help them cut back or quit, but now all promising scientific studies on kratom's role in opioid treatment could be immediately shut down.
Side effects of kratom are minimal, and its withdrawal symptoms are weak and nearly inconsequential compared to the suffering of people trying to quit opioids.
Prohibiting kratom will worsen the country's problems of opioid addiction and overdose.

documents.commentText:
To whom it may concern,

Kratom has been a personal live-saver for me. I'm 33 years old, and I've had chronic spinal issues for 13 years. Over the past decade, my doctors have prescribed any number of narcotics to "manage" my pain. I have taken so much hydrocodone over the years, and nearly became addicted. My tolerance for opioids and muscle relaxants was very high because of this, which caused my doctors to prescribe even stronger medications. Thankfully, after doing extensive research on holistic ways to manage chronic pain, I found kratom. With the help of kratom and physical therapy, my pain has decreased significantly and my life has become much better. I'm not sure if you know how damaging chronic pain can be to your whole body and mind. Living in pain day-in, day-out causes your life to erode and wilt. You stop wanting to move, for fear of a flare up. Your brain gets conditioned to expect pain and suffering every day, which leads to depression. My family, my career, and my mental wellness were all greatly affected by my chronic pain. Kratom has been a godsend to me; It has taught me how to enjoy life again, and realize that I can live without the constant fear of pain. Please consider the life-altering ramifications of banning kratom, and the millions of Americans it will harm. More research needs to be done on kratom, and that will be nearly impossible should it become a schedule 1 drug. Our healthcare system is set up to get people addicted to drugs, and then blame them for their addiction. I had taken naproxen and prescription high dose ibuprofen and found little relief. I was then put on prescription opioids hydrocodone/apap and later oxycodone. I really hope those in the DEA will make an informed decision on the ban that's been proposed. I would like to believe the DEA is a respectable organization that would not attack such an effective non addictive supplement as a drug they should treat like heroin or cocaine. The quality of my life will be decreased significantly by the decision to ban this plant and I will participate in every option I can find to try to reverse this if it is banned. Sincerely, Audra Fox

documents.commentText: My name is Charltien Long and I am am undergraduate neuroscience student at Johns Hopkins University.  I am writing to urge the DEA not to place Kratom/Mitragynine into Schedule 1.  I believe that there may be medical benefits to the compound for patients potentially ranging from psychiatric disorders to drug addiction.  As a student who undertakes independent scientific research, I find it very important that careful research be undertaken to determine the medical value or dangers of this compound before a final determination is made on this level of legal status.  Placing it into schedule 1 would effectively stifle all potential scientific research in this area.  While I believe some form of regulation may be needed, if there is a possibility that this may be shown scientifically as an effective adjunct treatment for opioid addiction, then the compound should not be placed into schedule 1 in order to preserve our opportunity to learn more about it.  Moreover, little is known about its societal impact or the lives of those who take it, more careful public health and sociological inquiry is needed to understand these questions more fully.  Overall, I would urge the DEA and the Justice Department to consider the potential medical benefits and ensure that research on the compound can continue so that informed regulatory decisions can be made more readily.

My son has been trying to get "clean" for almost two years now, he went from prescription pain medications to heroin to methadone.  It would have been easier to stay on the heroin and withdraw from that than to try and get off the methadone.  He is unemployed, and qualifies for state medical assistance, which pays for his methadone.  However, the privately run clinic he goes to has no intention of helping him "get off" the drug that is their big (government subsidized) cash cow.  The medical assistance he gets does NOT cover rehab or detox services, but will continue to pay for his methadone indefinitely.  There is no counseling or advice given to these countless poor addicted souls who wander in and out of the clinic's revolving doors on a daily basis for their "dose" to help them get off this evil LEGAL drug that becomes their slave master on a daily basis.  

That being said, my son has grown tired and angry of this hamster wheel and being sabotaged at every turn by said clinic to get himself off of the methadone.  He has spent countless hours researching and has put together a step-by-step program he can do on his own that will help manage his withdrawal symptoms and put an end this methadone misery he lives every day.  One of the integral ingredients in his program involves the use of Kratom, the very drug that now the government wants to step in and and get their hands on, which I am certain would make it just about impossible for someone like my son to get.  He broke down into tears when he read of the possible restrictions that were about to be imposed on Kratom should it become a Schedule I substance.  The use of Kratom, along with numerous other supplements, herbs, oils and vitamins, has given him the first shred of hope he has had in almost two years that he may one day lead a drug free life again, free from the shackles of methadone usage. I beg you to keep this substance readily obtainable and not make it a Schedule I drug, so that my son and others like him have a means to get through the living hell of methadone withdrawal.
